This game got me back into city-builders and management sims. I am now the proud owner of too many titles to mention and still return to play this often, and that's without any additional content beyond the base game. It's Christmas and the expansions are on sale, so I think I'll have playability for a lonnnnng time with this one. At least until Frostpunk 2 comes out, for sure!

It has now been over two years since my initial review, and I still come back to spend time with this game often. I am still patiently waiting for FP2, and the thought of it coming out this year has me playing FP1 more. Again. Two years later. Dammit.

I actually love this game. A lot. I have 31 hours in it, got a decent way through but some kind of update has made the game completely unplayable. I was playing fine until yesterday - today the game is completely broken, does not launch (I see snowflakes, but it is extremely slow, sound does not work, and then it crashes). I KNOW the issue is not my PC, I have a very high performance system and every other game I have still works fine. I've tried all the troubleshooting steps, uninstalling/reinstalling multiple times, verifying game files, clearing download cache, updating C++ etc. everything. Very disappointing, I get maybe 3 hours every 2 or 3 weeks to play and I've just spent those trying to fix this mess. Game is currently broken, do not buy. If the issue is resolved I will happily change this to a positive review, game is awesome when it works.

The main campaign is a bit short. Took me about 30 hours to beat with a lot of restarts until I got everything perfect. Even then the ending still managed to make me feel unprepared. It's pretty challenging and intense, you must be looking for ways to optimize all the time if you don't want to fail and/or have to make some difficult decisions. Overall a 9/10. As far as city builders go, it's pretty unique, and the steampunk aesthetic is impeccable.
Gr8 Game

A trailblazer in the "City Survival" genre, as such it focuses largely on a short but intense management of resources and time instead of endless dissociated economic growth and efficiency. the game manages to solve 2 big problems in city builder genre, the lack of real meaningful consequences, and the city essentially running itself

Unlike Timberborn, Frostpunk has END conditions, you can fail to keep your promises and be a dick to your people and you will be executed. Fail to raise hope for a better tomorrow and you will Banished. Population is also a non renewable resource (the main scenario operates on a fixed timescale of a 41 days) so every death does matter you can't come back from a disaster. but you can actually complete the game with a recap and reflection of your actions throughout the play-through

In Frostpunk building is managed at the player level with no automatic zoning or building you must place down everything yourself in the most efficient way otherwise you may end up wasting valuable space and resources or placing buildings outside of heat zones which are a necessity for your city's survival. 

Consequences are severe and unforgiving, fail to increase food supply and your city will get sick more often with a penalty to their recovery time which may lead to you having to sign "alternative food sources" leading to less people to gather food which sustains a "Doom Loop". fail to increase medical supply and efficiency and you end up with people who cant work who will die if they cant get proper treatment or will end up as amputees/palliatives who still cant work 

being a trailblazer in this kind of genre it does have some things to note, namely the scale. Frostpunk operates on micro scale not only in population but also in features as it was designed around a fixed timescale in game. the endless mode suffers from the previously mentioned "hands off city" which largely leads the player to go "the city can provide for itself, survival is no longer a challenge so why should i continue?" simply put if you are expecting City Skylines with a post apocalypse themeing this isn't it go back and worry about traffic flow.

For those of you who appreciate city building games, Frost Punk offers a fresh new take on the decades old genre. Thrust into the harsh icy environment that is frostland and forced to manage your resources along with balancing the hope and discontent of your residents creates a tense atmosphere where every decision you make has lasting effects on the future of your city's progress. 

What hooks me in with this game compared to others in the genre are the unique mechanics in a compelling setting that makes the experience more intriguing and breaks the mold of some of the other city management games that I have played in the past. 

If you like city building games then this is for you.

This game does deliver on that "survival" feeling, even as a strategy game. I felt like I was living in a very bleak world, like that book, The Road, so the setting here was crafted marvelously. The little choices you can make as far as laws and what direction to "police" your town make the replays all feel different as well. It's exciting to see how much you can get done before a disaster strikes. For additional fun: play with your thermostat off in winter!

In my opinion this is by far the best city building game. The game play is fantastic. It has amazing replay ability, the game is complex enough to make you keep coming back, and the gameplay and mechanics work really well with the atmosphere. Speaking of atmosphere this game's whole style is amazing, the graphics are awesome being able to watch your people go around in there day to day lives, and the models are amazingly detailed. The dark, almost hopeless atmosphere the game is based around makes it interesting and captivating. 8.7/10 - would die of frostbite again.

The game is fine, it's one of the best management games out there despite some clear problems in difficulty and build variety (there is essentially no versatility to the tech tree in reality, but you're free to pick sub-optimal builds if you like). In all the tech tree is easily the least interesting part of this game.

My problem is with the way saving was implemented. There is no auto-save frequency adjustment, there are not multiple quicksave slots, the game save system breaks if there are too many saves, and you can't delete the saves on the hard drive outside the game without risking screwing up quite a bit (they will auto-repopulate from the cloud). My game currently no longer can generate quick or auto-saves at this point and there is no information regarding this.

IF the devs respond it's going to be post a bug report. Except they don't respond to posts in the steam discussion bug forum (why have it then) and they refer you to a typical "worst in class" EA customer support copy paste: A "FAQ" attempting to reduce ticket load that was clearly never vetted that it did performed the intended effect. It is, in typical fashion, so laden with unnecessary garbage that it amounts to a modern EULA "read and accept" strategy rather than anything helpful to the user experience. Likely outsourced.

Ultimately I don't trust the next project by this developer given their treatment of the current project, and not only have a lost a number of saves but I now can't really use this one as the saving is entirely manual at this point.

UPDATE: The support response was to reinstall Steam. As I am sure I will have to reinstall the folders that contain the local files to fix the save issues, this means full reinstall with all games I have. Absolute insanity.

Frostpunk is a interesting take on the steampunk game genre. Coupled with the fact that it is also a city builder/resource management game. 

Frostpunk itself is a very stable game and pretty balanced in terms of difficulty level. A person experienced with resource management should be able to master this game in about a day or two. With some help from videos explaining the games mechanics. The mechanics themselves make sense, but can also be exploited (Ex. Turning off the generator during the day to conserve coal, but turning it on at night so that people wont get sick).

The atmosphere of this game is also very rich, it really does feel like your fighting for survival. Desperately clutching to every little bit of wood, coal and food that you have in order to survive and maybe thrive in this new cold hell. 

I would go into more detail, but that would take an enormous amount of time that I'm not willing to spend on a steam review. Overall, game is good. Waiting on the 2nd game now.

Great game, however outposts are still very bugged, which makes particular scenarios quite difficult to complete. In every scenario, I've experienced one or more of the following bugs with outposts:
1. The outpost team delivers resources once, then no more and seems to just disappear. When I dismantle the outpost, despite having just delivered resources, the outpost team is positioned at the outpost.
2. Despite having multiple outpost depots, sending multiple outpost teams to separate outposts just doesn't work.
3. When dismantling an outpost, the outpost team gets stuck there and cannot be selected to be ordered to return to the city.
4. When disbanding the outpost team, the workers belonging to that team disappear and aren't added back to your workforce.

Frostpunk is a well made, dystopic survival city builder in a steampunk setting. 

It has an Interesting storyline, with a world enduring a never ending frost/ice age during a victorian setting. It captivates immediately. The entire game has an enthralling soundtrack which I really liked.

Just finished the main arc, although I had to start over a couple of times because I didn't have the strategy right.  Whilst making your way through the technologies, building layout strategies, decisions and challenges you'll warm yourself through the big frost. Quite challenging at first, but once you get the hang of it, it'll make you want to step up a difficulty level higher.

This game will give me still a lot of hours of gaming pleasure when I start the other scenarios.

In conclusion, very enjoyable if you like city builders and strategy games. The many different scenario's have a good pace and don't bore at all. Very recommendable!

So if you're hesitant do try it and if you like it I recommend you try The Last Autumn too. And don't worry about the difficulty, you'll get over it. Definitely the best city builder/resource management game I've ever played. The meat of the game, the scenarios, are strongly narrative driven and each provide their own unique challenges. The presentation of challenges is great, with the first scenario "A New Home" giving you a solid introduction to the overall gameplay, and the other scenarios forcing you to focus on different playstyles to overcome the new challenges. The visual style and sound design are unique, powerful, and emotional, doing a wonderful job of placing you in the shoes of the leader of these last flickering bastions of humanity in the face of the relentless cold. 

At first, you will likely struggle to keep ahead of the curve as events and the ever decreasing temperature conspire to destroy your city and wipe out the last of humanity. But, as you learn the systems and what to focus on, you will gain a sense of dominance over the awesome power of mother nature. There is no combat, only the cold and human nature to fight against. 

While the scenarios do limit replayability, with the endless mode being something of a letdown, I still find myself coming back again and again to the frostland to try my hand over and over with different strategies to survive. As mentioned, the stories told in the scenarios paired with the amazing string led ost have a way of making you want to revisit them again and again. 

While you probably won't get the amount of hours of of Frostpunk like you might in other city builders like Rimworld or Dwarf Fortress, the themes and overall impact of this game is much, much more powerful. To be honest, ever since the last DLC for Frostpunk was released, I've been trying to fill the Frostpunk-shaped hole in my heart, and have found every other  game in the genre lacking. I only hope that when 2 is released, it is half as good as this game.

Years after release the original glitches with graphics and sound have not been fixed. 
> Cut-scene audio is choppy and keeps cutting out.
> In-game graphics on "Medium" overload even a high-spec machine.
> There is a lot of effort put into graphics and a dozen settings to adjust them, but no slider for "screen movement speed". So using mouse or keyboard to move to POV around the map makes the camera "jump" instead of sliding smoothly.

On an aesthetic note, the music is very one-tone and depressing. I get that it matches the struggle theme, but it does not change even if you thrive. It has successfully created a depressing atmosphere that I cannot bare for more than an hour.

Do yourself a favour and buy Frostpunk. I'm very much looking forward to the sequel.

[h1]Russia Simulator[/h1]

The Earth has died, leaving behind a frozen wasteland and a few hundred ragged survivors, who you are responsible for keeping alive through the next month. Decide whether the dozens of children should sit around in school learning their ABCs, or if they should carry their weight through labor. When one of them inevitably dies in a workplace accident, decide whether to give them a proper funeral or to toss their body into a frozen trench. Then decide whether their cadaver is best utilized as replacement organs for the living, soil to feed your crops, or just straight up soylent green.

Listen to your colonists grumble about having to work 12-hour shifts instead of a 9-to-5 to live through the end of the world. Decide whether this last remnant of mankind should find hope through a strict theocracy of zealotry, a more secular, authoritarian regime, or something a bit more permissive. Decide whether the masses of near-dead refugees knocking on your door should be allowed in to further tax your limited resources, or if they should be left out in the cold to die. Watch your angry torch-bearing colonists gather in the middle of an apocalyptic -100¬∞C storm to protest the decisions you made to ensure their collective survival. Get boiled alive after they decide they'd rather freeze than live under your rule.

Frostpunk isn't the kind of game that offers thousands of hours of gameplay, but what it does, it does well. The lore is quite good. There are four standalone story scenarios, all with unique gimmicks, which each take around two or three days of playing to get through, plus three endless modes. An additional two scenarios are available through DLC. It has some questionable balancing, but overall feels solid and is challenging. The ethical dilemmas are brutal and offer numerous replay possibilities. You spend most of your time zoomed way out from your city, but if you zoom in you'll find that your decisions have a lasting impact in the fine details. Making it through the "final boss" feels epic, and should you pull it off, there's a unique surprise waiting for you in the ending.

Frostpunk gets a solid recommend from me.

This is a game for people who like to be punished by spending money on something that will frustrate them instead of coddling them.  There is no intuitive path of options for an easy play.  This game is probably more difficult than surviving the scenario itself would actually be.  

I loved it.  I swore a lot.  A LOT.  I learned to make immoral choices (do not take in all of the refugees that show up, they will eat your food and complain until they rebel and cast you out into the cold).  Do not take risky actions with your explorers, as they will always die and send more refugees as a result.

The only complaint that I actually would say that I have about this game is the limited replay value.  In an endless scenario, I had maxed out all of the tech, had an endless amount of resources, and really nothing further to do.  I could get up and leave my computer for hours and nothing bad could really happen (barring random events), so there was no point in continuing beyond that point.  

Overall, I like this genre to an extent, and hope to see more games like this.  I'd also like to see more advancements, perhaps one day adding the ability to build steam cores.

Frostpunk presents players with moral dilemmas, where tough decisions must be made for the survival of their society. While I may have resorted to extreme measures such as child labor, it's the ethical implications of providing only soup to the people that truly highlight the darker aspects of human nature.

Despite these grim realities, Frostpunk manages to captivate with its compelling gameplay and atmospheric storytelling. The chilling setting contrasts with moments of warmth and humanity, creating a truly immersive experience.

In the end, Frostpunk succeeds in delivering a thought-provoking journey that challenges players to confront the best and worst of human nature.

A wonderful immersion into bleakness and desperation. At its core, this game is about efficiency management, with each decision crucial to your survival. You have to take into account the efficiency of which citizens work where, efficiency of building placement, efficiency what tech to research or what laws to pass at what time, and overall what to prioritize. Many times you will be torn between multiple difficult options, such as healing the sick so they're able to work again vs. researching better healing methods that will help down the line, or using your limited steel resources to build an automaton and free up some workers vs. building better-insulated homes to prepare for brutal temperature drops. All of this lies under the blanket of limited time and desperation as harsh sacrifices are made to avoid disaster. I found myself lost for hours at a time playing this game, as it feels like an honest, dynamic story of a settlement trying to survive rather than a simple city-builder.

This is a fantastic game of economy, colony management, lore, and strategy. 

It is also a game with the world's worst mechanics in some places, which make it infuriating to play.
Timer ticking down to the *boot-you-out-of-your-game* moment? No warnings, no blinking, bam.
Got banished? No "oops I left the game running", no "let me try that again", not even an extra autosave to go back to. Just need that 10 extra in-game seconds for the melt? Too bad.
Scout arrived at a point and is awaiting instructions? Guess they'll just hang out in the corner until you notice.
Wanna build roads? Use the button for the tech tree, but click the build button first.
Wanna zoom in just a tad? Guess you wanted to see the intricate details in the floor.

For a game with as carefully planned play mechanics as this is, it is aggravating to feel like you're actively being told not to play it, especially when so many of the mechanics are completely opaque to you until  the moment you need it - the replay value is almost entirely founded on "oh I didn't know I had to do that".

In the beginning I wanted to make everyone happy and comfortable but then it started getting colder and resources started getting scarcer. I kept bringing hope and addressed discontentment. I wanted all children and families to be happy.  

Then came the harsher weather... People started getting hungry and sick, discontentment rose and hope fell. People started complaining about my leadership... So what? Well I sent a couple groups out on expeditions to find more resources. In the meantime, I made moonshine, hired prostitutes and people got drunk and happy. 

A storm was coming and we were already below -100 degrees. People got sick, hungry, and were freezing to death. I was doing my best every single day to keep most alive but they were falling like flies. I closed the strip club, forced children to work, left some a bunch of people homeless, and purposely reduced heat, and rationed coal and food. People were so mad that they were threatening to leave, and I was on the verge of being banished. Lucky for me, I had passed a law to silence opposition through my faith keepers police, and sent them to beat people up to force them to comply. I imposed overtime and even 24 hours a day work shifts on people and children so that the city can survive.

Instead of wasting time singing praises to this great game, let me tell you a story of a wise old man.

A dying old man is my one true nemesis in the entire game. I first met him in the "New Home" scenario, trying to get the deathless walkthough and "golden path" achievements on hard difficulty. Mind you, it wasn't particularly hard once I made it through the first few days, so I was preparing to take it easy after that. After a few days since building my first house of healing, an event popped up with a message from a dying old man: "I die not of cold or starvation, I leave this world in peace after living a good long life; all thanks to the wonderful city you've build! Thank you from the bottom of my heart, GG WP, BTW your deathless achievement is now screwed!" Aw... such kind words... wait, what?!

The second time the event popped up in the Endless mode on extreme difficulty. The problem was that the decaying body of the old geezer in a healing house was causing an obvious discontent among the rest of the community, who demanded I did something about it. Because the event popped up quite early in the game, at the moment I didn't introduce any funeral law, having my hands full with lots of other problems demanding an immediate solution. Seriously, if you expect people to die soon and have to introduce a funeral law to counter the aftermath in advance, then you're most probably doing something very very wrong. You know, maybe try focusing on making sure they don't die in the first place? Regardless, here I stood on a verge of being exiled due to people getting mildly annoyed with extended shifts in almost all imaginable workplaces, eating soup for the past couple of week, freezing in their sorry tents they would have to call home for a very long time yet, and a storm coming in a few days. And among all these problems comes a dying old man and says: "Thank you for building this wonderful settlement that let me spend my final days in warmth and peace! BTW, I noticed you don't have a funeral law. So here's my last gift to you in a form of my rotting corpse which will hopefully cause an epidemic."

Since I literally only just accepted a different law, I had to wait for a 1.5 days before introducing another one. But alas, extreme discontent  from all the things above didn't let me say: "Hey people, I've got an idea! Let's dump the old man's corpse in a pit, freeze it up and then later on cut it into organs to help heal the sick!"

As I wasn't keen on forsaking the access to an awesome +20% healing speed buff by accepting the god-awful cemetery law (again, if you expect people to die and want to minimize the consequences, you're doing it wrong), I had to instead let people vent off their frustration in the arenas to slightly decrease the discontent and deal with the old man's corpse in yet another day. The plan had failed miserably, because after one more day the foul smell of a rotting dead guy was so strong that no amount of arena fighting could help people forget its existence. The whole story lasted for about 4 days until I finally got a grip and told my people: "Let's dump the old wise man into the pit" without the risk of being dumped there along with him.

Alas, much to my surprise, it wasn't the last gift from the old man. Several days later I noticed there was no body in the pit, which was suspicios at best. A bit later I came across a sick child stuck in "disposing of a corpse" status. Either the wise old man was a heavyweight, or the kid was too weak from living on soup, but the status wasn't going away, and the kid just stood there above the rotting corpse (which, apparently, stopped bothering people a long while ago). As days went by, the child became gravely ill and then passed away right above the old man, not being able to finish this one task he was ever asked for.

Thus began a long sequence of bugged-out corpses people could not dump, instead getting stuck above the bodies until they joined them. The old man did not pass away alone, eventually taking the whole settlement with him. And such was the last gift of a dying old man.

Edit: a few years later, this is still my most vivid memory from the game. That said, I highly recommend it to everyone and can't wait to play the sequel!

Since "Frostpunk" is a game that appeals to me in every way, I played the game for hundreds of hours. At one point during this time, as I started playing the "The Last Autumn" DLC again, I said, "This time I'm going to play realistically. I'll do whatever I would do if I was the leader of this project".
Ever since I was little, I dream of being a member of different kinds of managerial professions. This dream continued in my youth and I graduated from law school. I carefully choose the books I will read, the movies I will watch, the games I will play; I care about my personal development. For all these reasons, I was sure that I would play this game as myself this time, and I started the game in hard mode with the mentality of "even if I don't reach the ideal ending in the game, so be it". Indeed, my people were dying, getting sick, getting pretty hungry, and I couldn't keep up. I couldn't offer them safe working conditions, and I couldn't fulfill their demands for the most part. In order to complete the project on time, I had to compromise my values and even not allow a father to return home when he learned of his daughter's illness.
-And on the 29th day I signed the ‚ÄúTerror‚Äù from the book of law.-
I built an execution place. Next morning announcement was made and at 07:30 am one of my people executed. The time elapsed between the announcement and the execution may be a short time in the game, but it hosted so many emotions and thoughts... Did the rulers also go through these stages? What would be the extent of my corruption in real life in those circumtances? Was it because it was a game, or would I really be like this in the future?". Frostpunk may be a game, but it was a simulation for me in my that experience. A simulation that slams me in the face that I need to develop and consolidate myself and my ethical values. A simulation about how possible it is for the rulers to stray from the path.
You did it again. With This War of Mine when we traded jewelry for a broken guitar and a teddy bear, you made us understand what war actually is. And in Frostpunk, you explained how difficult it can be to make decisions for others, to manage and employ groups of people with limited resources and difficult choices, from a different perspective than the majority. The game itself is an incredible experience, but the reflection of this event on me is in a different dimension.

Let me tell you a story, of the first time i won in frostpunk. The journey of New London. At first things were difficult.
We struggled through the harsh cold, barely scrounging up enough food and wood to feed and shelter everyone. But I insisted on running a moral city, children would play not work, the disabled would not be abandoned but cared for. Things were hard, but we survived. With the sweat of our brow and the strength of our souls, we soldiered on.
Our goal was to find another settlement, many groups like ours had set out, hoping to find salvation around a generator. We quickly learned of a place called Winterhome, but all the places that we heard about them were abandoned‚Ä¶. Full of frozen corpses‚Ä¶
We tried not to think about it, hope slowly fell, but we prayed.
Then a man arrived. Bearing horrible news.
Winterhome had fallen. They had failed. They had all froze, starved to the point of cannibalising their dead.
We were alone in this world, alone and very cold.
Hope dramatically fell, people began a new movement, the Londoners, people who wanted to return to London, thinking that surely that great city could not fall.
Unbeknownst to them, London was a city of frozen ghosts now.
And so, i saw them needing purpose. And in desperation, i gave them one. Faith.
I used the power of faith to give them a new purpose, with churches and shines, im no zealot, but anything to prevent the city from falling, right? The city must not fall, no matter what‚Ä¶ right?
First it was churches,then prayers, then shines, then repentance, then secret faith keepers, then secret informants.
Friend turned on friend, family against one another, turning them in for any sight of dissent or thievery.
And i embraced it, it kept hope up, so i did what gave the city the best chance.
Then came the storm.
Refugees from throughout the land, came speaking of death, of doom, of a great wall of frost purging the land of all life. It would come in 15 days. And they were not lying, it was a monster. Cold sheer death, ready to kill the last city on earth. We frantically tried to prepare, mandatory sermons to keep faith and hope up, 24 hour shifts. I worked men to death to get enough coal to last. The refugees begged us to save the other groups of refugees out there from the storm. They didn't know it was coming, and would surely all be killed.
I left them to die, more mouths would could barely feed.
When the storm came, we hunkered down and prayed, for there was nothing else we could do.
The winds howled, and the air grew colder.
From -94 Fahrenheit, to -112, then -130
Our children huddled up with their parent to conserve warmth. A mans daughter ran out into the storm, fearing the city would freeze. Her father came to us, begging to be allowed to go after her. We allowed it. Feeling he would die.
As frost grew around our windows and we forced the generator to burn hotter and hotter, the temperature continued to drop, more and more
-148
-166
-184
I laid everyone off from their jobs and told them to stay with their families and pray, huddle to their fires and hope.
Our hospitals filled with men, women and children, all with severe frostbite, hands dead and blackened from the icy cold.
And right as the storm grew near its end.
The air dropped to a final deadly freeze.
Two-hundred and thirty-eight degrees below zero.
Our hospitals were overwhelmed, over half the city was dying, frostbite was rampant. I feared all our sacrifices would be for nothing.
Then.  The storm was over
We had survived, the last city on earth had weathered the worst storm in human history.
But at what cost?
I had created a zealous state, where secret police cracked down on any resistance. I banished drunken men to their deaths for spreading fear. I ordered the sickest to be left to die to save the many. I tore apart families and left hundreds to die in the cold to save what i could.
We survived, but had we lost our humanity?
Was it worth what we had done?

Any game that can take you on a journey like that is well worth it.

Frostpunk is one of the best designed, dynamic, and challenging city builder games ever made.

The UI and gameplay of Frostpunk is very easy to understand, and this is because the game is a marvel of good game design. The main campaign functions as the tutorial and introduces all the mechanics needed to beat the game without taking away player choice. The tutorial aspects of the main campaign are barely even noticeable on repeat playthroughs because of how non-intrusive they are. The UI consists of just a few huge buttons, and there are images of the buildings in the UI itself along with construction prices and a brief summary of what the building does to make things extra clear. Every menu is quick & responsive and clicking out of menus is just a right click. Buildings automatically resize to fit slightly off building spaces. Frostpunk‚Äôs UI is seamless and easy to master in a single playthrough, but there is an in-game instruction guide and official wiki supported if necessary. Its done so well that you do not even notice it.

What makes Frostpunk‚Äôs gameplay exceptional is that unlike a lot of other games in the city builder and even survival city builder genre is that it demands that the city always be adapting to new conditions and objectives. Research and laws are limited/restricted by time, and this means many ways to approach each campaign. Researching a better generator at the start may mean less people sick & more efficient early game gathering, but more people will need to be dedicated to coal and this may justify pushing out child labor or brutal 14-hour shifts. On all settings it only takes an hour of extreme cold weather to cause amputations and deaths. Coal demands are exponential, and on Hard+ the temperature can suddenly drop multiple levels early into a campaign or Endless Mode before proper heating upgrades have even been researched.  The game does a very good job at adding obstacles and a whole campaign may just be a constant challenge of putting out fires and whatever it takes to just keep the city going as the temperature plunges.

Frostpunk is a great example of games as art as all its mechanics and even its difficulty tie into its story and message. The key word in the title is ‚ÄúPunk‚Äù, but this is not just some shallow message about the police and church being bad. Its about the nature of cooperation and how authoritarianism comes from the weakness and fear of societies being exploited by cynical or even desperate well meaning leaders. 

Frostpunk is a well-designed game about building a constantly changing city in a brutally difficult setting. It offers a very valuable humanist message that is supported by amazing art & music design. Its definitely worth its full price with its expansions, and a must-buy on sale.

Pros:

- the win in this game is not handed out. You WILL earn it, but once you figure out the key to victory, it is wash and repeat.

- Huge fan of tech tree advancement and this game supplies the goods. Once you get production going, the cost to upgrade is not really that expensive. 

- Building your settlement is a snap. Literally. The grid snapping for buildings is sharp with no glitchy bullcrap. 

Cons:

- Steep learning curve. You MUST learn the path to winning. There are not ‚Äú5 ways to win‚Äù. If you do not do specific crucial things you will die. Again and again. 

- convenient that storms always start at the beginning of a workday. No seriously, they ALWAYS do so it is too simple to count the hours to get your explorers back in time to not die and stuff. 

- There doesn‚Äôt seem to be any real way to stop engineers from building and stopping what they are assigned to. We should be able to set building new stuff to engineers ‚Äúnot assigned‚Äù. Your dudes will drop that wood they were collecting and build something across the map without care. Too bad you needed that wood. I would think that in tandem, queuing built items would be a great feature as well. 

I recommend the game but casual gamers may get frustrated.

It's fun. If you're into city sims, this is definitely worth a try.

It's a rough game when you want the best results out of every situation, but honestly, I think this is a great game that can help you to practice on learning proper leadership for any kind of situation you're thrown into, as you actually get to practice on the idea of how empathy is done effectively and in which context solutions are brought up in the relevant time frame. When you're a leader, it is tempting to take the shortest term possible solution to get out desired results and gain approval from people, but that will have other permanent costs instead. Your people, end up doing the work for you, so that you get to take it easy, which I feel is not right to do, as games tend to focus on letting you do just that. On top of that, most people don't have the information available as you may have, they might not have the capacity to understand straight away given the circumstances. Simply put, this is a game where you get to learn how to take care of people properly and you'll notice how to do the most humane tasks is the most difficult there is to pull off, but it is the best long term option there is, even if it can appear that your people grow very slowly together. However, I think this is where this quote comes in: "The slow and steady wins the race."

Don't sacrifice people if you can choose it, seems to be the moral of this game. Time management, is crucial for success!

I then find one thing interesting: Is there a way to learn to enjoy doing all of this? I believe there should be and things tends to get easier the more you stick on doing something you're focused reaching the most humane outcomes there is.

This is a great game.

Beautiful, thematic, but punishing and punitive and consequently not really much fun until you discover you can play the campaign on an easier setting by going to 'scenarios'. 

The difficulty out of the gate is too hard (medium by default but fiercely punishing) and the tutorials too sparse, consequently you learn through trial and error more than strategy. For instance there will be tech you wouldn't intuitively think to prioritise but if you don't you're essentially done. 
You won't realise at first but once behind the curve in any particular area it's almost impossible to meaningfully recover, so begins the slow and inexorable decline until defeat with no reset button. Any solution will cost you lots of resources you can ill afford and once spent will be behind where you need to be in some other area. Beautifully thematic whilst you're doing this you'll really 'feel the struggle' which many praise this game for, but investing hours of effort only to have to eventually wait to lose and start again isn't fun. 
Be great to lower the difficulty out of the box so I could enjoy some struggle but ultimately be victorious. I eventually found you could play the main story as a 'scenario' and tweak the difficulty down after 8 hours of several excruciating playthroughs. Even on easy if you don't near max out the tech tree and stockpile like crazy you won't survive. 

Can only see the appeal for folks that like to throw themselves at adversity until they can perfect there way through the maze a la Dark Souls and Elden Ring. Nothing wrong with that crowd, but it's not for everyone, which is a shame because this game otherwise could be :-)

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happineass of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Frostpunk is honestly not a bad game and it can be fun but at the same time it can be very frustrating as well. This is not a easy game at all and it requires a lot of micro managing. When you do succeed at making a successful colony the game will really start to open up and can become a lot of fun, this is why i am giving the game a thumbs up. With that being said this is not the game for everyone though as it can be very rough at times and can feel like a losing battle, unfortunately in this game if you make a bad decision or neglect a need it can result in failure pretty quickly. I have noticed there only seems to be 1 path to victory in this game and if you fail to take this path you will most likely lose. What i mean by this is there are things in this game that NEED to be prioritized in a specific order and failing to do so will cause you to lose. Sadly i do not think there are other ways that you can do things to make a successful colony, it seems you have to follow the same recipe over and over. Other than that the game can be fun.

"Frostpunk" is a gripping and atmospheric city-building survival game that takes players on a chilling journey into a frozen post-apocalyptic world. Developed by 11 bit studios, this game offers a unique blend of strategy, resource management, and tough moral decisions. Released in 2018, "Frostpunk" has earned praise for its challenging gameplay and compelling narrative.

Graphics and Atmosphere:
The first thing that strikes players upon launching Frostpunk is its stunning visuals. The icy landscapes, detailed buildings, and weather effects create a truly immersive and chilling atmosphere. The game's art direction perfectly captures the desperation of a society struggling against the harsh cold.

Gameplay:
At its core, Frostpunk challenges players to establish and manage the last city on Earth in the midst of a new ice age. The central gameplay mechanic revolves around balancing resources like coal, food, and manpower to keep the city warm and its inhabitants alive. The game introduces a unique heat management system, where players must strategically place heating sources to prevent freezing, making every decision critical.

Moral Dilemmas:
One of the standout features of Frostpunk is its incorporation of moral dilemmas. As the leader, you must make tough choices that affect the well-being of your citizens. These decisions range from implementing harsh laws to sacrificing a few for the greater good. The consequences of your choices are not only reflected in the survival of your city but also in the emotional impact on the players.

Storytelling:
Frostpunk weaves a compelling narrative through a series of scenarios that unfold as you progress. The game presents a thought-provoking exploration of human nature under extreme conditions. The writing is poignant and succeeds in immersing players in the struggle for survival, adding an emotional layer to the overall experience.

Challenges and Replayability:
Frostpunk is not for the faint of heart. The game presents a steep learning curve and challenges players to adapt quickly to unforeseen circumstances. While the main scenarios provide a gripping experience, the game also offers various challenges and scenarios to keep players engaged long after the initial playthrough.

Conclusion:
In summary, Frostpunk stands out as a masterfully crafted survival game that goes beyond the typical city-builder. Its haunting atmosphere, challenging gameplay, and moral complexity make it a must-play for fans of the genre. Whether you're a strategy enthusiast or someone looking for a deeply emotional gaming experience, Frostpunk delivers a frozen symphony of survival that will stay with you long after the last embers fade away.

Wow, this is intense.  I've played some city/civ builders before, but the setting, stakes, and pacing in this game really keep you on the edge of your seat.  Compared to other similar games I've seen, it really forces you to micromanage and squeeze resources and space for maximum efficiency - which is stressful, but satisfying when you finally latch onto a successful strategy. Seems to have good replay value not only inasmuch as you will probably be banished into the frozen wastes the first time and have to start over, but because there are numerous branching choices to make in the scenarios which trigger different challenges and/or cause different outcomes.  Each scenario has run about 8-10 hours, which at least allows the satisfaction of finishing in one or two sessions, and adds some exciting urgency to your actions and tech choices, since there is no time to merely max everything out.  The replay factor compensates for the shorter game length.  Minor downsides for me are the camera perspective - although you can pan, zoom, and rotate, the angle from above a canyon wall does block the view of perimeter buildings sometimes, and there's annoying inconsistency (perhaps purposeful?) on various equipment - some of which you can freely adjust and some you can't, regardless of tech tree advances.

[h1] Scores [/h1]

Gameplay: 9 - read below
Graphics: 8 - pretty good for strategy (no ray-tracing, DLSS, etc, which is ok for strategy genre)
Audio: 9 - atmospheric, relaxing at times and engaging at times
Scenario: 8 - keeps challenged and interesting, depends on your decisions
UI/UX: 9 - easy to navigate, nicely designed, fits well into theme

[h1] Target audience [/h1]

If you like clicking the same buttons without thinking - this won't fit you.
If you like games that require pretty decent brain usage, but don't want to spend hours to learn it - this is it.

[h1] What is it about? [/h1]
Your people is at the edge of extinction. What kind of decisions will you make?
Will you be able to keep human moral values, or will you forget them to survive?
The game will challenge [b]both[/b] your strategic thinking and moral values.
Get ready to make tough decisions and take responsibility for them.

[h1] How hard is it? [/h1]
Game mechanics is easy-to-get. Does not require hours to get in, you'll get into it in minutes.
Yet the game itself is hard, requires decent brain usage. Has difficulty levels to fit everyone.
Gameplay is not repetitive. The possibilities grow gradually as your settlement grows,
in a way that it feels refreshing but not overwhelming.

[h1] How long is it? [/h1]
It gave me ~50 hours of interesting experience in one main scenario only,
and there are other scenarios + replayability. Definitely worths the time and money.
A game session typically took 1-2 hours, since it's an "atmospheric" game.
Yes you can play 10 minutes and have progress, but make sure to keep an eye on the watch ;)

[h1] Rare note for a strategy game [/h1]
This game has NO silver-bullet. Tell me if you find one! :)
I have played lots of strategies - Age of Empires, CnC, Stronghold, Warhammers, Total Wars, SimCity etc... 
Found silver bullets in lots of them in just matter of *hours*.
Yes, some easy steps which can be repeated again and again to gain lots of money, resources...
So those games became boooringly easy after ~20 hrs, and I either stopped playing or carried just for the scenario.

Yet, did not find such silver bullet in FrostPunk! Its quite well-balanced, congrats to 11BIT!
So this is the 3rd strategy without such issue, along with Anno and Discord Times. 

[h1] Verdict [/h1]
A rare game of the last decade that is unique, hard, fresh, non-copy-paste, and finally  - worth playing!

[b]Update for 2024: [/b] 6 years have passed! Yet, this game still remains the last non copy-paste strategy game of the decade.
You must try this game, man, rly amazing game if you love like this genres.
One of the greatest strategy games of this era.

This is probably my favorite game I've ever played. It took me a couple of tries before I beat the main story, and if that was all there was I could probably still play it for months, just because there's always a way to improve yourself and save more of your people. But there's a ton of additional content outside of the main story by itself that puts a whole new spin on the game! I don't think I'll ever get tired of it, not gonna lie.

One of my favorite things is how the world develops and the game progresses. It all feels natural and smooth and the way you have to be conscious of and cater towards your people. If you focus only on building and work and progress and disregard your people's needs/wants then that's how you'll really lose the game. It's a really fascinating dynamic you can play up when you do it well.

I absolutely love the music as well, Frostpunk has probably got one of my favorite video game soundtracks bar none; the way the songs build and provide atmosphere and feeling really immerse you in the world. You feel the fear, the dread, the hope, the loss, and at the end of the main story, the frantic need to survive no matter what it takes. It's absolutely remarkable.

A very accessible and atmospheric strategy game that is best played in winter. The scenario is a climate catastrophe set in an alternate reality in the period of the industrial revolution (basically steampunk) where people are forced to abandon cities and head off in steam engines to find a place to escape the weather. You are a colony leader and you must manage the resources in the locale of your steam generator to keep the colony alive and develop technologies to mitigate against the ever worsening cold weather. In the meantime, you may explore the wilderness outside of your colony in search of abandoned resources and other refugees. The population of the colony is subject to a mixture of hope and discontent which you can manage through enacting various laws. It also helps in this regard if you build things that give colonists a comfortable existence and you avoid working them too hard or causing them to become sick, injured, freezing or starving.

What a great game! Just completed the expansions, it's had me hooked from the start. What sets this city builder aside is the excellent story mode and great atmosphere. Makes other city painters look a bit dull and lifeless. Looking forward to FP2 already.

Strengths:

Unique setting and atmosphere: Frostpunk throws you into a harsh, frozen world where surviving the elements is a constant struggle. The grimy steampunk visuals and haunting soundtrack bring the world to life and build a constant sense of tension.
Tough choices and moral dilemmas: You'll face difficult decisions that force you to consider the needs of your people versus your own principles. Do you allow child labor to boost production? Do you enact harsh laws to maintain order? The game will make you confront the dark side of survival.
Deep city-building mechanics: Building your city requires careful planning and resource management. You need to ensure your people have enough heat, food, and work while expanding your reach for new resources.
High replayability: With different scenarios and choices to make, Frostpunk offers multiple playthroughs with unique experiences.
Weaknesses:

Can be brutally difficult: The game is unforgiving, and mistakes can have serious consequences. If you're not a fan of challenging games, Frostpunk might not be for you.
Slow pace: Building and managing your city can be time-consuming, especially in the early stages. Some players might find the pace too slow-burning.
Repetitive tasks: Certain tasks, like gathering resources, can become repetitive over time.
No true win state: There's no "perfect" ending in Frostpunk. You'll always be making sacrifices and dealing with the consequences of your choices.

Overall, Frostpunk is a well-made and thought-provoking game that won't shy away from challenging you both strategically and morally. However, its difficulty, slow pace, and lack of a definitive win state might not appeal to everyone.

Wow 45 hours flew by. I wasn't sure if I was going to like this game, but once you get going it is incredibly compelling. I enjoyed all of the scenarios, the last one was especially demanding. I recommend this game if you like challenging your raw brain power. You'll have to pay attention to a number of things at the same, which can be fun if that's the kind of game you enjoy. I found myself thinking about strategies and city planning throughout the day just to try to gain some sort of edge.  The combination of city planning, resource management, and thoughtful political decision making turns this city builder into so much more.

-No matter how many times you win, the game keeps telling you the same advice popups every time you play.
-For whatever reason buildings will sometimes take up more space than they need, which is both ugly and detrimental. (there are workarounds that sometimes work but it's still pointless and annoying)
-The sick can die on their way to healthcare and there is nothing you can do about it except endlessly reloading the save until they arrive. (This is super annoying if you are trying for a no death run)
-Both "purpose" law paths are the same in the end, the only difference is if it's a secular or religious dictatorship.
-Also, all the dlc sucks, especially "on the edge" where you can't side with the city or revoke the laws that they forcibly signed on you after you rebel.

I would recommend it if the first three issues were solved, but since they are making a new game right now it wont happen.

At the heart of this game, the loop is:
- play for a while
- make a mistake
- die
- play more, avoiding that mistake
- soon after, make another mistake
- die
- repeat
The story is definitely engaging, and the gameplay challenging, and that's why this ended up a positive review, but can also be frustrating and rather repetitive (in the handful of play-throughs I've given it so far) , and if that and the lack of "action" might annoy you, maybe give this one a miss. But if you've played Civilization to death, this might give some variety while using the same part of your brain.

If you have the type of autism where you like resource management, meticulous planning, optimising, and seeing numbers go up, this is the game for you.

I still have a few complaints here and there. While I enjoyed how in the main scenario the game refers to you as Captain--which is gender neutral and any player can feel immersed in--in some of the later scenarios characters refer to you as 'sir' or 'he' which sucks! Either keep it completely gender neutral, or let me choose my pronouns at the start. 

Also having all of the citizens be completely white feels ahistorical for Victorian era England, as by then there were DEFINITELY many immigrants from different cultures. It feels like a missed opportunity for this game about maintaining social harmony/overcoming discord not to include some of the inherent tensions between people of different backgrounds, plus would have made the NPC portraits of frozen white people a little less repetitive.

Also also, there are some years-old bugs in scenarios like Last Autumn that have never been fixed which is a bummer.

Overall though, worth the buy, especially if you can get the season pass on sale. All of the different scenarios offer completely new spins on the mechanics that are incredibly fun. Last Autumn and On The Edge are defs highlights.

I've played a number of these types of survival city-builder games. Frostpunk sets the standard. There is a constant sense of (fair) challenge even as you grow the city. It's very well paced and rewards players that think ahead and plan logically for worst-case scenarios. Speaking of scenarios, do NOT miss these fantastic extensions to the "New Home" main game. I was blown away by the number of gameplay mechanics they altered to make the scenarios feel like an entirely new challenge. Can't recommend enough. Bonus points for atmosphere if you play in the dead of winter.

When I came back and started the game I was greeted by a load option that was grayed out. I've tried everything I can think of and everything I could find on the internet to fix this because I actually really like the game but this makes it unplayable imo. This is not a problem only I have had.  It seems to affect a notable chunk of people who play this game. I've lost 12 hours to this bug and don't intend on sinking any more of my time into it. Was looking forward to the sequel coming out but this has left a bad taste in my mouth. If they can't fix an issue this game breaking years after being released.. I don't have high hopes for their future projects.

TLDR; The game is good but it deletes my saves every time I close it. It's not just me and I would recommend passing on this one. Worried about the sequel.

Have you ever played a game that looks amazing on paper and should be right up your alley but whenever you see its name in the library you get a horrible taste in your mouth and you start having flashbacks from the migraine you got the last time you played it? This is that game. 

Dark, miserable from one end to the other, with horrible immoral decisions you're forced to make just to stay afloat. Of course it gets easier once you find that single path that works, but getting there is very painful. 

However if you DO like pain and you are going to give it a chance, my advice to you is to pick a day when you're off work and you've got a good buffer of positive thoughts, cause at the end of the play session I guarantee you'll be feeling depressed.

Frostpunk is a game about Survival and Resource Management. But it is more than that. You will be pushed to the limit against inclement, unpredictable weather, constantly gathering valuable resources in a different timeline in the past. What are you going to do to survive? How far will you compromise your integrity and morals while making tough choices? People will die. It¬¥s up to you to give Humanity a final chance to survive while avoiding falling into barbarism and chaos. Immense replayability value with customizable scenarios. Enjoy this game.

 Argh

SPOILERS BELOW
   (if you dont want any spoilers, come back to read this review after at least trying a few times to make it in the arctic meatsicle paradise )     game rated   9/10  (in my opinion)

 Good village building and management game, with immersive storyline about helping people survive arctic meatsicle doom.  Spoiler alert kind of after this.  I would give this game top rating, if storyline was not contradicting itself ( after 30 days or so, after researching upgrade on beacon to forecast temperature ).  We are given choices to make during the story progression, sometime we choose not to take on extra people (survivors) we find exploring using the scouts, because we cant house them or feed them or both.  
     
     That being said, personaly, i chose to not take on survivors after my village was about 150 people, watching my coal and food consumptions, i estimated i could provide for about 150 people.  I do have a way to still rescue some survivors that will come live with us, by willingly having some of our villagers, die.  After numbers go down about 20-50 then theres room to rescue one group approx.  I have restarted about 6 times, just to test the different adaptation and purpose laws that we choose to instill.  
  2nd Spoiler kind of alert here.   a- I recommend you make children work (at safe places like cooking and farming as well as pickup resources when its warm enough for kids like warmer then -40), b- the only way i could get rid of londoners, is with the prison and occasional beating on culprits.  Once there is no more prisoners, or troubles you can unman the jail as close it down, just like medic and infirmary buildings can be shut down when there are no sick patients (to save on coal fuel).  I ended up having 4 robots to gather resources for -60 and colder weather and that works great.

  Just very didapointing (spoiler alert again here), that the story after beacon upgrade, now asks me to rescue all the people out there, when i dont think i our little setup can support 100-150 more people.  I will play it through and try, to see if game is over for me, as i wont save them all i'm sure.

  Anyway. lastly, there are many fun type buildings also, to help boost people's morale, like church, pub, fighting arena, gardens, or pleasure house they call it lol.  Buildings to help you control people and problems they create, like guard tower is great with patrol etc.

  Have fun and dont forget to turn off heaters when people dont work at their stations after 6pm !!!

    GAME RATED : 9/10
First time I played a city builder. I was hooked for 2 days and completed it. Its immersive and a very good game. I wil not play another city builder but probably Frost Punk 2.

Great game. Keeps you on your toes and fighting until the end. First city management game that has genuinely stressed me out.

Stress-inducing, anxiety-unfriendly, resource management at its finest

Exquisite combination of survival, civilization and society managing. Tough choices to make with complex consequences, constant struggle to stay alive and grave uncertainty reminded me of Battlestar Galactica mixed with other zombie apocalypse thrillers. This game is certainly unique and engaging from the start through the end, never felt bored or with an easy hand. Fully recommended, got it at sale but worth buying at full price. I hope the studio continues to create similar titles.

One of the few games that I can continue coming back to. I have achievement run the game twice so far with a bit over 500 hours on the console version of the game. Once you learn how to play the game, your operations run smooth, but my first runs were full of death. I had brought destruction to the frost lands and could only feel regret for my previous choices and move on. Now I still continue to hop on from time to time to see what I can attempt to ruin next, so ramping up the difficulty to see what I can accomplish on the next run is always a joy. Going from a peaceful protector, ready to sacrifice resources for comfort, on one run to a heartless leader, ready to sacrifice bodies for progress, on another, while suffering all of the consequences of survivor mode, always brings a change that I often don't expect until it is too late. I will definitely continue playing this gem from time to time. I can't wait to play Frostpunk 2 and everything you all cook up at 11 Bit Studios.

P.S. Soup gang on top

I just don‚Äôt like playing the game. 
It is a game you have to start over and over to get an idea of how it is played.
Even then, you seemingly have to be lucky to pull things off. 

I wanted to progress, but you can‚Äôt save even when things are going well meaning you have to start over every single time. 

It is not a game for me. With a few tweaks, I think it could be, but I just don‚Äôt like how the mechanics play out. It feels unforgivingly punishable way too often (rather than just ‚Äúaveragely punishing). A difficulty setting could improve the game a lot, but no. The developers want you to suffer. A lot. 
I play to have fun. I don‚Äôt mind being frustrated, but this game goes beyond that. It only wants you to suffer. A lot. Over and over. 
And as such, I feel like the game wastes my time. 

I am not happy about it, but this is why I can‚Äôt recommend the game. 

I can see how people may like this, but I warn you. Don't think this will be for you. 
I was fooled by many people saying it was amazing and as such wasted my money on making myself miserable.

This game is utterly fantastic. It's engaging, the Dev team have been - by and large - supportive and it looks and sounds brilliant. It's thought provoking too. I really enjoyed playing it.

But.

My old computer died and my replacement laptop has a high screen refresh rate. The game wouldn't launch despite everything.

I had a reply from a very nice member of the Dev Team who said: 
"our engine (Frostpunk is based on our own tech) is a tad moody when it comes to launching it on systems equipped with high refresh rate displays. We're well aware of that and we're currently doing our best to fix it - in the meantime, you can try lowering your refresh rate to 60Hz and attempting to launch the game then. If that doesn't help, I am afraid you have to wait until it's patched by our devteam."

Sadly manually altering the refresh rate didn't help.

I had another reply:
"Sadly, I am unable to provide any reasonable ETA of the patch, but our engine team has taken a delivery of 120-, 144- and 244Hz displays in the last few days, so the search for the reason is on, we'll do our best to get rid of this issue as soon as possible. "

This was back in June. Patches and DLC have come out but I still can't run the game and this is a real shame because it is really excellent. I highly recommend this game in general and I even bought the DLC in support of the Devs despite it not working but I can't really endorse it until they manage to fix this issue. 

***update***
They never got back to me, but I've since moved onwards and upwards in terms of computers. It's a great game, really excellent.

I find Frostpunk to be more of a story than an actual game.

A point I've seen sometimes in negative reviews is that it isn't very replayable, which I agree with. I haven't properly touched the game in months at the time of writing, and I've beaten every single scenario, DLC included. Endless mode exists, but even that gets repetitive after a few runs.

But I can definitely say that even if it's not the best GAME, it's absolutely one of the best STORIES I have ever interacted with.

The first run of Frostpunk is what I call the "true" run. You're experiencing what the Captain is experiencing; you're pretty confused on what to do and won't know what your actions will lead to. A law you sign or a few buildings you place now may have major impacts in the future.

Later on, after you know what everything does, when stuff occurs and what options are good, the game kind of loses its initial charm. This tale about humanity versus the elements and how far you are really willing to go is irrelevant if every building is a sauna and you're mining enough coal to power five cities.

But that first run. I myself can remember actively PRAYING and hoping with all my will that this virtual city of Brits won't all perish in the face of the unforgiving world. My Generator even ran out of coal right before the end as one last plot twist.

If you can get it on sale, do so and do NOT research anything about the game. Go into it blind and truly experience all of the hope, helplessness, despair and determination that Frostpunk invokes.

The game relies on BS mechanics. The graphics are good, the scenarios interesting, but the gameplay lacks in certain areas. Example you play the endless mode, you've been through 4 storms. 5th one comes along, and your people go "i declare myself hopeless. TL;DR Buy only on sale.

The game itself is good for its sale price, but lacks the depth nor the fun unlike the masterpieces in this genre. The game is centered around (un-)ethical choices for the survival. The main problem is that, by design, people in Frostpunk are just numbers, unlike the dev's previous one. For the people shown as numbers, ethics is just about comparing numbers. Child labor? Great, it's just trading discontent with extra hands. Organ transplantation? Yay, just getting the medical capacity for free. Move numbers by one-click. Then the game reveals the shallowness of the game mechanics. Basically what you only have to do is to keep the core chain of coal -> temperature -> health. That's all. Then you will have scenarios / events that gives you debuffs that is just prepared to torture players. Torturing player itself is not fun for players like me; games I like also have treats for you after you pass the wall. But this game is not. Just. Torturing. You. Period.
This game is not bad. But in this game genre, there have been already many very good games, and Frostpunk could not reach that point in my opinion.
S tier

Highly recommended game.

The presentation is solid. It does a great job setting the theme of survival in a world that wants you dead. Every person is named and you can see them walking around the city. The music is top-notch too. The [spoiler]final storm event[/spoiler] wouldn't be as epic without the music. 

The cold is very oppressive which makes the game engaging. Resources are limited. It forces you act pragmatically instead of always doing the right thing, reminds me so much of Pathologic. You might have to send little Timmy to the coal piles if you want to survive the night. 

The game loses its magic after learning the best effective strategies. If your city isn't struggling, you're playing on 3x speed, or you start min-maxing, it might be time to put the game down (some people like it, not me). The engagement comes from barely scraping by, probably why people suggest to go in blind. 

Technical issues: crashing in endless mode, I saw other people complaining about it in 3 year old posts, still isn't fixed. Occasional CTD for unknown reasons. Random game freezing (maybe because of the cold hehe)

I LOVE THIS GAME! I've seen this game for years now and never picked it up. I'm a huge city builder RTS player, Master SC2 player, and played everything from AOE to Anno 1800, Civ 1-6, Stellaris, City Skylines, Rollercoaster Tycoon, etc. etc. I've played a lot of these games.

Frost Punk is hella good compared to them all. It's unique and interesting and while the building and resource management is familiar, its all done in a unique and interesting way.

My favorite and at the same time least favorite mechanic of the game (Lol) is managing hope and discontent. I didn't watch any tutorials and didn't even find the tutorials until my 3rd play through (the previous 2 play through I failed miserably and my city froze too death and I was also kicked out of my city for sucking at management lol)

the 3rd time I started to get a feel for managing each crisis as it came and prioritizing needs appropriately. Needless to say I kicked the final storms ass with a huge warm thriving automaton ran city. I thoroughly enjoyed the challenge in this game which I've not gotten from a city builder in a long time.

Now i'm working on trying out the different endless Survival modes which are hard AF and i'm excited to let my people down all over again, until I don't of course :)

I bought this game 4 months after its initial release back in 2018, I played it then and thought it was great but I lost interest as I kept losing a couple weeks into the main story. 

Fast forward to December 2023 and I gave it another go, I idly remember certain technologies but overall it was like the first time I played it. I followed the major story points and eventually got to the storm, I was woefully unprepared. No stockpiles, no automatons, no nothing.

But, in the end I beat it!

But was it worth it? 

No seriously, I plunged my city into religious dictatorship and there's no coming back from that. 

I give it a 9.8/10. I can never give things a full 10 but this is pretty damn near close enough. Go in blind and follow the main story path, do your best to balance the bars and you'll eventually overcome the storm.

Frostpunk is a remarkable city builder incorporating survival mechanics to create some of the most intense moments I've had playing a game in a long while.

The bulk of the gameplay consists of scenarios: cities with a unique set of problems, a story to follow and a set end point. While the overarching goal in every scenario is ultimately survival, there are plenty of unique challenges separating them to keep you on your toes. There's also an endless mode scrapping the idea of an end goal and letting you keep going for as long as you can.

The game never lets you rest on your laurels, throwing new challenges at you with each day that passes. You must meet the demands of your citizens while balancing a delicate web of resources and responsibilities. A mix of both long term planning and on-the-spot decision making means that you're rarely left sitting with nothing to do. As time goes on your settlement becomes more advanced but the world outside becomes increasingly hostile and the swelling population makes both material and social requirements tougher to meet. If things ever seem to be going well, chances are that's about to change - or it already has and you just haven't realised it.

The experience is complemented by great visuals and an arresting soundtrack that changes and ramps up to fit the situation at hand. At its most intense moments where your food and fuel stores are about to run dry, your population's discontent is about to boil over and the cold threatens to paralyse your city's fragile infrastructure, the orchestra swells and Frostpunk is untouchable.

My only real complaints come from a UI that doesn't quite convey all I need it to, when I need it to. It can sometimes feel a bit clunky managing your city's workforce, especially when needing to micromanage where people spend their time to balance resources. I would appreciate blanket commands so that I could do things like open or shut down all of a given type of workplace with a single button, or press another to fill all vacant workplace slots with whichever idle workers are on-hand.

I wholeheartedly recommend Frostpunk to anyone looking for a city builder or survival game with more of a bite to it. It's tough and chaotic at times, but pulling through the tricky scenarios is uniquely satisfying and leaves you itching to return to do things better.

Definitely a very thematic game that attempts to tug at your heart strings for the plights of the people you lord over. Death at every turn, until you understand the game mechanics and that the game pushes you into extreme positions to satisfy two mutually exclusive meters, your towns hope and discontent. The music was the best part for me personally, but I really do not like how limited you are in this game, it's more like a puzzle than a city builder, and the puzzle is easily solved if you've ever played a resource management game. I did enjoy my time, albeit short, I'd say it was worth $5 but not much more than that.

The end game is suspenseful, there's a good deal of buildup warning you of some trial to come, however it also ends abruptly and it doesn't evolve the game in any way, it was for me, having done everything possible prior to said event that was even possible to do, like watching a film, there was zero, zilch, nada, that I could do about the event, once it came except for just watch, which is disappointing. I was hoping there was more afterwards at least but the game ends there and like I said, abruptly. I'm struggling to give this game a 7/10 but the orchestral music really pulls it over the top of that hill along with the weather effects visibly intensifying during some scenarios.
Definitely a great game if you love city builders.

To preface - I did really enjoy this game. The city building is fun and while it is freaking PUNISHING at first, once you get a hang of the mechanics it does a good job of hitting the sweet spot between being intuitive while still making you feel like you have to do everything with urgency.

However... the writing. Oh my good golly gosh, the writing. I am going to be laughing about it for a while. First of all - why exactly did we move NORTH from LONDON in an attempt to survive the GLOBAL ICE AGE? You know it gets colder the further you move from the equator, right? And it only gets worse from there. Highlights include:
-People in the last outpost on earth threatening to riot over 12 hr shifts
-Plummeting temperatures causing people to demand that they not have to mine coal anymore
-The game chastising me at the end over my nefarious deeds of... posting propaganda fliers
-People pissing and moaning about having to eat soup. Apparently the apocalypse is no excuse for subpar cuisine
-And more!

Literally all of this is purely writing error - you can just change the flavor text and not touch the mechanics and it'll still make total sense, but as it is, you will occasionally find yourself getting frustrated trying to manage the prissiest apocalypse survivors you've ever seen. Oh, and the game will still tell you you're a big meanie-head at the end no matter what you do, so... no, FrostPunk, I'm not particularly sorry for what I did to survive. Which was mostly tell a bunch of whiny Britons to put on their big kid pants. But at least I had fun doing it.

Bought it and played it for three days straight. Super immersive. It makes you care about each of your decisions. It's challenging and punishing if you don't think ahead enough. Can wholeheartedly recommend the DLCs too, they add some amazing new scenarios, giving you new insights from new perspectives, new techs and new missions. If you like games like Rimworld or Don't Starve you will love this game. If you prefer chill games like Planet Zoo this might not be it for you (although the game has an easy mode too!). Edit: All the horrible decisions you feel like you're forced to make to keep the city going in your first playthroughs, reveal themselves to be a direct consequence of your own incompetence and panic after you get better at the game. The game is incredibly well-paced and balanced!
