Took an immediate dislike to it. 

I was hoping for some dark humour but it was just immediately depressing. I don't play games to be even more depressed than I already am, thank you very much. Also, the title screen had as much space devoted to shilling other 11 Bit projects & DLC (including a massive Frostpunk 2 banner) as it did for settings and stuff. It was a bit of a turn off really. If I invite you into my house and immediately start trying to get you to subscribe to things or sell you my handycrafts, you'd be a bit put off wouldn't you. Offer me a cup of tea or something first, y'know. 

Then I started a "new home" (this game's "new game") and gave it a go but it was just immediately miserable. I built two structures and my wood ran out (fnarr fnarr) and the tutorial (I assume that's what I was in - since there was no separate option) didn't really help me cope with that. So I destroyed a structure to get some wood back and built a road to my coal hut and then waited - then 28 people froze to death. All the time I was thinking that that this was very reminiscent of another high production value / graphically appealing yet ultimately shallow game that I played years ago - Anomaly: Warzone Earth - and when I checked, it was the same devs. So I could see what was ahead of me here and chose not to get invested. They seem to make games for older casual gamers that wish their old Amiga games had modern graphics. It's all shiny shiny but I'm not fooled by that anymore. I have developed a reasonably reliable sixth sense when my time's going to be needlessly and monotonously wasted with scant intellectual stimulation (and let's face it, that's what you want from this type of game since it's not exactly testing your reflexes and situational awareness is it) - I don't think I'll be missing anything revelatory here. The Reigns games cover this "balancing act leadership" niche much more elegantly and I can play those on the bog on my phone, if that's what I want.

Frostpunk is an [b][i]incredibly[/i] atmoshperic[/b] game. If there's one word to describe it, one aspect that's beyond phenomenal, then it's the [i]atmoshpere[/i].

In Frostpunk, you will most likely start with the scenario and as such be in charge of helping your people survive the end of the world. The winter has come, it's as deadly as feared and it doesn't seem to end. In these conditions, it's your mission to keep a small village alive and help humanity survive.

This game is [i]tense[/i] in all the right ways. The soundtrack is simply [b]incredible[/b]. Very fittingly, the violins will embark you in a [b]chilly[/b] shivers inducing stress and fear. The time is running out, as are any other ressources, and the cold just keeps getting colder. 

People keep dying left and right and those that manage to survive will have to be kept well fed, medically treated, housed, motivated, obedient - and it's your job to do that, all the while you've got your hands full with managing shifts to meet deadlines, signing laws, running patrols, exploring the area, studying new tech and most importantly building, expanding and repairing a huge generator that is your only hope to survive.

It's a beautiful game and a very unique city builder. There is a free mode/unlimited scenario in Frostpunk, but it's main charme is definitely the story and the DLCs expanding it. The scenarios are challenging, you will most definitely fail, quite a few times. Each time will leave you motivated, having learned to prioritize better, progressing you not only in the story but also as a player. 

Frostpunk is extremely immersive and dark, cold, long, stressful, sometimes anxiety-inducing - it's the [i]perfect[/i] cuity builder and survival / strategy game for an apocalyptic scenario.


----
This being said, it's also strangely comforting and relaxing. The warmth of the heaters translates well beyond the screen.

The game cheats. Straight up. If you're doing OK, but it hasn't introduced a mechanic yet, you're going to damn well get the mechanic introduced. Regardless of your choices. 

For instance:
I had an >80% plus bar for hope and a <10% for discontent, I thought "Hey, I'm doing OK. Not great, but OK." (I was running thin on resources, trying to manage hope and discontent). Then, literally out of nowhere (not because of a choice I made, or anything else), a man walks into town, spreads the rumor about a city going down, dies, and suddenly I have a 50% full discontent bar, a <10% hope bar, and half my city threatening to go back to London. 

I didn't DO anything to prompt it; I had built a beacon forever ago. A scouting party had returned 4 days prior, and I was just minding my own business. But It wanted to make me contend with The Londoners, which felt really cheap, because it STOLE my hope bar. If I had gotten to chose a method of rumor suppression, or it had directly come from my scouting party returning with bad news, or if it had only been a HIT to my hope bar (not a complete reversal of it), it would've felt way better than just to have it randomly stolen because the game decided it should.
It felt so incredibly arbitrary; it wasn't as if it was a killing blow to a weakened city, or even just testing a city, it just decided that I was now a weakened city so I would have to deal with the Londoners, and waste my careful attempts to maintain hope and discontent. 

It didn't feel like it was trying to tell a story about your city, it felt like you were playing with it's toys and you would need to listen to it's railroaded campaign.

One of the most compelling strategy games I've ever played, that really makes me care for the people afflicted by the brutal world, and by my morally questionable decisions in the game.
Favourite moments include the recap of a playthrough that asks the question - did we go far? did we lose our humanity in order to survive?

Wonderful game with fascinating soundtrack and storytelling. I absolutely love the thematic and the way the game executes its mechanics and story.

The game inspires a lot, showing that much is possible if you have a strong will, no matter the obstacles on your way. Personally it inspired me to change a lot in my life and way of thinking.

In the beginning I noted the fascinating soundtrack of the game. It is made the best way it could've been done. The music makes you feel the ambience of the events Frostpunk revolves around just like another real reality. The voice acting in scenarios is wonderful and surprisingly artistic, however, I wish there was more voice acting.

The only thing I would really argue about is the way the game takes "easy" "medium" "hard" and "extreme" difficulties. If you think that when you easily finished the scenario on "easy" difficulty then "medium" difficulty should be just a bit harder, you'd be wrong. The differences between difficulties are humongous, making it very tough to practice and learn the new tactics of gameplay and citybuilding without any additional guides.

In conclusion I will say that Frostpunk is surprisingly very well made and definitely is worth its cost and giving it a try.

Frostpunk, developed by 11 bit studios, delivers a unique and emotionally charged city-building and survival experience set in a frozen, post-apocalyptic world. Released in 2018, the game challenges players to lead a group of survivors in the last city on Earth as they contend with the bitter cold, scarce resources, and the moral quandaries inherent in desperate times.

The standout feature of Frostpunk is its atmospheric and chilling setting. The game's visual design and art direction effectively convey the desolation and frigid temperatures of a world gripped by an eternal winter. The attention to detail in the frozen landscapes, steampunk-inspired architecture, and the subtle shifts in weather create a hauntingly beautiful backdrop for the city-building struggle.

Frostpunk's core gameplay revolves around managing a city generator, balancing resources, and ensuring the survival of its citizens. The unique twist is the reliance on a central heat source to stave off the deadly cold, with players facing critical decisions such as resource allocation, law enforcement, and managing discontent among the populace. The depth of strategy required to maintain both hope and order in the face of overwhelming challenges adds a layer of complexity that sets Frostpunk apart.

The narrative unfolds through a series of events and scenarios, with players grappling with moral dilemmas that impact the city's direction. The branching storylines and consequences for player decisions contribute to a sense of agency, making each playthrough a dynamic and engaging experience. The emotional weight of choices and the impact on the city's inhabitants create a connection between players and the virtual society they are striving to protect.

The sound design in Frostpunk plays a pivotal role in enhancing the overall atmosphere. The haunting music, the crunch of snow underfoot, and the distant howls of wind contribute to a sense of isolation and urgency. The audio cues effectively convey the struggle for survival and the constant battle against the elements.

While Frostpunk excels in many aspects, it's not without its challenges. Some players may find the difficulty level to be quite unforgiving, especially in the later stages of the game. The learning curve can be steep, and mastering the intricacies of resource management and city planning requires patience and strategic thinking.

In conclusion, Frostpunk is a masterfully crafted city-building and survival game that stands out for its unique setting, challenging gameplay, and morally complex decision-making. The blend of atmospheric visuals, strategic depth, and emotional storytelling creates an immersive experience that is both grueling and deeply satisfying. For players seeking a gripping and thought-provoking journey into the frozen unknown, Frostpunk offers a memorable and impactful gaming experience.

Wow. Ok, so I got this game on a whim for <$10. Looked ok, why not? 5 hrs later and I'm entrenched in this game. Holy hell is it hard to pull away from. I've never seen a builder game that has you so tense and filled with a sense of doom. This game needs to be a film, like yesterday. The intensity of the plot and what's going on is nuts.

To the person on the fence about buying this game - just do it. If you came this far and are intrigued, just buy it. It's a great game. Is it perfect? No. For those that know the game, I think the whole exploration element is flawed. But, what the game does well is a city builder that forces you to really consider the consequences of your actions. You often won't get second chances.

I wanna like this game, because minute to minute its so deeply engaging, but similar to other complaints about its linear puzzlelike nature (which i agree with), I found Frostpunk's approach to narrative to just be frustating. Some spoilers here but my critique more or less amounts to Frostpunk doesn't have much of a plot so spoilers are irrelevant. The game is entirely built around the question of "who will you become in the process?" but it doesn't actually ask that question to you, you don't get a choice of who you become the story just runs you through an entirely predetermined plot where the only option is do you wanna be a religious nut or a fashy nut. I went into the game with the intent to play a good person who's actually trying to get everyone through this and I acheived that, saving most everyone without any major moments of tyranny and not turning the city into a cult of me (which the game aggressively pushes you into). Despite all that... the game just pretends you were a tyrant anyways, there's just not anything in the game as far as I played to acknowledge what good or bad decisions you made, and at the end the same cutscene rolls ("faith was abused, the city survived... but at what cost? yadda yadda") it feels more like a misanthropic rollercoaster you're strapped to than an actual video game.

"Frostpunk" is a gripping and atmospheric survival strategy game that plunges players into a frigid post-apocalyptic world where they must manage resources, make tough decisions, and ensure the survival of their society. Developed by 11 bit studios, the game combines city-building elements with a unique twist‚Äîthe struggle for survival in a frozen wasteland.

Set in an alternate 19th-century timeline, where a new Ice Age has enveloped the Earth, Frostpunk challenges players to establish and maintain the last city on Earth. The gameplay centers around managing the city's resources, maintaining a delicate balance between coal for heat, food supplies, and the well-being of the citizens. The core mechanic revolves around the use of massive heat generators to stave off the bone-chilling cold, as temperatures drop drastically, posing an ever-present threat to the population.

One of the game's standout features is its morally challenging decision-making system. Players are often forced to make tough choices that can have profound effects on the citizens' morale, hope, and overall survival. The narrative is driven by a series of challenging scenarios, each presenting its own set of dilemmas and pushing the player's moral compass to the limit. The consequences of these decisions are thoughtfully woven into the storyline, creating a sense of emotional investment in the well-being of the city and its inhabitants.

Visually, Frostpunk is stunning. The frost-covered landscapes, steampunk-inspired architecture, and the constant struggle against the icy elements are depicted with a level of detail that adds to the overall immersive experience. The game's haunting soundtrack complements the atmosphere, intensifying the sense of desperation and isolation.

While Frostpunk's difficulty can be quite challenging, especially for newcomers to the city-building genre, the game's learning curve is well-structured, guiding players through the mechanics gradually. The replay value is enhanced by different scenarios and customizable difficulty levels, encouraging players to experiment with various strategies to ensure the survival of their society.

In summary, Frostpunk is a compelling and emotionally charged experience that successfully blends city-building mechanics with a harsh survival setting. Its unique premise, challenging decisions, and immersive atmosphere make it a standout title in the strategy genre, offering a refreshing take on the post-apocalyptic theme. Whether you're a fan of city-building games or looking for a thought-provoking and challenging gaming experience, Frostpunk is well worth your time.

Frostpunk is a survival strategy game set in a frozen post-apocalyptic world. The game's atmosphere is incredibly immersive, with stunning visuals and a haunting soundtrack that adds to the sense of desperation. If you enjoy a challenging gaming experience, Frostpunk is definitely worth playing. The game presents players with difficult decisions and complex resource management mechanics, which require strategic thinking and careful planning. The unforgiving frozen world adds an extra layer of challenge, as players must navigate harsh weather conditions and limited resources to ensure the survival of their community. Frostpunk offers a satisfying and immersive challenge for players who enjoy testing their skills and making tough choices. Frostpunk pays great attention to small details, which enhances the overall gaming experience. From the intricate animations of the characters to the detailed environments, the game creates a visually stunning and immersive world. The attention to detail extends to the gameplay mechanics as well, with subtle nuances that add depth and realism to the challenges faced by players. These small details contribute to the overall atmosphere and immersion of Frostpunk, making it a truly captivating and enjoyable game for those who appreciate the finer elements. waiting for Frostpunk 2

As a child, my dreams were filled with visions of new technologies and the wondrous possibilities they held for the future. Then, Terry Pratchett's books opened a portal to a fantastical realm, introducing me to the captivating genre of steampunk. "Frostpunk," with its chilling narrative and steampunk aesthetic, not only fulfills childhood dreams of technological marvels but also poses the intriguing question: What if our world had developed solely on the power of steam?

The game's graphics, ambient sounds, and enveloping darkness skillfully transport players into a world where frosty winds bite and the relentless cold seeps into your bones. The visual and auditory elements in "Frostpunk" effectively convey the harsh realities of a society struggling against the elements, creating an immersive experience that resonates on a visceral level.

What sets "Frostpunk" apart is its ability to make you feel the biting cold and truly empathize with the citizens under your care. The emotional connection to the plight of the people turns decision-making into a deeply personal struggle. Every choice you make has consequences, and the weight of responsibility for the survival of your society makes the game a poignant exploration of morality in the face of adversity.

The steampunk aesthetic isn't just a backdrop; it's a crucial element that shapes the game's mechanics and narrative. The "What if" scenario of a world powered solely by steam unfolds before you, offering a unique perspective on technological development. This distinctive approach to world-building adds layers of complexity, making each playthrough a fresh and intellectually stimulating experience.

As a gamer, the challenge presented by "Frostpunk" is both exhilarating and rewarding. The game doesn't spoon-feed success; it demands effort, strategy, and critical thinking. This refusal to hand everything on a plate adds a layer of satisfaction to every triumph and imbues each setback with a lesson to be learned.

The developers of "Frostpunk" have achieved something remarkable in creating an addictive game that effortlessly draws players into its icy embrace. Creating an immersive world is no easy feat, but the combination of atmospheric design, compelling narrative, and strategic gameplay has resulted in a truly outstanding experience.

"Frostpunk" is not just a game; it's a journey into a steampunk-infused winter wasteland that challenges your mind and tugs at your heart. It successfully melds childhood dreams of technological wonders with the captivating allure of steampunk, all while delivering an emotionally charged gaming experience that leaves a lasting impression. It's not just a great game; it's a testament to the power of storytelling in the world of gaming

As a fan of city builders like the Sim City series and old school RTS games like Red Alert and StarCraft, this game scratches both that city building and RTS itch, and then creates a whole new itch to scratch with it's survivalist gameplay twist. This game adds a flavor of morality to each decision you make and makes you feel like you're not only managing resources, but also lives. There are almost no easy decisions and I feel like I am making one prickly decision after another in the name of survival, power, or benevolence. The path to winning is never straightforward and even when you complete each scenario, you're forced to recount your path to victory and reflect... did anyone really "win"?

Speaking of games like Red Alert, this game has an absolutely incredible soundtrack that is every bit as enjoyable as the gameplay and worth mentioning in its own right. It hits the right notes (pun intended) and sets the perfect mood for the weight of this game and its setting.

Frostpunk keeps me coming back for more icy punishment. I've just completed all of the scenarios including the DLC scenarios and I am still hooked to come back and try my hand at the Endless Mode and Survivalist difficulty of the scenarios. This is the type of game where it's very easy to get sucked into helping your frozen town survive and then you look up at the clock and you realize hours have melted away. I cannot recommend this game enough!

Oh and I almost forgot to mention, the soundtrack to this game is absolutely incredible!!!

Early on in runs it can be good idea to pull all workers from gathering posts/sources and then just before shift starts reassign based on most needed resources.

Food Soup vs saw dust. Well both work but one makes more and you can always heal people. Discontent and hope are both resources use them. Dismantle and pause dismantling kitchens to stop people form eating when they should be working. Then cancel when you want to let them or need to make food so they don't die from starvation.

You can abuse overtime shifts, by starting then removing everyone from building and reassigning them back a few 3-4hrs later, to try an avoid deaths early on in runs.

Frostpunk is a top-tier city builder. It breaks from the mold of most of the rest of the genre by focusing on several scenarios with pre-existing goals rather than being a sandbox, but it pulls this off very well. Each scenario is fun and very unique, especially the DLC scenarios of The Last Autumn and On the Edge. Although the Endless Mode can feel a bit aimless and lacking as a city-builder sandbox, the game's scenarios are still each so strong and replayable that it doesn't count much against the game.

One of those games that feels a lot more epic than it probably should and stresses you out in a good way. 

The expansions are also really good.

Recommended, with caveats.
The thing I like about management sims, is reading the tech tree, planning out your long-term strategy, and gradually seeing it come to fruition. That's not how you're 'meant' to be playing Frostpunk. In the campaign, you're going to be suckerpunched by events that you cannot anticipate. You cannot read future tech in the tech tree, so if you take the wrong approach, there's not much you can do but reload a save and try again. That said once you learn the beats of the campaign, it becomes much easier to succeed. So it ends up feeling like the Dark Souls of management: it feels punishing until you repeat a trial and error loop and figure out an approach that works. 
This War Of Mine was similar, but the 'unfairness' of that game fit into its theme: war is hell, and if you're caught in the middle of it your survival is often a matter of luck. But the setting here is not at all real-world, and so it kinds of blunts the experience to reloading a save and knowing what you have to do to survive the next story beat because you peeked at how the next chapter starts. 
Apart from that, the mechanics are solid, visual design is great, and I generally like how you never really feel like you're on top of things, which is appropriate in an icy apocalypse.

I purchased this game during the cold snap in 2021. But the premise of the game made me viscerally angry. It was just too depressing. It was so promising too! Great graphics, beautiful wintry landscapes, and steampunk-styled technology. 
But I spent money on it, so the other day I decided to reinstall it and give it another try.
The premise of the game is that you're in a world that is getting increasingly colder, and you have to keep your citizens alive by any means possible. Everything you know and vaguely tolerate in a society simulation is here. With simulation games, it's always a careful balance between keeping your people fed and safe, and exploring new technologies that will make their lives better. In this case, you're doing what they actually need to survive, which doesn't always allow for their comfort and happiness.
Your goal is to make sure your citizens survive the coming cold. It's not easy to do that without resorting to inhumane tactics. It gives you plenty of opportunities to treat your citizens cruelly. All sorts of moral dilemmas are presented. But if you choose to help your citizens and treat them fairly, you'll be better off in the long run. Your city performs better when the citizens are optimistic. The game charts your progress and vulnerabilities based upon the mix of Despair and Hope at the bottom of the screen - when you show the citizens that you care about their well-being, it increases hope. 
Or, you can choose to go down a darker path of child labor, adding sawdust to the food, and forcing your citizens to work double shifts. If you keep the kids in jobs that are not dangerous, like the Cookhouse, it at least keeps them safe and warm. As long as your Hope levels are above your Despair levels, the citizens will do what you want. If you have 0% Hope, you lose the game.
The structure of this game resembles Civilization, but it's more limited. Instead of enemies to fight, there's the ever-present cold and dropping temperatures. Resource gathering is limited to five things. You can build around the inner ring next to the Generator and eventually will get the technology to heat individual buildings. You'll be researching many of your builds, so like Civilization it will be a careful choice of which technologies to research first. There's also exploration, which will bring more citizens, technology and supplies to your city.
One absolutely useless but beautiful feature of the game is that you can customize your view, so that there are more ice crystals and soot on the lens you're seeing the game through. All the menus and splash screens are well-done visualizations and the graphics are superb. This game looks wonderfully grunged and lived-in.
Do I recommend this game? If you like harsh environmental sims where you have to keep your citizens alive against overwhelming odds, this is the game for you. I found it very difficult to play, partly because I have empathy for fictional video-game characters. And I really hate being cold.  I started over several times, trying to find the right balance between keeping the citizens happy and researching new technology.. The morality is far more nuanced than I originally gave it credit for. And the visuals, of course, are fantastic.

In general, this game is rather challenging, even on "easier" settings. Random events are quite demanding, and can easily derail the city on first playthroughs. The city planning aspect does improve as the city grows, but the game focuses more on resource balancing, using random events to unbalance your plans. The graphics are quite solid, but the color scheme is a bit drab, though this is expected given the scenario. 
I'm actually changing my review since after giving it some more time and thought, the game ends up as a bit boring. The stressful bits are not rewarding, and feels more like "figure out the right build order" than a city planner. I can see some people enjoying it, but for the majority of those that like a city planner, this is not your cup of tea. Still, kudos for the innovative idea :D

I reinstall and replay Frostpunk every winter. Something about four feet of snow outside and the wind howling mightily while I battle the same elements in-game is just ... *chef's kiss.* 

Frostpunk is almost meditative. Progress is methodical. Your choices are weighty and should not be made hastily. Your success in a given scenario may hinge on a moral or ethical compromise you don't want to have to make. You kept your colony alive - but at what cost? 

Never before have I played a game so thoughtful - one that forced me to consider the ramifications of my choices. Those more cerebral aspects aside, the game is beautiful, runs well, is well written, and each scenario, while retaining familiar elements, brings a completely new aspect of the game to life in a really enjoyable way that forces you to diverge from a strategy that worked on a different map. 

As winter looms, give Frostpunk a try.

Though this review comes a bit late, Frostpunk is one of those types of games that has familiar elements that the Devs have managed to harness into quite the unique experience. While it plays similarly to 4X games, the only enemies are the coming storm and your own citizens. Race against the clock while the world around you grows ever colder; develop new technologies to help you keep your generator going as it's the only thing protecting you from the sheer terror of the coming storm. The initial learning curve is a little steep but my first full playthrough had me feel a new kind of terror, better yet - dread - of the clicking clock and my own helplessness in the face of the river of history. 

Overall, I'd recommend this game if you're a fan of survival and strategy games. It's a fresh take on some old genres that I thought was worth the money.

This isn't a game. It's a set of rules that you are to abide by restrictedly in order to meet 'win-conditions.' There is no freedom of choice in how you play. You either do what the devs specifically set in line for you to do, to the letter, or you fail. This game gives you the illusion of options. But if you don't select the extremely specific and limited options the devs have intended for the win-condition, you lose. There is no liberty in choosing to build a certain aesthetic, even if you choose a path that clearly makes sense, such as industrial speed and stream-lined resources. Have yo developed a surplus of supplies needed? No problem. The game will suddenly make those supplies gobbled up without any reason when you need them most. Oops. They just all went away because "reasons." What this is happens to be a blue-print for what one or two people envisioned as a toy-model of a robot. You have to follow the instructions to the letter to build the model. In order to pass it off as a game, they don't show you the instructions, and market it as model-builder with options. And shame on you if pieces fit despite where they don't go. Oopsie. You fail. Do you want to beat the game? Well, you'll have keep failing util you have figured out the singular path. or use a wiki. And in that way, the "game" has stole your time rather than enhanced it. But the addictive qualities that appear to be aspects of a city builder will distract you into thinking it's a game. And when you finally realize what the devs have done, that's when you'll feel the sting and miss the time they stole from you, along with your money. This game isn't fun. It's an addictive time-stealer. due to the illusion of being a city-builder and survival game. The devs made this game with the vision of sticking their middle-fingers in your face as they laugh and take your cash. Absolute trash.

Game provides sufficient challenge on base difficulty, but allows for some real hardcore choices to be made due to the ability to change the difficulty. Good story and alternate stories that build on the main one, but also has endless mode for those who just want to go and go and go.

Despite the artwork suggesting a Survival Game, and the gameplay aesthetic being reminiscent of a strategy game, I discovered through playing that it's a city builder/management simulation game instead. The gameplay is quite fun, being one of those games you can binge a couple times whenever you're in the mood for it. It did take me a couple hours to set up the keyboard and controller controls in a more convenient layout though. 

It has some pretty neat additions to the typical city builder, incorporating features reminiscent of strategy games like Civilization. For example employing scouts to explore and gain loot from nearby locations on the map, and a tech tree. The theme is rebuilding civilization in some kind of new ice age, so rediscovering/building technologies to unlock higher tiers of buildings rather than just population milestones is a logical implementation for this game. 

The law book has that Civ feel to it too, but it works basically the same as the ordinance/law system in a typical city builder. It has all of the other features of a city builder as well. While some city builders implement a grid for laying out the buildings, this game employs a circular grid around the main heat source. Which would serve as another cool immersive feature if the balance wasn't broken.


After completing the main campaign I've experienced enough that I can say for sure that the game has some serious balancing issues. The heating lamps one can build along the streets between buildings are OP, and to balance that it seems the devs amped up the weather difficulty to ridiculous extremes. To be specific: 1 heating lamp has the same power with about as large of range as the massive heat generator that the game is entirely designed around the concept of building your town around, and the power automatically scales up in the heating lamps to match the main generator power upon it being upgraded.

Additionally the range upgrades on the main generator are separate, and multiplicative of the fuel consumption rather than incremental like the power upgrades. Making it dramatically devastating to city development (guaranteed game ending) if you attempt to build the city in the way the tutorial prompts you to. Meaning there is only one way the game can be played for city development without being instantly wiped out by weather, which is to completely ignore the main premise of building around the central heat generator, avoid its range upgrades, and focus solely on heat upgrades, placing heat lamps, and for the -80¬∞C to -150¬∞C you'll also need all of the building insulation and heater upgrades. 

The heat lamps are very cheap to build, cost significantly less fuel to run than the increase in cost for generator range upgrades, and they sit on the roads between buildings. So they do not take up any space, and they don't even block movement or anything when people pass through them. It will always be several times more useful and cost effective to simply build heat lamps around the place (building around the heat lamps), and detrimental to try to support range upgrades on the main heat generator. Making the circular grid centered at the main heat generator just annoying, with needing to destroy and rebuild sections of the town when connecting them with heat lamps between them. 

The first time I continued my starting game I got a couple massive drops in temperature (from -40¬∞C to -100¬∞C) while still in the early game that made it impossible to do anything. Workers won't work if their workplace is too cold, or they get sick because their homes are too cold. Because I'd been following the tutorial suggestions and building around it with range upgrades everyone instantly became sick and stopped working. Ultimately forcing me to start the game over from the beginning, save file seemingly inaccessible after Game Over. 

On my second play through of the main campaign I used what I'd learned of how the mechanics work from the first, and I was in the mid-game by the time I made it to where I lost last time. I got to the unlimited resource deposits before I'd grown the town any, so I needed the heat lamps for the mines and realized how OP they were. This time I realized it didn't even matter what state your town is in, because I had 0 on my discontent meter and 100% on my hope meter with every building still comfortably heated after the massive drop in temperature, no one hungry or sick, and my hope was still set to 0 and discontent to 50%+ by the triggered story event. Therefore the only way to not lose instantly from scenario design is to have done everything perfectly so that your progress can slowly recover from there. Which is a terribly weak scenario design in my opinion. 

There are several other scenarios as well as an "endless" game mode though. So perhaps some of the other scenarios will be better, and the Endless Mode is probably more like what I expect in this kind of game. I have the complete edition though, and much of that is bonus content that may not be in the base game. Still I'd say it's a decently fun game, and I'd recommend it at maybe $10 for the complete edition. If it isn't on sale, there are probably other games your money would be better spent on.

What do you mean, why would children working an additional 24 hour emergency shift after their extended 14 hour shift in the coal mines causes discontent? And no we can't afford to give more food for child [strike]slaves[/strike] workers.

This game is great. You start with a few people and a nice comfortable temperature of minus 20¬∞C. You start nice, send your workers to start gathering coal and wood, maybe build a few houses so they don't freeze to death in their sleep. After a few minutes, the game mentions that you could really use some extra hands and suggests to open the place where you can sign new laws. And whats the easiest way to get some additional workers? That's right, put children to work in safe jobs. Later, you notice that you made a promise to heat all homes to a livable temperature but you don't have enough coal to actually keep your promise. So how about we sign a law about extended work shifts so we can get a bit more coal before the night starts? And food is running out so why don't we stretch it a bit by adding sawdust to the food? Later on you have some gravely ill people (possibly due to that sawdust) and you need to decide if we amputate them or just keep them alive while wasting valuable medical spots. And thus the slow but steady descent into a very grim dystopia begins possibly ending with you killing revolting workers because they didn't like your decisions. Or you could be the nicest leader of them all and everyone ends up dying of starvation. Or you're actually competent and manage to keep everyone alive, while only passing laws that aren't that bad. The last option is the hardest one by a huge margin.

Also the [spoiler]final storm[/spoiler] has fucking boss music. And it fucking deserves it.

Pros
+ it's pretty
+ fantastic sound track
+ unforgiving gameplay, demands your constant attention
+ unique approach with an interesting law/political system
+ uncompromising in their vision, not afraid to be a niche while refusing to pander to mainstream crowds 

Cons
‚Üí very simplistic for a city-building sim, lacks depth 
‚Üí locks players into specific play-styles with little to no variability between them. Multiple playthroughs become tedious and repetitive right out the gate.
‚Üí You're told this is the last surviving bastion of humanity, but you've been given a bunch of people who would have already succumbed to this kind of reality/environment given their level of intelligence and overall temperament.
‚Üí Complete lack of dual+ monitor support. 
... windows key is disabled in game regardless of your personal settings, removing the option of using the built-in Windows solution to this kind of issue
... launch commands that would have gotten around this are disabled 
... game client resets program's screen position whenever you change resolution in windowed mode
‚Üí game locks your refresh rate to 50-75Hz
‚Üí text is REALLY small on anything less than 1920 x 1080
‚Üí windowed mode locks your mouse into the program, forcing you to still have to alt+tab.
‚Üí you're given absolutely no ability to change UI or text size
... meaning the only solution for Dual Monitor, being make smaller than your resolution and drag over, becomes a squint fest

This game is unlike any other city builder. This game is art. I've never experienced anything like it. The people who made this game started with a goal: to portray hope, hopelessness, desperation, and resignation in the face of a slow freezing death. They wanted to portray a story of humanity's desperate attempt to use technology and determination to save itself from the cold. They wanted the player to realize the weight of their decisions when it is too late to change them. They wanted the player to sit uneasy in the calm before the storm, only able to hope that they have done enough. Then, they meticulously crafted every aspect of the game to meet this goal. Every single element works together in harmony. The music, the sound design, the visuals, the writing, the story progression, and the game-play all work together. Nothing feels out of place, everything has a clear purpose and adds something to this overall singular feeling: desperate resignation. All games are technically art, but this game feels like it was made to do more than be fun and make money. It was made from the heart, a cold heart.

Balancing resources, managing happiness, citizens complaining, the decay of your morality, downward spiral, distract them with alcohol, brainwash them, it gets colder, downward spiral, make their children work, it gets colder, round up the non believers, it gets colder, leave the children behind, downward spiral, it gets colder, spend lives to save the coal mines, it gets colder, ice crystals form in you're lungs, it gets colder, your tears freeze your eyes shut, it gets colder, the air is ripped from your lungs, it gets colder, still ever colder. The city must survive.

Frostpunk is one of the most memorable games I have ever played. Playing A New Home for the first time is one of those experiences I wish I could wipe from my mind so I could play it again fresh and new. Do not spoil anything for yourself or you will ruin an amazing experience. All the other scenarios are quite good as well, and The Last Autumn DLC is well worth it, although On The Edge is kinda meh. The visuals are very good and the music and sound effects are phenomenal. 

As far as downsides, it is true there isn't a ton of replay value for the average person. After beating all the scenarios on normal the closest you'll get to a fresh experience is playing on hard or survivor difficulty, which are a genuinely difficult (though not unfair) test of your knowledge of the game mechanics. Endless mode can be fun initially but you eventually reach a point where you've capped out on population, taken up all your land, and have such a strong economy that you cannot possibly lose. Beating all the scenarios on the harder difficulties will get you many hours of additional play time, and many many more if you want to get every achievement.

Absolutely worth buying in my opinion, and getting it on sale is a steal.

Frostpunk‚Äôs scenarios feel like they‚Äôve been honed and tuned very carefully, giving you the exact right amount of challenges at a time. Plugging holes left and right is very engaging, there‚Äôs always something to do, a path to choose, a law to decree.

The industrial steampunk city in the midst of the eternal winter of the north is visually pleasing, fun and simple to build thanks to its circular grid system and easy to keep track of due to its rather tidy user interface.

You‚Äôre constantly being forced to make hard and very impactful decisions, it truly feels like the fate of the city is in your hands. A city builder very much after my tastes.

Fantastic post-apoc city builder.  I especially love how its complexity is drip-fed slowly, at precisely the correct pace, and nearly every variable (including heat) can be understood either intuitively or with just a modicum of effort.  Well made and immersive.

My only knock against it is that Frostpunk can feel oddly "small" for a city-builder.  If someone looked over your shoulder 2 hrs vs. 5 hrs into a scenario, they could be forgiven for not seeing much difference.  There ARE differences, of course, but Frostpunk doesn't feature a prominent burgeoning grandeur that is often a draw within this genre.  The spatial elements of city-building are minimized.  The game isn't small, really - there's a fair bit of depth to explore in the various systems and scenarios - but if you're looking for a playground sandbox of post-apocalyptic creation, this isn't it.  Each scenario is a puzzle, and while there are slightly different approaches you can take to solving it, this isn't a game that allows for much meandering.

TL:DR I endorse child labor. 

For the people who just wanna read, this game is amazing. It's something I never knew I wanted which made it stick to the little tacky board in my mind palace that is reserved for stuff I like to do on the annual. Mostly, literally the cozy micro management if not survival based struggle buses like "Don't Starve" and "Dwarf Fortress". However Frost Punk is also a herald for the streamlined and tailored experience that is not usually delivered from our AAA developers and their schemes to crowdfund- Early access fund - and monetize the menus of our would be beloved experiences. 

 Frost Punk is a classically structured game in every sense of the word. It has an intro cut scene which is frankly carried (beautifully) by the score. The SCORE is amazing! This sound track is awesome. Truly half of the experience. The design and graphics are such that you can't zoom in all the way to peoples faces but you can click on every individual citizen and know almost every minute detail about them. Each one with their own sad portrait of their cold blushing faces. The intro lets you know how apocalyptic things have gotten. a last stand of human beings aims to survive the harsh end times with a generator they have been tugging around. they settle a place and begin collection rubble garbage and abandoned wrecks of miscellaneous old world items and get to work re purposing them. 

As you begin managing what work is being done it becomes clear that in order to mitigate the chaos and despair of the bastion city of humanity you, the mayor, must adapt and lay down the law- literally. You are given a choice as soon as the first few days go by. Do children work or stay in a home? 
Which has lasting and sometimes unexpected consequences from then on which is not something you see in most other games. Some games change a single variable give you a boost in one thing but not another whilst Frost Punk will have you bumping into whole story branches that have been unlocked. Is there entertainment? What do you do with the dead? What about food supply management? How about we use kids to help in other ways? 

very soon you unlock a tech tree by building an engineers building and after that its sim city with motivation and that apocalyptic blessed soundtrack. The limitations given throughout the game make things incredibly interesting and managing expectations while also giving people hope and gauging how much you can get away with makes the game a remarkable experience from start to finish with a fantastic end state that wraps the whole experience up in just 5 or 6 hours. If you're looking to see how long you can survive the eternal winter then by all means go endless mode and test your skills. 

A final note on game design. This is one of the few games that I love because it respects my time. as an adult with things to do every day I love that I can finish a run rather quickly compared to some of those insanely huge games out there that think you want to live in them. I like these kinds of paced out games. It feels very much like having a solitary board game to play at home. I'm not so overwhelmed that I can't manage it for a half hour and I'm also not bored at all the entire run. Every event that takes place adds to the agency of the mayor character your playing. Failure itself feels very fun and has me smiling every time. 

If you're looking for something that wont suck your life away and still leaves you wanting to revisit it about once a year if not more often then I highly recommend this game. I would even go so far as to say that it is a must have and I haven't even played the DLCs but I am excited to get those soon this year and have a go at them.

Post-apocalyptic game with a strict resource management, city and resource planning, maintaining the needs of your people, exploring the map with your scouts all the while ensuring the survival of your city in a frozen wasteland and making difficult choices that impact your entire run.

The game itself offers several "scenarios" with numerous diffiulties that adjust the way you play, primarily force you to be stricter and more ruthless with your people. Amazingly thematic game that has managed to pull me into the story quite a bit with its amazing soundtrack and story-telling pop-up windows.

A unique game in its own category, it's really hard to find anything that's wrong with the game for me personally. Only going into a great detail, where the game ultimately leads you down a narrow path of a strict tech and law order, in case you intend on playing on extreme or survivor difficulty. At that point you really cannot divert from a specific click, build, tech and law order.

Managed to play for 200 hours, played each scenario a few times on all the difficulties. Even for a single run of each of the scenarios, the game offers unique stories for each of these scenarios, which are all unique not just in story but also many other things. Most unique being The Last Autumn DLC that takes place before the apocalypse.

This game gets so boring real quick. The idea has potential but seriously so many times you give orders or make decisions but they never get carried out by the st00pid AI. Not even sure how this is supposed to count as a strategy or survival game! I'm only glad that I didn't pay full price for it and purchased it when it went on sale. I would have been really upset had I paid full price for this kind of dullness.

EDIT: My previous negative comment is above but I'm giving this game a shaky positive review now and here's why: After several attempts I realized that this is Not a strategy game and as long as you continue to view it as a strategy game you will continue to lose. It's not about what you want to do with the map, it's what the AI (The people you have to "save") need. So in other words it's about managing things, and you have to anticipate these needs, for example if you know your scouts have found survivors and are sending them your way then you better build housing for these survivors before they arrive. Also, ignore some unnecessary upgrades in the beginning for the sake of upgrading your coal production cause you're gonna need a lot of heat. Yes, the developers are a bunch of sadists! A temperature of -150, are you kidding me?! Smh Oh and what survival is this when 2/3 of the population ends up dead no matter what you do! lol Anyway, if you keep this in mind: that it is a game about managing a situation that's already broken and that you're gonna lose most of your population anyway before you win then yes, you'll find some enjoyment and "fun" when you actually reach certain mile stones and eventually win. So yeah, there you have it! Could be improved but again here's a shaky like from me. 

Oh and you're gonna need to use propaganda, lots of coal and propaganda! lol

A brutal resource management game where the world doesn't care about you, and would honestly prefer if you, and the City, just died. But we can't let that happen, the City must survive. 

At the beginning, survival is a struggle and you'll most likely fail a few times until a proper strategy is formed. Even completing the first scenario feels impossible at first, especially with the discovery of 'The Storm'. Persevere, as is the indomitable human spirit that powers our city. No matter the cost, the City must live.

This game will allow you to make hard decisions. The beauty of this system is that as desperation sets in, these initially difficult decisions suddenly become easier to make. The City must thrive. Your cruelty and your kindness as a leader are in a constant battle, as is the discontent and hope of your city.

When all is said and done, you'll be presented a time lapse of your city, and a reminder of the decisions that was made along the way. The game won't judge you, but you certainly will.

There are additional scenarios as part of DLC, each one a new story of human will and the lengths we will go to survive. My favourite would be the Fall of Winterhome. 

An amazingly brutal resource management game. Highly recommended, especially if the game is on sale.

I have never been as captivated by the storytelling and narrative of a game such as Frostpunk. "The City Must Survive" is a saying you will find yourself repeating as your city braces against temperatures as cold as -150¬∞C.

At its core, Frostpunk offers a captivating narrative that keeps you invested throughout the game. The backstory is set in an alternate 19th-century world where a catastrophic volcanic event has plunged the Earth into a new ice age. As the leader of the last city on Earth, your mission is to guide your citizens through the relentless cold, making tough decisions along the way. The morally complex choices you face are the heart of Frostpunk. This game excels at forcing you to confront the darkest corners of human nature.

The Generator is your lifeline. If you lose this or cannot fuel it, you doom all of Humanity to an agonizing and slow death. You must keep feeding coal to the heart of the city in order to keep your citizens from freezing to death. 

Frostpunk also excels in forcing players to confront moral dilemmas. Should you enact child labor laws to keep the generator running, or is it worth sacrificing the children's well-being for the greater good? These choices are not black and white, and the consequences are felt all throughout the game. The depth of these decisions adds layers of complexity and emotional weight to every playthrough. Your citizens react to each and every law you write.

You have the ability to become the all-mighty dictator of an highly-organized yet brainwashed society. Conversely, you can also become a God to your people and be worshiped devoutly, and any heretics of your rule shall be eradicated. Although these ideas seem promising, you will soon discover the true reality of being such an authoritarian leader or deity. You must decide whether you cross that line and plunge the remainder of Humanity into it's darkest era.

In conclusion, Frostpunk is a masterpiece of the indie gaming world. It combines a compelling narrative, stunning visuals, innovative gameplay mechanics, and morally complex decision-making to create an experience that is both challenging and emotionally resonant. If you're a fan of city-building games, survival challenges, or thought-provoking storytelling, Frostpunk is an absolute must-play. It's a game that will stay with you long after the snow has melted, leaving you pondering the moral choices you made and the lengths you went to for the survival of your city.

[h1]1. A City Builder Like No Other:[/h1]
Frostpunk? More like "Frost-chill-your-bones-to-the-core"! This game throws the rulebook out the window. Forget those city builders where everything's sunshine and rainbows ‚Äì in Frostpunk, you're in a world that's colder than your ex's heart. And what's amazing is you can take it slow! No rush, just build your icy utopia at your own pace.

[h1]2. The Drama Hits You Like a Blizzard:[/h1]
Talk about the feels, my friends! Frostpunk's got this "human drama" thing down pat. I'm tellin' ya, when you see those polar bears attacking or a cave full of helpless folks, especially kids, it's enough to make you reach for the tissues. And as you get deeper into the game, the decisions get INTENSE, and the consequences? Well, let's just say it ain't all sunshine and ice cream.

[h1]3. Lore So Deep You'll Need a Shovel:[/h1]
The lore, folks, oh, the lore! If you're into diving headfirst into a game's story, Frostpunk's got you covered. There's lore galore here, with snippets and tidbits scattered all over the place. It's like putting together a puzzle, and when you finally connect the dots from all the DLCs and games, it's mind-blowing!

[h1]4. Music That'll Give You Chills:[/h1]
The music in Frostpunk is a whole other level of epic! I mean, when that storm finally hits in "A New Home," you're gonna say, "THAT MUSIC!" It amps up the tension, it's spine-tingling, and it's just plain amazing. It's like having a front-row seat to an epic blockbuster.

[h1]5. Graphics as Stunning as a Winter Wonderland:[/h1]
And let's not forget how easy on the eyes this game is! The graphics are jaw-droppingly beautiful. The icy landscapes and cityscapes are so detailed you'll be glued to your screen. It's like playing in a winter wonderland, but with a dash of chilling survival.

In a nutshell, Frostpunk is a game that'll warm your heart (even in the cold) and give you a gaming experience like no other. Massive props to the developers for this masterpiece. I'm highly recommending it, and even after all those hours, I'm still coming back for more. And, my friends, I'm hyped as heck for Frostpunk 2! Can't wait to see what icy adventures await us next. Thanks for tuning in, and as always, stay frosty, my friends!

I'm definitely glad I picked this up, with it sitting in my 'should play at some point' list for a while.  Shout out to Johnny Chiodini for playing it on his youtube channel and pushing me over the edge into buying it for myself, props to you and a hello to the L.S.P. community.

An excellent evolution on the city-builder genre that packs enough thematic punch to make you genuinely grieve for every mistake. Sometimes there are no good options, and you will have to live with the consequences no matter what you do. Realizing the domino effect you unwittingly set in motion 30 minutes ago has now broken into an all-out crisis is one of the most engaging and terrifying experiences I've ever had from a management style game. Add on top of that an incredible dynamic soundtrack and you have an amazing gaming experience.

The various narrative scenarios on offer are the biggest draw and I wholeheartedly recommend the Last Autumn DLC. Coming to grips with the various curveballs each scenario throws at you elevates this game from a simple city-builder to a unique genre-fusion that uses light roleplay elements to challenge your sense of morality and pragmatism. Learn just what it will take to keep your promises as temperatures drop well below zero.

My first 5 playthroughs of this game were disaster.  BUT I figured it out:  to play this game, it's best to remember everything is out to get you:  the cold, starvation, the citizens, tech trees ?, the UI ??, and the developers ???.  I'll explain.

The cold is omnipresent and will require constant adjustment of heat provisions through micromanagement.  This seems stressful but don't worry, your citizens will get sick and die no matter what you do.  Dying is a best case scenario, actually:  you can end up with useless citizens through injury who drain your resources indefinitely before you get mid-game technology to do anything about it.  Yes, citizens will constantly be falling ill no matter what so you might as well start child labor ASAP so you can get work out of them before they inevitably keel over.  Don't feel bad--have you heard of Minecraft?  The children yearn for the mines.

If that isn't fun for you, to break things up, gameplay will be occasionally interrupted by insipid storytelling that amounts to "Very human much sadge".  Just a text popup about "Marge lost her husband" or "Billy fell down while he was playing".  It only leaves me asking myself things like "Wow, what was Billy doing out of the coal mines?"  Oh, by the way, hope you didn't forget about your actual game micromanagement tasks after that pop up!  Whoops, too late, you forgot some heater button and three people are crippled by frostbite now.  

The citizens are actively working against you, don't kid yourself.  They are not your friends; they do not want to survive, they just hope to make you as miserable possible before they off themselves to make you lose.  Citizens will ask you for expensive improvements that will ruin your economy, but will get butthurt when you tell them "no, I don't want to use up all of our vital limited resources".  If that wasn't enough eventually they start organizing, convinced that they will be taking some portion of your city's supplies to return to the city they left during a big tearful intro scene.  "YOU'RE F***ING JOKING."  No sir, I am not.  Their big plan is to leave the city and walk ALL THE WAY BACK through the blizzard they can't even work 8 hours a day in.  Why am I stopping these people--hell I'll go with you to the land of milk and honey, it sounds amazing.  Too late, now they're revolting.  But here's a heartwarming story about a stuffed animal.  And six more people died while you were distracted by it.  Sucker.

Getting new technologies is a hateful exercise that never feels good.  You're going to either eat big up-front cost that may bring other upfront costs, be absolutely useless without other costly technologies, or triple resource costs for some niche marginal sidegrade.  Congratulations!  You can upgrade your giant coal consuming heat engine--it's now two or three times as expensive to operate.  Or better yet, you can spend resources to discover a building that costs resources to inefficiently farm resources.  Unfortunately, there's no technology to burn citizens alive in the furnace for making crackpot plans to hike 3000 miles in the snow on the tech tree.  I'd buy that one first every game.

Lastly, the UI really ties the game together, in that it's mostly for people that weren't loved as children and are hoping games will help them recapture that magic.  The game pings Help Tips when new game elements appear.  But then clicking on the prompt just brings you to the Help Menu.  It's as though they're telling you "FINE YES IT'S A GIANT HEAT ENGINE FIGURE IT OUT, I'VE BEEN HOLDING YOUR HAND FOR WELL OVER 3 SECONDS ALREADY!".  This strongly suggests that the people who made the Help Menus were probably tapped for modeling the citizens' sociopathic behavior as well.

If you were dumb enough to keep playing like me, you slowly discover sh*tty "tricks" that the developers programmed into the game.  For instance, your first mission is to get coal for the giant heat engine your people "desperately" need.  You rush to hook it up and get it pumping heat bc wow you're just a great guy.  Well, stupid, you don't actually need it at all during the day.  You're literally wasting coal completing the quest.  Surprise, you run into a coal bottleneck a few days later when the temperature plunges.  Now a bunch of your citizens get frostbite, are crippled, need a special building, and will no longer work.  F*** me to tears.

But knowing this, you can now play knowing the real secret:  this game is scripted linearly, with scripted events, scripted outcomes, and scripted gameplay.  The illusion of choice is simply a process of discovering inferior or deadly outcomes of incorrect choices.  Definitely play this if you didn't just flip to the end of Choose Your Own Adventure books as a child.  For everybody else, the ending is:  they all die.  Or so I can only hope.

A game ideally experienced within the icy confines of a fully cranked air-conditioned room, where the chill creeps into your very bones. Commanding your subjects with numb fingers, each touch growing stiffer as time progresses, mirroring the chilling impact of every decision you make. With each passing day, the biting cold and gnawing hunger gnash at your sanity, the cacophony of grievances and catastrophes compelling you to dispense radical judgements. Will you cling to faith's fragile thread or brandish the whip of authority? Within this realm, the end only justifies the mean- a principle draped in shadows and veiled intentions.

Simply and without doubt one of the best, if not the best game I've ever played

 This is not one of those games you walk through in a couple of hours, just dealing with the environmental challenges would be enough on it's own, I admit to feeling cold the whole damn time, add to that the moral and logistical difficulties and it becomes  a much more involved and thought provoking challenge.

Probably worth mentioning that I'm not someone who's generally interested a games story, or in a lot of cases the music tracks, this is the first game, in many many years, in which the story grabbed me, the music normally muted was allowed to play, for it wasn't intrusive and added immensely to the atmosphere, which had me truly immersed and invested in keeping as many colonists alive and healthy as possible.

Frostpunk is a survival strategy game about surviving the next ice age. You lead a group of people huddled around a big generator that creates heat. Workers, engineers and even children will have to make their contribution in order to survive.
I've never played a survival strategy before. There are no enemies, so your main problems will be the freezing temperature and lack of food. As expected, there are a number of buildings and upgrades that help you achieve your goal. The game is divided into several scenarios, with a common objective to survive 30 days (or so) in the freezing wilderness. The extra scenarios come from DLCs, but they don't really differ much from one another. Also, there is an endless survival mode.
While the game captures the atmosphere of despair and self-sacrifice very well, it soon becomes repetitive and tedious. Everything revolves around having enough coal for the furnace or enough food for your workers. The first scenario is fun because everything is new, but all the subsequent ones are just more of the same. Scenarios tend to have unexpected story turns and need to be played in a try-mistake manner (something tragic happens out of the blue and you're not suitably prepared for it - tough luck, try playing the scenario from the beginning). The music and graphics are passable. The user interface could have been done better - I frequently find myself spending a minute or so while looking for a specific building or worker. The game seriously lacks depth, and basically you'll see everything it has to offer in the first scenario (which only lasts a couple of hours). I like the design of buildings and upgrades, but there are too few of those available.
Frostpunk has a good idea, but it is too short and shallow. Worth buying on a discount, but don't expect too much.

Insurgency: Sandstorm is a testament to the sheer satisfaction that comes from finely tuned weapon customization and diverse class options. As a fan of tactical shooters, I've found this game to be a refreshing and immersive experience that delivers on its promises of realism, strategic gameplay, and exceptional customization.

The weapon customization system in Insurgency: Sandstorm is nothing short of remarkable. The level of detail and depth in tailoring weapons to your playstyle is a delight for anyone who revels in personalizing their loadout. The plethora of attachments, scopes, grips, and skins allow for a level of fine-tuning that's not just cosmetic, but genuinely impactful on your in-game performance.

But where the game truly shines is its class system. Each class feels unique and offers distinct advantages and limitations, promoting team-based cooperation and strategic diversity. Whether you're taking on the role of a Rifleman, a Medic, or a Demolitions expert, the game's balance and attention to class-specific abilities create an environment where each player's contribution feels vital.

The immersive nature of Insurgency: Sandstorm's gameplay can't be overstated. The combination of realistic visuals, sound design, and attention to detail in weapon handling creates an atmosphere that pulls you right into the heart of intense firefights. The way bullet physics, cover mechanics, and team coordination come together makes for an experience that is both thrilling and demanding.

The only slight downside is that, while the weapon customization and class diversity are exceptional, the learning curve can be steep for newcomers. This can lead to a frustrating experience for those unfamiliar with tactical shooters. However, with patience and practice, the depth of the gameplay becomes more accessible and rewarding.

In summary, Insurgency: Sandstorm is a tactical masterpiece that excels in weapon customization and class variety. The level of detail and strategic depth in both these aspects makes for a satisfying and immersive gameplay experience. While it may pose a challenge for newcomers, the payoff for those willing to invest the time is an unparalleled level of satisfaction and a tactical shooter that stands among the best in the genre.

Hold onto your winter hats, because it sounds like you stumbled upon the unicorn of gaming ‚Äì a game that's actually gasp GREAT! And not just great, we're talking AWESOME-level awesomeness. It's like you opened a box of cereal expecting a free toy and instead found a tiny, perfectly cooked steak ‚Äì unexpected and deliciously satisfying.

But wait, there's more! This city-building game has a twist that's as refreshing as sipping an ice-cold lemonade in a desert ‚Äì you're not just crafting buildings, you're battling the cold. It's like becoming a city planner and meteorologist all at once. "Today's forecast: chilly with a chance of resource management."

And let's talk quests ‚Äì it's like this game sat through a thousand "quest committee" meetings and decided, "You know what? Let's just keep it simple." It's like the game designers are the Zen masters of questing, leading you down a path of straightforward warmth management rather than a labyrinth of confusion.

Keeping everyone warm becomes your Everest, your ultimate challenge, and your life's mission ‚Äì it's like you're a winter fashion guru, making sure your pixelated citizens are cozy and stylish. "No, Greg, those mittens don't match your scarf ‚Äì start over."

The pros list is longer than a CVS receipt ‚Äì gameplay, graphics, story, perks, events, user-friendly interface, and a mechanic for materials that's simpler than explaining the plot of a soap opera to your cat.

And here's the grand finale ‚Äì this game is SO different, it's like your eccentric neighbor who has a pet llama and hosts yoga classes for squirrels. It's so refreshing, it's like a splash of cold water on a scorching day ‚Äì you didn't know you needed it until it hit you.

So grab your thermals, channel your inner city planner-slash-meteorologist, and prepare to embark on a journey that's not just gaming, but an epic saga of keeping your virtual citizens snug as a bug in a digital rug. Winter is coming, and it's about to get pixel-perfectly cozy!

Very unforgiving, very dark and bleak. You will lose the first handful of playthroughs, but it's incredibly addicting once you get the hang of it. It's not a city builder, even if you are technically building a city - it's more of a resource management game.

Also there's a lot of allegories to some of the darkest moments in European history. I don't think anybody outside of Poland could have made such a brilliantly bleak game and have it still be fun.

I especially commend the 'Last Autumn' DLC for its wonderful game-ification of the Soviet perversion of Marxist ideals. That's something you'd never see from an American game studio.

TL;DR - only worth it on sale, and if you have a powerful PC.  This game leaned heavily into aesthetics and immersion at the expense of gameplay and content.  In my opinion, it actually pays off... the first time.  It did immerse me.  The choices the game presented were brutal and nerve wracking.  The min-maxing was fun.  Then you finish the first campaign and realize that's all the game has to offer, and that the devs want you to spend more money on their DLC.

Pros:
* Aesthetic.  Vibes.  Setting. This game had a vision and successfully delivers on an alternate, dystopian steampunk ambience.
* Looks good, particularly the lighting.  This comes at the price of performance, though.
* Story is more compelling than most strategy games.  I did actually want to survive the storm for reasons beyond just 'beating the game'

Cons
* Mediocre gameplay.  It isn't bad.  It is serviceable.  The real innovation to this game is the aesthetics, so if that doesn't interest you, you probably won't like it.
* Very poorly optimized. This is the worst performing city builder / strategy game I've ever played.  Wouldn't run on my original PC at all and I had to refund it.  I got a new monster pc at a later date and tried it again and it runs fine.  Installed it on a macbook pro while on vacation (was surprised its even available on mac) and the frame rate is abysmal and input lag makes it unplayable.  
* Threadbare content / low replay value.  This game has nothing to offer beyond the main story.  Side scenarios are shorter, easier, less interesting versions of main story - no new laws, buildings, or any functional changes to gameplay.   Main scenario takes maybe 10 hours.  You can squeeze a bit more out of it if you replay it at higher difficulties for achievements, which is what I did.

During my first successful run-through, I was quite frustrated cause I thought no matter what I did, I was going to fail. The cold was going to kill everyone. The cold days seem like they would never end and it just kept getting colder and colder. I was losing faith. The music was tearing me up and people started dying. 

Then it appeared, the sun. We were all saved; we lived... but were we truly alive?

In the beginning I'll note that the game is able to create apocalyptic atmosphere for it's specific setting. Ripped away from the world and casted into frozen hell, stranded and hungry, with only marvel of the passed age standing between you and ruthless cold. Soundtrack is great and it has few gems like "The city must survive". Mechanics add to it, with diseases, discontent, hope and so on. It feels as if you were struggling to survive - at least at the beginning.

At it's core it seems to be really cramped city builder with huge focus on survival mechanics and with no real potential for sandbox playing - which itself isn't a flaw in design. Gameplay revolves around specific scenarios with specific problems and challenges that move story forward. Finished scenario usually leaves little to no space left for buildings in the city.

But to the point - the gameplay. There is always the most optimal way to play a specific scenario. For convenience let's imagine it as a curve. We'll call it the A curve. It contains all decisions player undertakes during the game. Here, depending on difficulty level, is a certain distance you can derive from the A curve [in given direction] during your game and still win (survive). If you will go beyond this treshold - you won't be able to succeed. For the standard difficulty the "tunnel" around the A curve that marks how forgiving the game is is quite wide. The problem is that at maximum difficulty it shrinks to the size of fiber-optic cable. You basically have to find out where exactly the A curve is (the hard way) and then follow it meticulously until the very end.

What I want to portray here is that the game doesn't give you many ways of solving complicated problems if you want to be challenged. You have to know the scenario and know exactly what to do and what events are going to appear and when. So the game rewards you for being a seer, not for reacting best you can to unexpected. 
The example with the curve is somewhat simplified, and there may be actually even few of those. The point still stands - you have to find this exact path of maximum efficiency and stick to it.

Design of the city itself affects those curves slightly at best. What I mean is that the efficiency of our colony can be only marginally increased by well designed city outlay. The projecting side of the game is not really impactful, and the outcome of the scenario depends generally on how many specific buildings we have if anything, not where those are located.

There are also some other minor problems with gameplay, but it's whatever at this point.

In terms of lore it makes very little sense that the generators are capable of sustaining cities of only around 800 inhabitants each, especially given what it took to build them (building a generator is probably the most interesting scenario btw, it's in dlc though). Also bri'ish larping pagans because of natural disaster is as believable as fallout lore. I understand that much can be said and expected from them, but this is beyond ridiculous.


In the end, we get a game that could have been good, if development was more focused on city-sim side of the game, with more gameplay flexibility. What we've got is quite annoying survival simulator with city builder elements within it.

Waste of a great premise. There are some parts of the execution of this game that are spot on and it has great aesthetics and some cool ideas, it's often briefly REALLY fun to play which is why it stings more that the difficulty is almost unplayable and the games makes very minimal attempts to be accessible to a new player. You have to learn the hard way how to survive on even the lowest difficulties and most of the creative possibilities of a city builder are lost to invariable challenge. Worse the game tends to waste your time buy causing you to die because you're not ready to meet objectives you didn't know were coming, forcing you to replay hours of scenarios even when you have the skills to complete them.

I was all set to change my "would never recommend" rating after finally completing the first scenario on easy  difficulty. Watching the timelapse of my city, which I had nurtured and lovingly guided through the many huge challenges of the scenario to ultimate success felt  so fulfilling.... then I was dumped into the menu screen. Thre was no way to actually play and enjoy the city I had built. It was over just as I was about to start having fun. I would give this game somewhere between minus 30 and minus 120 stars out of 10. Fuck this shitty game.

Also the game aggressively advertises its DLC and sequel at you while you're in the game menu. Hey, marketing tip! If you want to get me to buy Frostpunk 2, the time I am LEAST likely to do that, is when I've been playing Frostpunk 1!

Game gets just about good if you add -devconsole to steam launch arguments, start an endless scenario on the most forgiving map press backtick and type ShowDebugButtonsPanel, that way you have some buttons to hit every time you almost die from stupid shit. That means you get to play the game long enough to get the hang of how it works, rather than dying too fast to learn anything from your mistakes.

I actually unlocked almost all of my achievements without cheats once I'd gotten good at the game, but first impressions count so I still rate the game poorly. If I hadn't had cheats I would never have had a good enough time to warrant continuing, or had the practice to build up those skills,  so the intended play experience is worse than garbage.
