TL;DR: This would be a great game.  But items plague gameplay.  Surprisingly irritating items that suck the joy out.

Let's talk about the good:
It's interesting.
It's clever.
It's fun...when you're not annoyed at it.

Let's talk about the bad:
1. The game has the ability to show how much time is left on your quest.  But fails to do so for some quests.  This leaves you with the misunderstanding on other quests that you aren't running out of time unless you deliberately go to that quest and verify if there's a time limit on it or not.  The fact that it doesn't show the time when the game has the capability is VERY irritating.
2. The game will deliberately slow the clock down every morning.  You almost never want the clock to slow down in the morning.
3. You can't set slowdowns for your own items.  Gathering post out of things to do?  You get a tiny alert on the left which quickly vanishes.
4. The alerts you receive for interesting/actionable/important items are too difficult to hear when playing the game at low volume.  And the same deep boom sound is played for non-actionable items, making it very confusing when you hear the 'new thing' sound but there's nothing to do.
5. Visual indicators for alerts can be on the left side of the screen, the bottom of the screen, the right side of the screen, or even not displayed at all on the screen!  The game effectively forces you to stay centered on your city at maximum zoom out so you don't miss stuff.
6. The game likes to tell you about things you already know about.  For example, a new tech tree opened up and I started researching it.  Three seconds later, a concerned citizen informed me about the new tech tree.  Wow, thanks, game. :(
7. The Winterhome scenario shows an extra slot for outposts.  You can't use it.  I messed with that spot several times, only to find out that it's reserved for a specific building that unlocks later.  Not cool.
8. Of all the complaints, this next one is probably the one that ticks me off the most.  The game uses what I call 'Witcher' logic.  If you haven't played The Witcher, that game is known for giving you choices...that don't matter.  And all the choices are wrong.  FrostPunk gives you tools to help keep your citizens happy.  And then berates you for using those tools on the closing credits of the map.
9. Finally, there are four storyline maps and 7 'endless' maps that come with the core program.  That's a good deal if you paid under $7 like I did.  But how many people got this game for that price?  Btw, no multiplayer.  Just an fyi.

Frostpunk's gameplay mechanics are not just about resource management and survival. They are a reflection of the ethical dilemmas and moral choices that define us as a society. The decisions you make are not merely strategic moves, but moral quandaries that question the very nature of humanity. Do you sacrifice a few for the survival of many? Do you uphold human dignity at the risk of extinction? These are questions that transcend the digital realm of Frostpunk and resonate deeply with our real-world ethical dilemmas.

The game's narrative is a masterclass in storytelling, weaving a tale of desperation, hope, and resilience. The characters are not mere pixels on a screen, but embodiments of human spirit, each with their own stories, dreams, and fears. They are a mirror to our own selves, reflecting our strengths, our flaws, and our capacity to hope even in the face of despair.

Frostpunk is a testament to the power of video games as a medium for philosophical and ethical exploration. It is a game that does not shy away from asking difficult questions, challenging our preconceived notions, and pushing us to reflect on our own values. It is a game that reminds us that even in the coldest of winters, the warmth of the human spirit endures.

It's about a 20 hour game. Good graphics. Interesting concept. There are some balance issues that make endless mode a poor experience. The hope system is broken. All the hope modifiers are temporary except the authoritarian ones. You can make a utopia where no one has ever died, and all the work is done by automatons but still get overthrown because a storm is coming. Apparently, an inbound storm caused my people to lose all hope despite having survived others and having plenty of food and coal stockpiled. The game forces you to become an authoritarian and then tries to morally grandstand you. The main campaign also fails to differentiate between passed and utilized polices. For example, if you pass the soup policy but never serve soup, the endgame will say your people suffered with watery soup. This is especially frustrating because some onerous policies in the tree have to be unlocked to access gentler policies. (emergency 24hr shift -> longer workday)

The are also some graphics bugs. The overlay for a freeze/thaw gets off to the side a lot. It makes an otherwise impressive effect look cheap.

I enjoyed it but its always disappointing when a studio makes a good, 95% completed game but opts to announce a sequel rather than fixing mistakes. They also released a bunch of DLC, again without fixing some of the core balance issues.

A Refreshing Journey in the Cold - Frostpunk Review

Frostpunk, a survival-themed city builder, has proved itself to be more than just a game; it's an engaging narrative that presents a challenge while also providing a sense of personal connection. This game has managed to offer an impeccable blend of strategic difficulty and a user-friendly tool-set, something not many titles can balance perfectly.

One of the aspects I truly admired about this game was its challenge curve. Initial impressions might suggest that the difficulty ramps up too swiftly, but upon immersing myself deeper, I discovered a beautifully calibrated progression. The increase in difficulty was strategic and deliberate, keeping my city from sinking into a static state of complacency and constantly propelling me toward new objectives and achievements.

Frostpunk brilliantly avoids the need for a min-maxing approach, which is an often tedious requirement in similar genre games. The game provides the freedom to strategize based on your preferred style, whether min-maxing or a more casual approach.

Graphically, the game is an absolute treat. The portrayal of the icy landscapes and the individuality infused into each entity is commendable. The attention to detail in each character, structure, and scenario helps bring the game world to life in a very tangible and immersive way.

Perhaps the most striking feature of Frostpunk is its ability to personalize the gaming experience. The city's survival weighs on your shoulders, and the game does an outstanding job of communicating this responsibility. I remember the first time I lost the game; it was a punch in the gut. Frostpunk has this unique ability to make you care, make each decision matter, and make you feel like your city's survival genuinely hinges on your actions.

In conclusion, Frostpunk is a gem in the survival/city builder genre, offering a compelling mix of strategic challenge and player agency. It truly makes you feel responsible for your city, each decision, and the fate of your citizens. Whether you're a veteran of the genre or new to city-building survival games, Frostpunk provides an experience that is captivating, challenging, and deeply personal.

This game is soul-crushing. Unlike other reviewers, I don't consider this to be a plus. Day after day, the depressing music drills into you while you watch the next cold wave approach. There is no light at the end of the tunnel. Nothing to look forward to. 

The game never rewards you for doing anything right, it only punishes you for doing things wrong, which is all the time. Your people freeze, get amputated or starve. 

 I guess I'm just not a masochist.

OS: Linux Mint 21.2 x86_64
CPU: AMD Ryzen 7 5800H
GPU: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650 4GB
RAM: 16GB

Don't bother to run this on Linux if you don't have a very strong GPU. With these specifications, I managed to run it at ~25 fps with minimal settings. This is due to the game's engine, which somehow eats 4GB of VRAM at startup. This is managed way better in Windows, but that's not the case with Linux.

It's a shame, the game looked very promising, but I had to request a refund. I hope this can be solved in the upcoming Frostpunk 2.

Frostpunk is an amazing game but there are key parts of it that seem to collide with how I think ( so this review is more of a me thing).  first what I find great: Game presentation is gorgeous, saying the game has a good soundtrack is a gross understatement and the story is enthralling  and makes me excited for the sequel.

However  outside of the main campaign a lot of the mechanics don't seem to mesh well  ( note even with how many hours I have I haven't played every single mode through)For example  the last autumn‚Äôs  generator construction is a really unique idea  but even on easy juggling generator construction and well-being of your workers tends to be too much. If you focus on generator construction motivation plummets and discontent skyrockets, if you try and focus on motivation and safety  you get fired on day 15 for missing  your deadline.This wouldn't be so hard  if one of the more frustrating elements of the game wasn't as prominent which is  simply put scuffed situations: most of the time I quit a campaign solely because it would be a waste of time to reach the bad end  because You will often do everything right in  and still lose. And while other games do have this  prevalent as well, the main issue is this conflicts on one of the earliest advice you get in the main campaign  which is ‚Äú  just solve problems your way it's fine‚Äù  and quite a few campaigns this is awful advice especially on higher difficulties  you usually need to go in with a battle plan in the back of your head in order to win some scenarios, and if you're not smart enough to do that on your own well time to start searching up a  campaign guides and do everything by a strict rule book.The other  large problem I have is a few campaigns feel like an afterthought ( obviously they weren't a literal after thought they would look  and feel a lot worse if they were)  but what I mean by that is  campaigns like the arcs last  45 minutes  to an hour tops will simultaneously not giving you enough time to really do anything or experiment with the cool scenario  as well as endless  Builders scenario  has the blood of two different scenarios that mesh horribly  and create a lot of scenarios where you  end up overflowing with discontent and /or  sick and dead people.Finally some laws just don't seem worth it due to their counterparts just being better in most if not all scenarios, for instance  Child Carehouses  and child workers would be a bigger decision  if it weren't for the Apprentice  boost you get from The Care House branch  along with the morale boost you get normally,Same with cemetery/body disposal  paths  well a bit more even than the former  Cemetery tends to be the better option because of it giving you  a permanent way to deal with dead bodies and not adding another building you have to manage and work around ( take this one  with a grain of salt because I haven't tried out Oregon transplants for a campaign). 

Despite my negativity I think this is an amazing game  but  the mechanics  tend to clash and be unforgiving for wrong reasons often  if you're not someone who's very into city builders the gameplay won't be  very fair And expect more out of you than you can possibly do even on easy.So if the atmosphere doesn't somehow bring you in then there's unfortunately nothing in the gameplay for you.

I'm not the biggest RTS gamer but this game absolutely knocks it out of the park with new mechanics and meaningful choices that matter at every moment of game play. You will find yourself restarting the same scenario over and over just to make slightly different decisions and keep your virtual peons alive. It's not exactly a city builder and the only enemy is the weather but it still manages to keep you engaged and enjoying every second. This is the kind of game you can play over and over because the game loop is so addicting. If that wasn't enough, the game comes with an endless mode where you can practice various scenarios of surviving on different maps that reset every time there is a big storm. So there is more than enough content here even if you power through the various core game scenarios. If you feel particularly brave you can even challenge yourself to avoid using certain early game tech options. I remember watching a guy on youtube who played on endless without creating a cook house and only using the rare snow pit cannibalize option.

In summary, this game is just great. IMO, a must have.

Frostpunk distinguishes itself as a fantastic survival game by offering players a thrilling and perilous trip that keeps them engaged from the beginning to the end.

The game distinguishes itself from others in its genre thanks to the original way it combines city-building, resource management, and moral judgment.
The weight of your decisions becomes apparent as you guide a group of survivors in a frozen post-apocalyptic world, influencing both the health of your civilization and the morale of your¬†inhabitants.

As you observe the frantic struggle for existence amid the freezing environment, the immersive experience is further enhanced by the eerily gorgeous images and ambient sound design. The realistic and pressing atmosphere is a result of the game's attention to detail and its dynamic weather engine.

The gameplay mechanics of Frostpunk are expertly designed, and they force players to properly balance resources, build effective infrastructure, and oversee the psychological and physical requirements of their population. The game's depth and intricacy guarantee a satisfying and stimulating experience.

High replay value is provided by the narrative-driven and deliberately planned situations, which encourage players to experiment with various approaches and deal with a variety of difficulties. The game's capacity to arouse feelings, such as hopelessness and triumph, only serves to emphasize how excellent it is.

The developers' dedication to the game's community is also admirable. The experience has been improved and expanded upon through frequent updates, maintaining the game interesting and new.

Frostpunk receives a stellar grade of 9.5/10 for being a wonderful work of survival gaming art. With its gripping gameplay, fascinating graphics, and difficult decision-making, it proves the value of storytelling in video games. If you appreciate survival simulations or are looking for a challenging and riveting gaming experience, Frostpunk is a game that you just must try.

To Be Brief: Frostpunk is a dystopian city builder that presents an interesting setting with solid visual direction and sound work and then stumbles in the execution. Frostpunk is a good game, but if you already know you dislike city builders, this probably wont be the one to shake you from that position. 

Frostpunk carries with it the cardinal sin most city builders carry with them: No matter what else the game does, it fundamentally struggles with presenting you with anything interesting after you've completed it once. Frostpunk does alleviate this somewhat with diverging choices in the game but most of them are poorly explored and boil down to, "Do I want everyone to become a religious fanatic or a fascist?" The setting is poorly leveraged beyond, "Extreme situations drive humans to extreme ideas" and the game itself doesn't really change much. You still have the same overall goals, the means you achieve them with are still the same except your choices provide very slight opportunities for variation. Every single event in the game is virtually guaranteed with few or no exceptions, most results are of little consequence. 

As a result the game presents a lot of 'telling' and not much of that 'showing.' Allowing children to work in, say, a coal mine never runs the risk of a general strike. If you pursue the path of religious fanaticism you'll never find yourself in a position where the faithful find your own faith lacking. If you encourage proto-fascism, you never face any consequences for it other than that, maybe, one person dies of a hunger strike. 

As a result of that, this game does have a problem where once it becomes a SOLVED game, it becomes decidedly boring. Which is a shame, because everything else about the game is great. The setting is inventive, the art and sound direction are great and when and where it manages to get you invested, it's fantastic. But then you find yourself on the other side of those challenges and realize there wasn't much to it. And there's no new challenges for the game to provide. So instead it has to lean on scenarios that only slightly off-set the challenges.

OK this is a tough one, as a city builder it seriously lacks creativity and charm.  The music is as frustrating as the lack of guidance for a new player.  
Once you have come out of it, looked it up online to figure out how to solve the adjacent to road problem, and come across some very uptight fans, you will find a sort of puzzle game with a story, where you are slotting and making laws to make your unhappy and cold population as happy as possible.  It has a maleness about it in terms of the lack of intuition involved in living in a freezing crater.
I am going to say yes it is worth its money and worth playing, however it has already established itself as not a good personal choice due to the very high irritation factor and lack of flexibility.
If you are an uncreative, slightly grumpy gamer this one is definitely for you, however if you are more interested in the occasional cheery moment and being clever about solving problems, probably don't. It is not a speedy game either, I found myself shouting at the screen quite a lot even in the first playthroughs.
I dont feel I wasted my money on it, but if you are looking for happiness, you probably won't find it with this game.

[b]Most disagree with me, but this game is mediocre at best.[/b]

Honestly, I hate this game. It's frankly awful, and the fact that half the content is locked behind DLCs (for example, can't do free-build without buying the DLCs), and on top of that, there are blatant advertisements for Frostpunk 2 right as you start the game, before you even get to the main menu, is just stupid.

Also, this game is absolutely difficult, and not in a good way. I don't get how so many people praise it when even at its easiest difficulty it feels like a stress-inducing chore with very little replayability. I like the idea of it, but I hate the actual execution.

Start the campaign, try to gather some wood and coal far away from town center while also trying to build houses and a medical tent so the people would stop complaining, wood runs out, dismantle the gathering post, still not enough wood to build another one, cue rapid collapse, and game over in 20 minutes. You have to do things in a very specific order. There's no room for error, at all. There's no freedom to play the game your way.

[b]Honestly, it's a game designed for masochists, and anyone who enjoys a normal level of challenge for city builders should look elsewhere. There are much better games out there.[/b]

Loved the play-through, really enjoy the game.  Could you somehow add an option, either in this game or the sequel, where you can turn off the snow particles entirely?  My wife loves these kind of games but can't play it due to the amount of small particles flying across the screen.

Disliked: 
- The animation was hard on my computer, and not possible to put on a setting where it was not.
- The hunting profession magics away the problem of almost all food sources dying in this weather.
- Refugees quietly accept rejection from being allowed to enter the city. Realistically there would be a need for a military.
- For survivors of a hard life or death scenario, civilians are still pretty mentally fragile. Managing this is more annoying than fun.

Neutral:
- It was pretty hard to lose.
- Wish there was some attempt to understand why it is so cold. It could always be a mystery. But towards the end, we had a lot of engineers with free time and a technology level that includes robots.
- Towards the end we had enough technology and resources to survive -200 degrees indefinitely, if the game mechanics did not insist on a temperature too low to grow food indoors. If people can survive, so could plants and animals.

Liked:
- The harshness of the environment escalated in such a way that there was something to work on all the way until robot production. I was entertained for a whole day.
- Good atmosphere and effects.

Sure in Banished they are some problems with winter and food, but you can mitgate it easily, here you have tools, but half of these tools are expensive, you cannot trade ( in main game) you are islolated and you know there is no help. 

You either survive or die, and if you die there is only one way the cold. The workers in this game are also important, while haveing names help them one bark from few of them and the eve of new day helps you undestand

Interesting premise for an older RTS game, but good to burn a few hours here and there for only a few bucks. Goal is to survive 48 days in the cold and make it through end-game final "storm". Had to restart it a few times because I failed and got lovely "Your Time Has Come" message from my population. You have to manage heat, resources, food, health and also Discontent & Hope which are governed by actions or decisions you take as leader. Also send scouts out to explore and gather other survivors and "steam cores" which can't be crafted/made. Game doesn't last very long once you know how to play it and what is important to focus on (coal). I think I had less than 18 hours with it. Each replay makes you go back through scripted sequences and initial challenges so that gets a bit old, but they've added new features and challenges which I have not played yet. Graphics are good with the animations and artwork. Voice acting and voice prompts are good. Building is limited to circular/radial patterns around the central generator. Not a huge issue and you can decide what to put where. Upgrade trees are present for different technologies and then a set of "laws" you can enact that effect Discontent and Hope. Enact a law regarding health and some hope may rise, but discontent may also rise. Tell them to let a kid die in the cold and hope will fall, but discontent may fall. Lots of variables. The only thing I didn't like is that there's a time-scale button to increase game timing half or double speed (something like that). If you click double speed - which you'll have to do or just sit there waiting for hours - sometimes your Hope or Discontent will spike and you'll lose before you can address the issue. There were a few times when all was well (good Hope and low Discontent) and when I clicked the speed-up time, it suddenly notified me "Your Time Has Come" which is the game's message that you've failed. Units can also only "work" or "upgrade" during daylight hours although they will build and hunt during the night. All in all an interesting premise presented pretty well and for the price it's a good way to spend a day or so when you don't want to work! I'd like to see a Frostpunk sequel with some expanded game play/options.

I do like it when a game keeps me on my toes. However in this one, you are always in a disadvantage in every step of the way. 
Which is fine at first, but further in the game you're doing nothing but trouble shoot and react instead of acting. 
Then for no reasons somehow a building has no workers, though you didn't put the workers elsewhere. You notice that when you are getting out of ressources.
Then there's always the demand to heat the living quarters. But when you place a heater right in front of the building it won't do nothing.
After reloading it magically works and the homes are heated properly, still you broke your promise and people loose hope.
Also to find the one cold home is like trying to find the needle in a pile of snow.
The developers really should fix those bugs.
I'm aware that this is a hardcore city builder, but there should be more options to react on the problems than the two obvious and definetly not the best solutions.

Ah, there's so much to say about Frostpunk. What a spectacular game! Everything about it is great, it's 10/10 for me.
It's a survival RTS single player dream, with a fantastic law system that coordinates well with the tech trees. Nice cutscenes that introduce each scenario but then don't get in the way after, beautiful winter aesthetics, moral choices that still stir my soul even after making them tons of times. It's tough and smart, you will lose if you don't take it seriously. The weather and temperature system is completely genius, it really adds a new sense of worry but usually with enough time to do something about it. The exploration mechanic is also great. Gah - it's a thing of pure gaming beauty, I'm HYPED for FP2.

I also highly recommend the Last Autumn DLC, a great, difficult scenario with new tech and new choices, perfect for post-frostpunk depression.

Frostpunk has captured my heart, and it's much more than just a game - it's an immersive, dark societal survival saga that tests your strategic abilities to their absolute limit. The initial playthroughs are brutal, exacting, and unforgiving, demanding you to truly understand and acclimate to the frigid world you inhabit.

The expertly composed music and sound effects heighten the experience, imbuing a palpable sense of grim realism. You can almost feel the oppressive weight of existence in this frozen wasteland, each note and sound adding layers of depth to the stark reality that this game portrays.

The decisions you are faced with are as profound as they are unnerving. They are substantial, fraught with moral ambiguities, showcasing the clear thought and meticulous planning that went into the development of Frostpunk.

Yet be forewarned: Frostpunk is a game that seldom allows for a pristine sense of triumph. The decisions you're compelled to make to ensure survival are often shrouded in ethical gray areas. So, even as you persevere, the actions taken to achieve such 'victories' leave an indelible mark on your conscience, akin to a stain that won't wash off. Survival here doesn't always taste sweet; it‚Äôs more a grim acceptance of what you've had to do to secure it.

This game actually made me feel bad once for genuinely messing up and killing everyone in Winterhold.

TL;DR - Strong recommendation to play, visuals and gameplay have come together into brilliant release.

It has been quite for some time and 11 bit studios brought upon us challenging management problem - surviving and saving during deadly frost times, heat them, feed them, treat them. Help humanity withstand disastrous catastrophe never faced before.

It has been released long time ago, but probably someone will check out my review before Frostpunk 2 on the horizon. Here are my strong points of recommendations why the game is worth your time.
- If you fan of strategies, management, city-building, etc just buy and enjoy, it will not feel like any other game before
- Challenging, across multiple stories you will need to face different victory conditions, some of them are not easy to fulfill from the first try of the game. It has a learning curve
- One more [strike]step[/strike] day gameplay.
- Visuals, they are definitely one of the topmost reasons. Steampunk setting of Victorian style English colony bring some of the best aesthetics in genre.
- Decent "replayability", I was not tired of the game through the hours I had spent on it. Would probably have spend even more but wanna check out other games from my library as well. Also sequel is coming so likely will spend time in it.

I already had hundreds of hours with Frostpunk's Console Versions. Playing the PC version enhanced my experience tenfold. 

This is one of my favorite games ever. The atmosphere, lore, and visuals are all amazing. Gameplay is extremely addicting. The soundtracks are beautiful, it encompasses the chilling terror, moral ambiguity, and inspiring hope. Frostpunk's introduce thought provoking ways to manage your city. How far will you go to save your rule? How desperate are you to get your resources? What line will you cross to ensure survival? All choices are yours to make. 

Frostpunk has multiple scenarios you can play after beating the main one. My personal favorite being the tragedy that is the Fall of Winterhome. All scenarios tells different stories, each rich and builds on the lore of the universe you partake in. 

I can't wait for Frostpunk 2! I highly recommend you buy this game!

It's a stupid artificial simulator of a suicide club. It beats sandbox city-builders because there's something like a campaign instead of open ended nonsense where you have to decipher the game and entertain yourself. But as someone who works night shift for the last 15 years i question why the hell there is no second shift for people to literally not die. And such gamey stupid artificiality is everywhere. Hur-dur child labour. Yeah, there is no government endorsed child labour, and it's illegal. But when things get going parents exploit the hell out of their children. I've spent all my childhood working potato fields, growing crops, stealing cow turds at nights, building the house, sorting and assembling ball pens, manually washing clothes, scrubbing homes and washing dishes, because parents assigned me such tasks to earn my share of food. This is not a game about first world democracy, this is survival. And people in live or die situations don't behave like extremely rich white people from usa.
If they can't self-provide and self-organize to the point of making you a scape-goat for their own inability to make any decisions, they should work better. If they want to die so much, well, let them. 

It can be a challenging game for people who love artificial self-imposed challenges more than common sense. Even if you make something stable, the next quest will intentionally just gift you like 90% hit to all the stats. The only winning move is not to play the game. And as for my taste, i cannot "recommend" this game of managing repulsive idiots who want to kill themselves. Let them, i'm outta here.

Frostpunk taught me that even when it seems impossible, there's always a way. You might need to adapt, and change. But you can always find a way to survive. The game is a brutal, brutal survival experience. I failed my first 5 or so play-throughs. But eventually I beat it. I survived. By the end, I didn't think I was gonna make it. The cold had simply frozen all of my food generating structures. The number of sick was growing rapidly, and I got worried. But then I stripped all of my frozen structures, and put my medical buildings as close to the heat as I could and I gave it all the heat I had to help heal my dying city. And then eventually, after painful, brutal, days... The sun came, and I survived. A game hasn't tested me like this in some time, I was determined to beat it though. Everything about it is excellent though, from the music to the artstyle to the concept. Some pop up decisions didn't really make sense to me though, like the game might give you three choices and it tells you the outcome of all three and for example, 2 might be negative outcomes and 1 is much more positive. I don't know why you'd choose any of the negative choices? Seems bizzare but it only happens a couple times. Other than that, the game is fun through and through. And even though my first few games failed miserably, it was fun to lose and learn what to do differently next time. 9/10 game, truly.

i love how the game captures desperation

considering the choices you get in the game between "the right thing to do and outright eveil" - I thought the theme was like the decades old citybuilder black & white, where you choose between good and evil. 

My first play through i made a good samiritan run, the second run was going to be an evil run. Quickly did i realize that its not a choice between good an evil, its actual moral dilemmas. Can our stockpiles of food sustain refuges or do i doom my citizen to starvation? Do I secretly fill up the food reserves with human meat or do we all starve to death.

neither is the ultimate "laws" of either religion or "order" the goal to achive, rather they are the result of a slippery slope where in the most desperate of times the temporary benefits of executing treasures elements in the city is has an aluring appeal.

Frost Punk to first glance, looked like a bit of a lower budget, lazy city building, possibly uninteresting of an experience, kind of game. However, I willingly eat my hat, and shame myself to think so lowly of the game_ just by looking at game play and still images. Frost punk is without a doubt the most addicting game I've ever played, even though it doesn't seem like that kind of a game. It's grindy, but not Diablo/mobile game, kind of grindy.  

The universe is very fascinating, based around the "Year Without Summer." The scenario(s) are interesting and interactive. You tend to take your decisions a little to personally, especially when messing up. Watching your little NPCs work to death in the arctic cold. When you screw up, you begin to learn and find out ways to improve. As a guy that HATES to do things twice, this game, I don't even give it a second thought. 

Very problem solving, critical thinking, and resource management based of survival game. Gotta think on your toes and prioritise, and get ahead of what is coming as best as you can. I without a doubt LOVE this game and cannot wait to try out Frost Punk 2!

((On top of the hours I've played here on steam, I also have an additional 20-25hrs on Xbox Game Pass, where I first learned about the game. ))

[h1] Review[/h1] 
I got this game once for free on epic, but solely the base game. After I played a bit the main scenario, I immediately bought it on steam as I wanted more of the game, and I don‚Äôt buy any games on epic.

[u]Gameplay[/u]
The idea is that you build a small city around a giant machine while managing heat and other resources. There are 4 Scenarios being usually around 2-4 hours in play time. They each have some unique twist to them. As an example, in one you have to horde masses amount of food and prepare houses as a slowly bigger storm of refugees arrive in a wave. In another one you have mostly to keep up the heat of seed vaults.
Buildings that are closer to the machine usually don‚Äôt need heating on their own so its good to build houses or medical stations there while buildings that are warm anyways  like workshops for research can be placed further away. 

Additionally from building heat sources, deciding which building to research next or build, you can have scouts that traverse a non-random map with resources, stories and other stuff to find. The difficulty in the game is usually with the scenarios main goal and additionally the heat will drop and rise but slowly being lower than before meaning old buildings may not retain liveable condition and needs to be heated or people will get sick or die.

There are also some political rules/choices you can make which can go into a fascist dictatorship or religious rule. Generally, the religious path is just way superior because they have better bonuses and do not require men all time to patrol the streets.

The game is played in a way that you barely can win on the normal difficulty if you don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs coming. As some have scripted scenarios that can lose your game if you didn‚Äôt quick save all time.  For me it was incredibly fun to try and build different approaches managing to finally beat a map and I feel like for that the main ‚Äúnormal‚Äù difficulty is a good challenge between not too hard and not too easy if you accept that you might need to retry once or twice. The higher difficulties on the other hand don‚Äôt feel that fun as they are feeling like a lot RNG based and on top of that you basically have to follow 1: 1 guide to beat them.
Overall if you beat everything you can also do an endless mode but for that the game wasn‚Äôt really programmed or at least mainly intended and balanced. Beating the scenarios is incredibly fun but its rather short lived as without DLC there are only 4 which u beat probably in around 10 hours. After that you can do miscellaneous achievements in case you want to continue playing but I found the game had way too many and some being repetitive like play a run without building a or building b etc. Or misleading ones as there are no death achievements despite the game featuring scripted deaths anyways.

[u]Story[/u]
I found the scenarios stories fun and engaging having various sudden plot twists and while also giving some smaller decisions. Overall really engaging and immersive having also some smaller lore info‚Äôs sprinkled into the loading screen as there are wide arrange of contrary opinions about the cold or they explain the reason why the game is even set at the artic.

[u]Sound[/u]
The game features heavily violins and generally orchestra music which also ends into a very heavy cascade in the finale of a scenario making the city must survive one of the best songs I have ever heard in any video game.
Also the general sound design is conveying the danger and threat of the barely habitable surroundings perfectly from its heavy on duty warning noises, to snow storms pillaging across the area.

[u]Graphics[/u]
Im always impressed with these base buildings games animation of diverse buildings and characters. Its fun to look around and see what kind of building does what. This doesn‚Äôt feature this a lot and is more focused on A LOT of images that have small animations adding its own style to them. This type of animation style always looks fantastic and is in the game almost everywhere to be seen and rarely these repeat.

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR[/u]
I found the game very engaging due to its unique setting, great orchestra OST and fun gameplay that while not being too complex still is something rather unique with its heat management system. There are sadly only a few scenarios but those that exist are really good, wanting me to tackle them on higher difficulties albeit I found the higher difficulties more frustrating than fun. The endless mode isn‚Äôt really balanced that great and therefore my biggest critique is the rather short gameplay time. And me saying I want more of the game is more or less a good thing.

I got this game last weekend because it came in really good sale bundle, I had heard of it but never really looked into what it was. I am so glad I gave it a shot, yet somewhat regretful, because I have become so obsessed! This game is frustratingly difficult, I love it. Even if you think you have everything set up perfectly, it can all come crashing down within seconds, but it is so worth it when you finally reach the end of a scenario.
It's a city builder with resource management and harsh survivor mechanics. Each scenario sets you up a bit different, but beyond resources and labor, you need to also maintain Hope and Discontent levels of your people(for most scenarios at least). You can lead your people down a path of Faith or Order, hold religion over your people's heads or rule them with an iron fist. All of these needs are constantly battling for your attention, and you're never truly in an abundance of any needs being met. A decision you make early in the game, could be the reason for your downfall 5hrs into the game later.
This game has massive replayabilty, I usually never replay games but I can't stop redoing scenarios to achieve different results, not even to mention the variety of difficulty setting you can play with. The game is still worth it on its own, but the expansion does a really good job of changing it up while still feeling like the same game, making gameplay feel endless.

I can not wait for the sequel to come out next year! I would love to see some spin-off type titles to go along with the world building they've set up. They leave some of the lore loose on purpose, but I it just leaves me dying for more answers!

Playing Frostpunk was an unforgettable experience the first time I played through it. I attempted to create a city with humane laws that managed workloads for the betterment of my people under a fair government, only to become an extremely corrupt government that threw morals to the wind to withstand the final test in the games brutal campaign. There is almost no other game that has matched the helplessness that I felt throughout the journey and I highly recommend this to anyone who has even the slightest interest in it. Easily one of my favorite games I have played.

A city builder with a twist. It's fun, well written and absolutely leans into this crazy world of... frostpunk.

-> Immediately ran into a bug with 'The Last Autumn'. It felt more like it was just of an annoyance that I was there, and the addition of new materials already made me grow cross-eyed. It was okay, but I'm not a fan of having to restart again...
-> 'On the Edge' was okay, but it became very much an overworld management screen, rather than the Frostpunk I enjoyed. Very little city building, and much more concerns around choices, which would have been fine if the game changed to manage it better.
[spoiler] You can't see the favour or relationship with the other settlements, or even your own city stats when you start to make your choices, so you either load a save after a poorly informed choice, or live with it. [/spoiler]

Man, my friend told me to play this game like 7 months ago. I saw it on Steam (on sale for 8 bucks CAD) last week after wanting a different building sim other than Cities: Skylines and now I have 55 hours in a week and a half. I bought this game and played the first night for 6 hours. Over the course of the next 5 days, I played the moment I came home from work and played until I physically had to tell myself to go to sleep for work the next day because all I wanted to do was play this game. On my first day off owning this game I played for 20 hours. I played as much as I could on the weekend and then my next day off I played for another 12, then called off work the next day to continue playing because I had such a lack of sleep and even given myself a migraine from staring at my screen for so long. Probably have some other underlying factors that might attribute to that but oh well. Pretty good game tbh.

Silly name aside, Frostpunk is a brilliantly conceived and executed game that sucked me in quickly and didn't let go until I was having night terrors about keeping the coal generator running. All aspects of the game were well thought-out, it looks and runs great, and you really feel the pressure to help your community survive the harsh winters. It's comparable to the Tropico series, with a morose skin, and as functional as the better entries in that series. Highly recommended.

This is a honest review, no bias. I love this game. everything about it. One of the best if not the best city-builders I've played in a while. The atmosphere and score really create the perfect environment for an addictive but punishing city-builder. The lore is just right to where not too much is revealed in the main game, but makes you wonder about a lot of things. This game is a perfect judge of character for anyone who might need that and is also a perfect resource-strategy builder. The challenging part of the game is really what makes it so good, the immersive-ness of the game makes you want to sympathize with the survivors, while also creating order and faith to keep the city running no matter what. The moral choice this game will have you make really stand it apart from other city builders, aside from the great score and graphic design.

This game much more than just a city builder. It's an immersive and riveting campaign, full of hardship, stress, and triumph against all odds. You'll be faced with challenges that will make you think "How can we possibly survive this? We're doomed!" and then, as their leader, you have to find a way to pull through, no matter what. There's no other choice. You'll find yourself growing attached to your citizens, thinking that, after coming so far already, you can't give up. You'll be constantly wracked with uncertainty and fear of what could be next, but also full of the perseverance, grit, and determination to face it.
Truly one of the most thrilling and fun experiences I've had this year.

Really enjoyable game, lovely balance between a general simplicity of elements (easy to learn) and challenging and diverse scenarios. The lovely graphics and music don't hurt either. 

Favorite scenario by far was the Fall of Winterhome, tough scramble right from the start and just when you are getting comfy, they hit you sideways with a new fight all the way to the end. Don't read ahead, just play it.
The Generator is life, and if it runs cold, it's a race to either get it back online or be cast out of the city by the people who trusted you to keep them alive
Love this game! Can't wait for FP2!!

While this is a superb real-time strategy and city builder, with incredible graphics and sound, it unfortunately fails in the user experience.  The mouse cursor is white and can be difficult to find in the predominantly white snowfields of the game.  The tutorials of the game consist of flash-cards indicating what to do, but does not adequately describe how to do it.  Need to send scouts to a city?  Make sure you select your scout team, even though you've only got one scout team and there is no warning that you need to do so.

While the graphics are brilliant, the design of the buildings is not.  A lot of them look identical from your top-down perspective and the only way to find a specific building is by scrolling through the GUI.  You also have no means of keeping track of how many buildings of a specific type you have.

The difficulty curve is best described as 'Dark Souls'.  Mere days into your run you are hit with devastating blizzards that can permanently send the temperature so low that buildings stop working and your citizenry start getting frostbite.  This cripples your ability to gather resources, which makes the citizens angry, who demand expensive action that costs resources you don't have.  Worse, the game does not really allow you to experiment and find solutions: you HAVE to know in advance the one true solution or you'll be kicked out -- and this is AFTER you rig the game to its easiest setting.  The game badly needs a sandbox mode where you can study its mechanics in peace, but it's not there.  The result is learned helplessness and rage-quit.

The narrative of the game is incredibly interesting, but it is presented poorly.  The opening prologue in story mode is beautiful, but it runs for too long without providing any desired insights.  Snippets of lore only come on the load screens, and too short to truly read and absorb.

I truly wish I could have enjoyed this game more, but the frustration I have while playing the game stop it from being fun.

This game presented a unique and captivating challenge that kept me engaged from start to finish. The strategic elements required careful planning and resource management, forcing me to think several steps ahead to ensure the prosperity of my city. What truly set this game apart was its awe-inspiring story and concept. The developers crafted a rich and immersive narrative that unfolded gradually, revealing unexpected twists and turns along the way.

The concept itself was fresh and innovative, breathing new life into the genre. The seamless integration of strategy and city building mechanics created a harmonious gameplay experience that felt truly immersive. I found myself constantly engaged, brainstorming new strategies, and exploring the depths of the game's possibilities. This game truly exceeded my expectations and delivered an unforgettable gaming experience. If you're a fan of both strategy and city building games, I highly recommend diving into this world of challenges, fresh ideas that will leave you craving for more.

What a delight! What an absolute delight of a game. I played it, played it again, bought the DLC, and played those, too. Replaying each scenario to get the perfect ending was enjoyable, and hunting for the achievements was even more so. I only wish that there was more, such as a multiplayer option or further customization for your starting point (possibly allowing the player to see how much easier or harder it was for the settlements of Children's Mine, Hot Springs, or Shipwreck Camp).

Played the game on Gamepass and liked it so much I just had to buy it on Steam with all the DLC. Incredible builder with a story. I was worried that since it's linear it will be short with very little replayability. I was wrong. Plenty of fun in the base game, and even more with additional campaigns in the DLC. I have at least as many hours on Xbox as I have on Steam, and got to have lots of fun for the price of the game. I highly recommend it.

This game is so depressing that you feel like you lost even when you win. It plays a mournful violin theme while your hopes for a thriving society and happy inhabitants slowly crumbles to dust, just like your family always knew your own life would. 

And you will love the game for it. Because you still want to save what you can.  Because you want to give them hope and at least a fighting chance. Yes, some have to die, but if that means others get to live... it's worth it! Isn't it?

A relatively simple game to get into, Frostpunk is a settlement manager game with only a handful of resources. The emphasis is on ethical questions rather than economy or complex manufacturing chains. For example: wiill you force people to have amputations, if that saves their lives?  It has a few scenarios you can play, worth about 30 hours if you're slow like me. The rest is available as DLCs.
It is a very well done game.

Frostpunk‚Äù is an impressive simulation and strategy game that puts you in charge of managing a city in a world ravaged by harsh weather conditions. It presents survival challenges and requires strategic decision-making to allocate resources, develop the city, and ensure the survival of its citizens. With multiple endings depending on your decisions, the game offers endless replay value. The graphics are stunning, and the gameplay is immersive. Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed ‚ÄúFrostpunk,‚Äù and I highly recommend it to all strategy game enthusiasts

The worst possible nightmare for any leader, but that is what makes [i] Frostpunk [/i] a unique and beautiful game at the same time. Contrary to other strategic games such as [i] Sid Meier's Civilizations [/i] and [i] Heroes of Might and Magic [/i], there is absolutely no honor and glory in [i] Frostpunk [/i]. All there exists is the extreme level of responsibility imposed upon you to lead your people to survival in the extreme environments you are in; your success yesterday is easily forgotten and your failure today will be remembered with grudge and hatred. You will be threatened both by Mother Nature and your own people all the time, and nobody is there to soothe your pain, let alone save you.

The beauty of [i] Frostpunk [/i] is in that it goes to the extreme length to emphasize the price and burden of leadership. Typical strategic games promote the aesthetics of honor and glory in leadership, paying as little attention as possible to the weight of the crown. But [i] Frostpunk [/i] goes the other way and bring out to the surface how painful and agonizing it can be as a leader. There is seriously no time to feel entitled; Mother Nature keeps lashing on your back and the people you are supposed to protect keep complaining and protesting your rule. Sometimes you just want to quit, but at the same time, you know that someone has to do this or everyone including yourself will perish. No dream, no ambition, but sheer responsibility keeps you moving. This, I believe, is the crucial reality of leadership that modern day society has long ago forgotten and that [i] Frostpunk [/i] successfully reminds us of with its extreme premise. I'm very impressed by their delivery.

Overall, [i] Frostpunk [/i] feels more like an artwork than a video game. At a glance, it's a strategic game like [i] Sid Meier's Civilizations [/i], but [i] Frostpunk [/i] does not have enough contents to call itself as either 4x game or city builder game. It focuses more on its unique aesthetics stated above, and keeps throwing thought-provoking questions to you as you play through. Personally, this was a very refreshing, or even educational take for me. It feels like a classic literature on political science (ex. Machiavelli's 'The Prince', Plato's 'The Laws', etc.) in video game format. If you are also someone like me looking for realistic aesthetics of leadership, I can recommend this with confidence. But if you are strictly looking for a city builder game, you might want to check out other city builders.

Where to start with frostpunk, is it infuriating at times? will you find yourself swearing to never attempt a certain scenario again? will you be so annoyed you think about never opening the game again? the answer to all of the above is yes. But if your like me you'll still boot it back up and try again and when you win a scenario eventually you'll want to reply and do better.

This game is highly addictive, challenging and rewarding. As of writing this review I've beaten all but one of the scenarios and some more than once. The story is compelling, the extra content well worth the cost and the satisfaction with success is amazing. If you are impatient or easily enraged this game may not be for you, and there is a learning curve (I can almost guarantee you will fail on your first attempt if not the first few) but if your willing to try again and learn from your mistakes you will find a gratifying experience that will have you coming back again and again.

An absolutely beautiful gem of a game with a gripping story and a well thought out and  interesting universe. I did find it very hard on normal difficulty and had to do a custom one for a  following playthrough (you can change the difficulty if you survive for long enough in new home) . I genuinely cared for the survivors and prayed for them surviving the storm. Has a bit of a learning curve and as said if you're new to this sort of game it is very hard, but it really is a good, unique game. Very recommended.

I don't see what all the hype is about. The pacing is very slow, very little happens, occasionally you build one building. The premise is a bit silly, if you were living in a cold crater you wouldn't just put a heater out in the open and vent all your heat into the atmosphere, you'd build a facility with a roof and heat that. Everything about it is just... dull! I don't understand why it is so highly-rated. I've played for 5 hours, and I'm just bored.

Fantastic game, so far very challenging. If you're having doubts, buy it and play it, you won't be able to stop. If you're stuck, you prob got a good idea of what you did wrong. Mechanics are insanely meticulous, hopefully I'm done this one when the beta for the second comes out. I hope you enjoy it as much as I have and as much as I know I will in the near future.

This game is phenomenal. I fell inlove with the game after just a couple hours of playing. I really like the concept of being the last survivors on Earth and clinging on to your only hope, which is the generator, providing heat and warmth so that surviving is made possible through gathering resources, building structures, making heart-breaking decisions, and surviving the harsh winter of the North. It really plays with your feelings since in this game, you are to make decisions that will probably shake your morality and make you question yourself. I fell inlove with the game since the graphics were outstanding, the soundtracks are absolutely stunning, the gameplay is chill. Overall, the game is definitely worth trying, and that is, if you're into apocalyptic survival games.
One of the few games I can truly lose track of time playing.

Let me say right out of the gate that this game is not going to appeal to everyone. If you're not down for an extremely hard Frigid Death simulator mixed with city planning then this game is not going to be for you. But it was ABSOLUTELY for me. I can't stop playing it. I want to get better. I want more of my people to survive than the last time I played a scenario. My only complaint is that I bought all of the DLC and still want MORE. If you're unsure if you'll like it, buy it on sale. If this looks like the game for you, dive in and experience the glorious, stressful dread for yourself.

I haven't played this game all too much, and I don't have everything unlocked like many people may, but in the time I have played this game. I have enjoyed it very much. The time I've played it may not look like much, but when you get playing this game, a short time can feel like a long time. This game does a great job of making you consider every decision you make. Overall, this game has a great story, and even has a second one out that I haven't got to play yet, but I can only imagine it is as good as this one. I would recommend this game to anybody that loves to have control over things like people, resources, enjoys a good challenge, and likes decision-based games. Off the top of my head, I couldn't really suggest any changes to the game to improve it, except maybe more choices as to how to respond to the community within the game, but even then, there isn't much you could do to improve it. Absolutely one of the better builders out there.

it's difficult, but restarting is always a joy. I have 140 hours played and have never finished the first mission. That might make me a bit of an edge case and weird, but at the same times it tells the story of how replayable and well thought out the mechanics are. Every single time before finishing the mission I think "I could have done this or that a little better", quit and restart.

Mechanics are well thought out. You know what is happening, and why it is happening. UI is great. Graphics are solid for the genre. Atmosphere, as well, is as good as it gets in this genre.

My only major criticism is that in some cases the game doesn't really make sure you know what you need to know when it comes to timed objectives. 9 times out of 10 when I fail to build something I promissed to build in time it wasn't because I couldn't have managed to do so, but because I simply forget. Some "in your face" type of notifications for certain things would be a good addition.

How many hours I'll have played before the game is finished, I don't know, but value for my money... I've already gotten many times over.

Welcome to Frostpunk, the game where the cold never bothered you anyway... until now! This game is like a survival version of Disney's Frozen, but instead of singing about love, you're singing about staying warm.

In Frostpunk, you play as the ruler of a group of survivors in a post-apocalyptic ice age. Your job is to build and manage a city that can withstand the freezing temperatures, while also keeping your citizens happy and healthy. It's like SimCity, but with more parkas.

And let me tell you, keeping these people warm is no easy task. You'll be juggling coal supplies, generator maintenance, and the occasional freak snowstorm. But don't worry, you're not alone! You'll have a team of trusty engineers to help you keep the city running smoothly.

But the real star of this game is the moral dilemmas. Do you sacrifice a few citizens to save the many? Do you institute child labor to keep the coal mines running? It's like playing the world's coldest game of Would You Rather.

Overall, Frostpunk is a chillingly good time. Just make sure you have a cup of hot cocoa on hand, because this game will make you feel like you're living in the middle of an eternal blizzard. And who knows, maybe after playing Frostpunk, you'll finally appreciate the heat waves of summer

A good steam/frostpunk city builder dealing with the challenges of building a city during the period of an 1800s apocalyptic frost/cold.  There is also some half decent lore tid bits to find throughout the scenarios.  This is however a fairly brutal game even on normal and tends to snowball, where things tend to go well and be easy or, will be bad and snowball into being worse, and its often better to just restart if things go too bad.  Harder difficulties do tend to severely limit your options for success, and personally I'm not a fan of the hardest mode like Survival that remove your ability to save and pause the game.  

There is also ironically possibly something slightly off with optimization which seems to make this game generate excess amounts of heat on my system that requires enabling fan boost.

TL;DR: Frostpunk is one-dimensional and an extremely linear city builder. Compared with other survival city builders on the market you can get much better games which you will play for much longer. I‚Äôve got vanilla Frostpunk and all DLCs for ¬£10 and I feel it‚Äôs the alright price.

Pros:
- Fantastic soundtrack and arts
- Very unique game (especially when it was released)
- The first game is really really interesting and you will definitely feel like you should play once again with different choices
- If you are playing for the first time, it really feels like a survival game

Cons:
- In the first game, Frostpunk will try to create a feel of being a deeper game (from the story, choices and mechanisms perspective). It‚Äôs fantastic on the first run but on the second run, you realised how many things here are pre-scripted or are not changing that much when you will choose a different path.
- I failed to survive the last blizzard and I was excited to play the second time but the second run was just boring and didn‚Äôt bring any new to the game, so most of the time I setup on the max speed and pause the game when something was happening (research complicated, I need to send somewhere troops on the map, more coal etc).
- The main split in the law & order is when you need to choose one of the path: totalitarianism vs church. Yes, there are different laws between paths, different ways of governing the city and different buildings but in the end, it doesn‚Äôt feel like there is a bit of change between paths in the gameplay.
- If you finished your two first runs and you chose different law paths then the game will not offer you anything else. Each run can take 4-6 hours, so after 10 hours, you will see everything that the game can offer to you.
- My second run took 4 hours and I felt bored for most of the time. It was just copy-pasted gameplay from the first run for 90% of the time. The difference was with choosing law and different buildings which I could build.
- I thought when people will be more unhappy it will impact my city in some way but I couldn‚Äôt feel it at all. I couldn‚Äôt feel a difference between the 0% unhappy level and 60%. I never achieved more than 60% because it‚Äôs so easy to get it down to the bottom.
- I think the map (where you can send your troops) is pre-generated and there is no difference in the told story, numbers of getting materials, place of locations etc.
- You can get some resources per each found city per 1 day but in the end, I haven‚Äôt seen a point to get anything else than just steam cores. All other resources are available in your city and can be gathered much quicker.
- I got an automaton on my second run from the 3rd location on the map and from this point everything was going extremely smoothly. After getting the factory and the first 4 automatons to get busy in coal mines, I felt like I‚Äôm just cheating here.
- After the first two runs I known which technology is the most useful, which law is the most powerful and where to get the best resources from the map. At this point, you know the meta and there is absolutely no reason to change it during your next run.
- I haven‚Äôt finished any run for the DLC but I‚Äôve opened each map and I‚Äôve checked possible laws, technologies, locations and non of the DLC was interesting to play the 3rd time.
- Even if I will play every single scenario from vanilla and DLCs 3 times, it could be in total 40- 50 hours. It's still really low number if we will think it's a city builder. There are many other city builders which can start showing new mechanism at 50 hours gameplay and you can still discover new things. Here? It's total maximum which you can take of from this game.

It's a "decent" game. 6/10 if I had to give it a score. I beat the campaign in about 12 hours but the game is well crafted and descriptive, complex, and content-rich. I feel like two things really hold the game back:

1. You'll notice almost immediately that the developers incorporated some weird splash effect on the windows and popups that reduce visibiliy, and increase wait time, and feels like a cheap alternative to using real graphics. This same "cheap graphic design" is also how I would describe the "icing effect" that covers the edges of the screen at nearly all times.

2. There is almost no replayability in this game. The choices do matter, because if you choose the wrong one you lose but not because there are multiple choices to win. The only major choice I could see having an impact on the campaign is whether you choose to side with order or whether you choose to side with religion but either way you're scouting the same locations, building the same structures for the same resources, and in the same order of operations or your settlement will die.

The complexity of the game isn't in that it provides choice but in the illusion of choice it describes well the benefits and detriments of each action. For $30? Pass. If you happen to find it on sale for $15 it's probably worth a few hours of your time.

EDIT:

I wanted to edit my review after playing the game again recently. The developers actually did listen to feedback and removed the intensity of the graphical splash effect! Better, the new DLC adds greater depth and longevity to the game. The best part is that even with all of the new content this game is now only $12. I've changed my review to 7.5/10.

For those who enjoy brutal survival games, this is a great purchase.  Its setting is on point, it's bleak, it's miserable, it makes you want to grab a jacket.

The entire game (Minus expeditions) is set in a single location around which you will build your colony.  Within each variation, as far as I can tell, there's no variation as to what the landscape and the available resources will contain.  Don't take that to mean that there's no variety, there's plenty of it, it just comes in the form of the dynamic events that occur throughout the game as well as the expeditions you'll undertake.

There are five resources to find and utilize - coal, wood, steel, food and steam cores - and you have very little time to setup systems to obtain these resources at [i]least[/i] as fast as you're consuming them.  There's a somewhat invisible resource of heating, provided by your generator by way of expending coal, and this will be your life line in this post-apocalyptic land of frost.

As the game moves forward, you will be in a race against time to obtain what resources you need to keep your civilians alive in [i]that[/i] moment while also keeping more than just a little of your brain power on what they're going to need next.  And they will need more things and increasing amounts of them sooner than you'd think.

The resources present on the ground will run out in a matter of days, and you'll have to establish more permanent methods of harvesting the raw materials you need to stay afloat, as well as ways to heat everything during cold spells or you'll quickly become inundated with sick citizens who still need beds to sleep in and food to eat but won't be providing valuable manpower.

My main complaint about this game is that, within a scenario, there's basically no room for error.  If you don't meet a specific deadline for certain things - providing housing within the [i]first day [/i] for instance - then you will quickly be beyond recovery for that run, and you're left with limping along to an inevitable loss or just starting over.  But the thing is, that next run you'll fix that issue and then immediately be hit with another situation that you couldn't have foreseen without foreknowledge, fail again, and repeat this process ad nauseum.  

And yes, it's a survival game.  I get that failing and learning and trying again is what the game [i]is[/i].  But I feel like they should have made each critical point such that you have some time to adjust and correct course without outright failing.  Sometimes you can, but the vast majority of the time, if it's your first time seeing some critical event, you're almost certainly about to spin up a new game.

All in all, for anyone who loves more challenging survival games, city planning, etc, this is a game for you.

Side note - the board game of this is also really good and super challenging.

One of the games of all time. Brutally difficult at first, but with a comfortable learning curve.

I love how the game handles what is essentially the mode of government. You start with neighborhood watches or chapels, doing a service to the people of the city, then spiral into despotism and start executing people at random just to get by.

Child labour, putting sawdust in the food just to fill bellies, letting the sick die in the streets because you can't keep the heat on. Many tough decisions to be made just to survive.
Played endless mode, went 6 storms without a generator, then realized over 100 of my workers had fallen into the generator during construction.

I can‚Äôt express how this masterwork of a game astonished me.

I was just expecting a fun management game like Banished or Ceasar. Frost Punk adds to great gameplay an amazing artistry. The music, graphics, effects, text and progression rythm all contribute to express this whole experience.

The first game is a very intense experience. One wouldn‚Äôt expect such tension build-up from a management game.

Then there are several other stories to play through, and several settings in endless mode for a more classic playmode.

I would recommend this game twice if I could to people who love management games.

I'm convinced that this is the most perfect game I've ever played, and I'm not exaggerating. The soundtrack is unmatched, the artstyle and ambiance is phenomenal, and the attention to detail still blows my mind 140 hours in. It manages to address the psychology, politics, and morals that come with controlling a large population as a leader, just as much as the physical survival and hardship. I've genuinely learned so much from this game, including things about myself. I didn't think a strategy game would be the most immersive gaming experience I've ever had, but it's true. The sounds within each building are different, and sometimes change depending on the mood of your people. The story, the characters, the design, the scenarios, I could gush about this game all day, it's my favorite. I can't wait for Frostpunk 2!

A game that's difficult to master and impossible to perfect. It took me a while to get in to the game coming from more traditional city-builder/survival titles, and the game's brutal and unforgiving nature was off-putting at first. It seemed like nothing I was doing was happening fast enough to save my city from certain demise. That's when I realized, that's the point of the game. It's supposed to force you to choose the lesser of two evils and challenge your morality in the face of nigh unwinnable odds. The moment you start to think everything's going smoothly, a hundred refugees will turn up on your doorstep and you've gotta either have the infrastructure ready to receive them (and all the problems they will bring with them) or reluctantly turn them away to die in the wasteland. The story and writing are crushingly bleak, as is your outlook if you don't upgrade your coal and generator ASAP. If it gets too frustrating dying during the first cold snap of the game, try it on easy mode to get the hang of things, even on easy you'll find plenty of challenges as you make the toughest calls imaginable trying to find a balance between doing what's right and doing what needs to be done. Oh and the music slaps. 9/10, can't wait for Frostpunk 2!

Frostpunk is an amazing city building survival game that puts you in charge of developing the "last city on earth", from using resources to make buildings to defining the laws that are used throughout the city to ensure the citizens survival. To make it short, Earth has undergone an eternal winter and each day gets colder. You must build the city, which is surrounded by a large heat generator powered by coal, while maintaining the peoples needs and their "Hope" while making their "discontent" as low as possible. Certain actions can raise or lower either, too high discontent or too low hope and it's game over. You start the game with quite literally nothing but a few survivors and scattered resources, as you gather it allows you to start building more things like homes, medical outposts, and coal mines that are essential to maintaining warmth. Sometimes it seems like the people forget they're in a post apocalyptic wasteland and instead thing they're at a 5 star hotel as they'll consistently ask for things like better homes when you have no resources available, easier shifts when longer ones are more important at the moment because you're low on a lot of things. You can decline them for a time before they demand you do something at the cost of increasing discontent significantly should you do nothing. Usually you have a few days to keep your promise made to the people but should you not finish the project, or for whatever reason your people just don't build the damn houses in time it will impact your hope. And then there's the frustrating moment when you have too many buildings but not enough workers.

Despite these frustrating moments within the game, it's really fun and always keeps me coming back as each session you learn something new that you could've done better to ensure your people survive and the next session you survive a little bit longer. I highly recommend it for those that are craving a new challenge to the city building genre, you won't regret it.

Absolutely fantastic city builder, immersive and full of life despite being post apocalyptic. It doesn't hold your hand and you absolutely will fail over and over. But that's the point. Its mean't to be hard. Don't give up if you fail, remember your mistakes and try again!

Some tips in no particular order;
- Keep tabs on your research, try to make sure you're always researching something as soon as the last is done.
- Do the same for laws. 
- Emergency shift is a life saver for research and resource production. Don't abuse it but at the same time, use it where you get the chance, preferably when you have low discontent. 
- Prioritise coal supplies, get coal mining ASAP and eventually have them be automated. 
- Do not ignore heating. Its critical. 
- Try to get the max cap scouts out when possible, this will greatly help you late game and do not forget to use outpost teams, the resources will be valuable.
- you can fast forward gameplay, 1 to default speed, 2 to medium, 3 to fastest. Much nicer using the keybinds. 

Overall amazing game, really enjoyable, its worth getting!

Recommended DLC: 
- On The edge
- The Last Autumn

[h1] Frostpunk [/h1]

Arguably, 11 bit studios' greatest hit. Frostpunk is a fantastically immersive and fun game set in a world where frosts had overtaken the world, and humanity is at the brink of extinction. It is incredibly tense, and every day is a new challenge. Survival is a constant battle for resources, and to be effective one must think several steps ahead and prepare accordingly. 

It's a wonderfully unique game that does an excellent job at immersing you into the world with its visual presentation, music, general atmosphere, and gameplay loop, The gameplay consists of you collecting resources, researching new technology to help fight against the cold, and managing the morale of your people. The whole system runs like a well-oiled machine, and it can be quite unforgiving on higher difficulties. 

Even though there's not a lot to dislike about Frostpunk, there are still some things that it could've done better. The morale mechanic, for example, is not very fully developed, and you don't get any advantage or reward for maintaining high hope and discontent low. It's a missed opportunity to make the game more exciting and rewarding for players. On the same note, the two different governing styles that you get to unlock to help you govern the morale of your people aren't that hot, either. They both play quite similarly to one another, and picking whichever one is akin to choosing a new coat of paint; The only real difference between the two trees is their themes: Faith or Order. But arguably the worst thing about both of them is their final skills, which effectively makes the rest of the skills in their respective tree completely worthless. 

As a piece of advice for all potential Frostpunk buyers out there, don't purchase the game of the year edition. I repeat, do not buy it! There is a reason why each of them is rated so poorly, individually. It lacks effort, doesn't try to offer anything substantially new to the gameplay formula, and it's grossly overpriced for what they are actually offering. Trust me, you are 100% better off not buying the complete edition, The main game, as well as the three free scenarios, are more than enough to keep you busy and entertain. No need to shell out extra money. 

All in all, Frostpunk is a great game. While it may be a bit underdeveloped in some areas, I believe this is the case where the whole game was able to rise and be better than the parts of its sum. I had a wonderful time with Frostpunk, and I wouldn't hesitate even for a second recommending it to people I know.
