An incredibly immersive management game and city builder. Frostpunk is expertly designed, aptly showing that games don't need tons of resource types or building varieties to be engaging. At first I was hesitant to try Frostpunk due to its dark theme and being locked into a circular city design, but it ended up becoming one of my all-time favorite games. The game is bleak, but you will persevere over the brutal elements and lead your city into a new, hopeful future. 

But first, you will fail.

A lot.

This game is a lot of fun. The aesthetic is cool and creative, and the style feels like a cross between managing a Victorian town and managing a moon base. FrostPunk is one of the better city builder/pop management games out there. Living through the storm without losing a soul is a good feeling.

This game is fairly hardcore which can be a plus or minus depending on the person, and the game expects you to quickly grasp the game mechanics in order to be successful. The difficulty settings are unforgiving and the game feels hard even at the default medium setting. The mechanics are not directly explained well but generally adhere to common sense. One of the most important things to know is if you build outside of heat zones you're going to have a really bad time. It's better for your people to be homeless and living near the generator than it is for them to have a home out in the cold, as the pops would apparently rather freeze to death in their homes rather than be warm but homeless. The game is very unforgiving about sending people into the cold, and if you send people to work in the freezing cold they will soon develop frostbite and die pretty much how people would in real life at those temperatures.

In my opinion some of the hazards are a little bit unbalanced especially for new players. It's not unusual for certain hazards to be worse than the storms themselves, and since they are RNG this can feel very frustrating especially at first. However, these features can add to replayability for more experienced or advanced players since the hazards pose a significant challenge.

Overall I'm glad I bought this game and recommend it to fans of survival or city-builder genres.

Brutal and relentlessly unforgiving in the best way imaginable. Frostpunk is a "Survival City Builder" set in a post-apocalyptic ice-age that will kick you in your frostbitten groin simply because it can and you weirdly ask for it to kick you harder. This is an arctic rabbit hole where you can easily sink dozens, if not hundreds of hours into with its addictive gameplay loop and gambling at whether or not you can survive the storm and the plummeting temperature.

Resource management, politics and balancing a dichotomy is a requirement if you plan on surviving the cold.

It's a very well made game, I haven't encountered any bug after 20 hours of playing, the visual is beautiful, and the art is very cool. The main campaign is packed with scripted events and DnD style encounters so there is no RNG involved, but it is nicely done, I was always on my toes and cautious with my first playthrough. It is a city building and resource management game with a snowball Earth / steampunk theme. It has fun aspects. It can be punishingly hard if you want. After playing for a reasonable but not super long amount of time, I have found several bugs. The game also seems poorly optimized; it lags badly the more I build, which seems odd to me for a game that's not doing anything incredible graphics-wise. Attempting to play the game's most casual mode, on the most casual map, just for a fun building experience without any intensity, I encountered a bug where every single night 10-15% of my population would take ill. Regardless of the difficulty settings, or the strategy I chose. Regardless of whether I carefully protected my people with heat or let them freeze. The result was always the same, not just repeatable but inevitable. This is a game-breaking bug, because there is no conceivable way to manage this illness rate: Even if you dedicate your whole educated population to battling sickness and ignore all other things you are supposed to manage, the illness overwhelms the whole settlement after a week or so. I did not experience this particular bug playing through the campaigns, only in the game's sandbox mode (called Endless).

All things considered, the game is entertaining but not containing a ton of content nor breaking any new ground. And for a game supposedly out of early access, it has some really obvious bugs.

Aside of all this their are scripted moments in which your peoples hope will fall drastically, and even if you have homes for everyone, they are fed, warm, and you have only a handful of sick, you will still have them tell you you did a bad job and they will kick you out. GG you freeze to death.

Frostpunk demands a delicate balance between population management, urban development, advantageous research endeavors, overall growth, and resource allocation. Failure to find a healthy balance results in catastrophic consequences.

On top of the classic resource and building mechanics one would expect from this genre, the game includes a surprisingly entertaining research tree and public policy system. Research is not only required, but necessary for success. Players must determine which items to research depending on the weather, desired play style, and need to acquire certain critical in-game resources. 

With a suite of challenging and varied gameplay mechanics, a player should expect - at minimum - 60+ hours of non-repetitive playtime. One game can be roughly 6-10 hours, with another 5 or so replays to try all the mechanics out. This is not including the extra maps and DLC.

The mystique of this city builder - with its brutal consequences, unique building layout, multiple challenges, and gripping story - had me hooked before it was even in my library. I loved the absolutely punishing choices and un-winnable situations your past decisions placed you in. Restarting from scratch and applying new strategies was fun. Loosing was fun. I've played Dwarf Fortress... BTW.

As I drew closer to the most impossible of situations I applied every tactic I could and held firm. The sunlight was approaching, my people were all alive, our morals were unbroken(important), and I was about to see how this games developers handled such a challenging genre blend... 

The sunlight comes. The game faded away. Okay - so there might not be an unlimited play after the main campaign. WORDS! words on the screen! This looks like a recap! Just like the Harvest Moon style games. This is a fantastic way to end the game. The player activities triggers that fill out the variables that make up the end game story cards. This gives the players ownership of what they've achieved. Brilliant!

Or at least it would be if I knew who's game I was reading about. I never did any of this stuff. My rations were all full and hearty. My children went to daycare. My people had warm(mostly) beds and healthcare. What the hell it this end game triggered fromm~oh my God they had no(few) triggers... This is a good/bad ending. These developers had the potential to create a beautiful finale for an epic journey and instead they spat in my face. 

After all that complex & genius design - you fail here... 

Immediately I deleted and hid the game from my library. The only reason I remembered and wrote this review was a "similar to games you've played" list.

[h1]ASKING HARD QUESTIONS[/h1]

	11 bit studios created a madly atmospheric game about survival against all odds. Player takes a role of a leader of one of the last settlements on earth. The Great Frost is coming and you have to prepare for freezing snowstorms. Each playthrough is a race against time, but ever-worsening weather conditions are not your only problem.
	Frostpunk throws a plethora of moral and ethical dilemmas at the player. It asks thought provoking questions and explores themes of power and corruption. This is a though, bleak world, where sometimes it's not possible to make a good choice. 

	Visual design paints a vision of nineteenth century industrial city powered by coal and steam. Soundtrack composed by the great Piotr Musia≈Ç adds depth and meaning to the story. It's just fantastic!

	11 bit studios created a polished title. Gameplay mechanics blend seamlessly with eachother. Frostpunk has it's own identity. Never before, maintaining a digital city was this dramatic and stressful. 
	Various scenarios mixed with great Endless mode provide content lasting for many hours. Frostpunk demands skill, planning and resilience. It's not an easy title by any means. But it's a rewarding experience. 

	I recommend this game.

If you are interested in a full video version of this review then check out my yt channel: https://youtu.be/uswdAYiuIXo

Frostpunk is a survival strategy game set in a frozen post-apocalyptic world where players must manage resources, build a city, and make tough decisions to ensure their citizens' survival. While the game has received critical acclaim for its unique game play and immersive world, it falls short in several key areas that can make it a frustrating and ultimately unsatisfying experience. One of the biggest issues with the game is its lack of replay ability. While there are multiple scenarios to play through, the game play and mechanics quickly become repetitive, making subsequent play through feel like a chore. This can make the game feel stagnant and uninteresting, particularly for players who are looking for a more dynamic and engaging experience. Another issue with the game is its punishing difficulty. The game is designed to be challenging, but it can feel unfair and frustrating at times. It can be difficult to balance resource management, building construction, and citizen needs, and even a small misstep can have devastating consequences. This can make the game feel stressful and overwhelming, particularly for players who are not experienced with the survival strategy genre. The game's story line is also a problem. While the game's premise is intriguing, the story itself can feel disjointed and unsatisfying. The game relies heavily on the player's imagination to fill in the gaps, which can make it feel incomplete and underdeveloped. Finally, the game's interface can be clunky and difficult to navigate, which can make it frustrating to manage and oversee your city's operations. This can lead to mistakes and missteps that can have significant consequences for your citizens' survival.
Frostpunk has some interesting concepts and game play mechanics, but falls short in several key areas that can make it a frustrating and ultimately unsatisfying experience. With its lack of replay ability, punishing difficulty, disjointed story line, and clunky interface, it's difficult to recommend this game to anyone except for the most dedicated fans of the survival strategy genre.

Frostpunk is an incredibly immersive and captivating game that delivers an intense and thrilling experience. Set in a frozen, post-apocalyptic world, the game immediately draws you in with its stunning visuals and hauntingly beautiful music. The setting is unique and brilliantly executed, making you feel as though you are truly living in a harsh and unforgiving world.

The game's main focus is on survival, and it does an exceptional job of making you feel the weight of every decision you make. As you struggle to keep your citizens alive in the face of bitter cold and dwindling resources, the stress and tension are palpable. The game constantly challenges you to make difficult choices that can have serious consequences for your people, and you can actually feel the responsibility for your citizens.

Overall, Frostpunk is an outstanding game that is sure to leave a lasting impression. Its setting, music, and gameplay are all masterfully crafted, and the experience of playing it is truly unforgettable. If you're looking for a game that will test your skills and keep you on the edge of your seat, then Frostpunk is definitely worth checking out.

I sat down and started a Frostpunk game,. Then had a moment and played the game pretty much solidly until I completed the starting scenario at 2 AM.

It's pretty, it's atmospheric, there's a nice (albeit periodically jarring) attempt to create an atmosphere and make you invest in your people's hopes and fears. The challenge - of progressively falling temperatures and refugees from <nonspecific event>, and of managing your people's hopes and fears - is pleasing. Figuring out how to arrange your appropriately polar city is fun. Music's fine (I didn't turn it off) and your scouts venture into the wasteland to discover what seems like a cool story.

So far, so good. There are a few things I outright didn't like: the choices/challenges the AI presents you with are pretty mechanical and independent of context; the tech items cannot be "read" until you're able to research them, making planning ahead difficult; the morality of the game (like D&D) doesn't match the setting; and information is generally scanty, meaning you might well play partly or wholly through your first run just to figure out all the places you went wrong.

That leads on to the game's worst feature, that it is essentially a bounded puzzle with (very) finite choices. I haven't tried the endless mode, but suspect it would be like an inferior version of Timberborn: periodically circumstances become difficult, periodically they relent, you manage. Timberborn, though, isn't final release. I want to play another run or two at the scenario to explore the other laws tree and to try and do a few things I didn't realise were good ideas first time around (like not recognising how crucial your scouts are meant to be), but fundamentally this game has shot its bolt.

Conclusion: worth buying, but only at a steep discount.
Never played a city building game with such intensity and stress. Keeps throwing disasters after existing crisis at the player. What a thrill ride of a lifetime, thank you 11bit.

One of the best city-builders out there. The fluctuating cold is a clever way to keep  you from snowballing like in most city-builders. Things can go wrong very quickly all because the temperature dropped a couple of degrees. Or vice versa, a bad situation can turn around because of rising temperature. Many elements can come together and if one cog falls out of place, it's over. Its a great blend of survival resource management and plenty of hard decisions to make. I recommend reading every popup for decisions, it's great flavor text to keep you immersed in your personal story of running the city. Usually being cruel can make your life easier, but the art of the sad, cold people looking at me makes me think twice a time or two. 

The music is also phenomenal. It really sells the feel of sad Victorian British people just trying to make it out in the frozen wilderness. You got your quartets and strings, everything needed for that turn of the century mood. I don't want to spoil anything if you haven't played this, but "The City Must Survive" is the best track in the game because of it's context alone. 

This game is hard, so keep that in mind when you buy this and don't get discouraged when things don't work out. I flubbed my fair share of scenarios, but I eventually played and beat all of them. You can also change the difficulty before you start a scenario. I only recommend doing this if you cannot get far in the current difficulty. I think the mood of the game is softened when things are too easy. 

I love this game and it's easily in my top 10. I'm pretty upset I haven't played it until now considering this came out almost 5 years ago. If you're thinking of buying this, stop thinking about it and just do it. The expansions are also worth the asking price. The Last Autumn is a close second for best scenario in the game.

FROSTPUNK is a game that literally begs you to institute child labor. It will threaten you with disaster again and again if you don't work people to death. And yet, damn, have I played it a lot.

In the game, you play as the leader of a group of survivors of an unexplained ecological cataclysm, which has resulted in the world freezing over. You order the construction and staffing of the means of production, with the populace providing feedback in the form of demands, and meters of Hope and Discontent. If they get too upset, they'll depose you -- though this has never happened to me. As a leader, systemic problems like supply shortages fall to you, and the game invites you to solve these problems with such innovations as: putting children to work as workers (bad), putting children to work as helpers (good), working people until they drop dead (bad), institutionalizing sex work (bad?), and opening a pub (also bad?). The ethical compass of the game generally suggests that you are the anti-hero whose only redeeming quality is keeping (almost) everyone alive.

I enjoy Frostpunk as a game where I get to say, "Everything is fine, actually." I refuse to proclaim inhumane laws (with the exception of hospital overcrowding, which is flat OP) while meticulously ensuring nobody dies. This involves a great deal of reloading old saves in order to make perfect choices, but it's also the only way I find the game appealing. In a world as dire as the one we live in (outside of the game), it can be a relief to stare tribulation in the face and know with certainty that nobody has to die. Even if we get a little chilly, we will pull through by our collective strength.

I find the alternate playstyle, of watching your settlement fall apart under your ineptitude, to be un-fun precisely because that's the world I navigate day to day. Despite my best efforts, I cannot prevent systematic cruelty; at best, I can abate it for a time for a meager few, while working toward a just transformation of the way of things -- a transformation I have no guarantee I'll live to see. We go to work in the cold and we are told to toil or perish, even under rampant plague and abject privation. I do not need a reminder of it; I do not want to romanticize it. So when Frostpunk begs me to institute child labor, I say no. We all deserve better than that.

Pros (that i can think of, i'm not a pro reviewer)

Cons:

- The outcomes don't feel very heavy hitting. The moral choices don't deliver the intended gut punch because you feel no real attachments to the people you order around. The game should have humanized the player by giving The Captain character an actual story arc, a face and a personality

Frost punk is a game that challenges you to survive in a frozen world where society is on the brink of collapse. You have to manage your resources, make tough decisions and deal with the consequences. The game is very immersive and atmospheric, with stunning graphics and sound effects. The gameplay is also very engaging and rewarding, as you see your city grow and adapt to the harsh conditions. Frost punk is not for the faint of heart, though. It can be very stressful and depressing at times, as you face moral dilemmas and sacrifices. If you like games that test your skills and emotions, frost punk is a great choice.

FrostPunk is hands down one of the best games I have ever played. From the moment I started the game, I was captivated by the post-apocalyptic world and the challenging gameplay. The attention to detail in the graphics and sound design is truly impressive, making the game incredibly immersive. FrostPunk is an exceptional game that truly stands out in the strategy and city-building genres. From the immersive post-apocalyptic world to the challenging gameplay, FrostPunk is a game that will keep you engaged for hours on end.

One of the things I love about FrostPunk is the way it presents you with difficult decisions that have a real impact on the survival of your city. Every choice you make, no matter how small, can have consequences that ripple throughout the game. Some decisions present moral dilemmas that offer interesting choices without directly impacting the city's survival, while others can completely change the course of the game.

The graphics and sound design in FrostPunk are top-notch, immersing you in the game's atmosphere and making you feel like you're really in control of the fate of your city. The gameplay is both strategic and thought-provoking, requiring you to constantly balance resources, technology, and the needs of your citizens to ensure their survival.

Overall, I would highly recommend FrostPunk to anyone who enjoys strategy games or city-building games. It's a great game that presents you with meaningful decision-making and impactful gameplay, and I thoroughly enjoyed playing it.

The situation is grim. The world as you know it is gone, hell has frozen over.
You have but a handful of people to build a city for you, and to bring in the resources you need for their survival. Will you try to be a compassionate leader, or will you put even the children to work 14 hours a day as a last ditch measure of desperation to keep that Generator going?
The fate of your people is in your hands, and every decision you make has immediate and longterm consequences, for better or for worse. So pick the path you descend on very carefully.

You will really need to strategize and prioritize as you just never seem to have enough workforce to keep everything flowing at the rate you need it. And when you thought it couldn't get any worse, beware as the temperature is about to drop significantly in a couple of days, better get the next generator power level researched at all cost before we all freeze over. Oh and make sure your coal production can sustain the next power level too. And try also not to starve, nor overwork your people to death in the meantime. Then just when you thought the worst of it was over, the story f*cks you over for good measure.
You'll be kept constantly on edge as you try to manage the flow of resources made possible by the very people you're trying to prevent from falling sick or worse, freezing to death, all while having to respond to emergencies and social unrest if you're not careful.

I find the setting, the story and the whole ambiance really immersive, and the OST is a masterpiece, it really conveys the feeling of utter desperation, of real struggle with all odds stacked against, of desolation and loneliness, of barely holding on. It's sad but really beautiful, and can really get you deep into it especially as a roleplay-oriented person.
Great story

Where to begin on this game. Well, to start I believe that this game has placed a few scars on me is fair to say. The game is fantastic, looks beautiful, and most of all holds a very simple premise that is locked behind a dozen roadblocks that keep that premise from being easy to achieve, This game is not for those who want an easy experience to sit down and enjoy casually. Frostpunk is a bleak punishing Sim colony builder. There are 4 campaign scenarios that play out differently while generally giving you access to all the same buildings. Until the late game, you will be struggling to maintain a good balance on resource gathering, building up your city, and keeping it heated. The positive to this struggle means that almost all the technology upgrade choices are good and many seem prudent. You will often catch yourself stuck between a tough choice of 2-5 different techs each time you go to upgrade for most of a scenario.

The biggest issue with this is that 2 or 3 of the scenarios have major (or seemingly minor) scripted events that occur that can completely screw you over. Since you have no clue what these are going to be the first time through a scenario, they can keep you from getting the best possible outcomes or even cause a cascade to failure. This means you typically need to make a hard save backup once every 3 or 4 days, otherwise enjoy getting royally screwed through no fault of your own since you had no way to predict what was going to be coming.

Great city-building-game with a fun twist. I get really engaged in how the people of my city trive. After eight hours I still wonder how many twists this game will bring.

Difficulty level is challenging on normal level, as it should be. 
Easier difficulty would be less interesting to play. 
The game's athmosphere is very well done and the level of difficulty is perfectly right for what the game aims for: 
You get really immersed into the menace of the frost and feel the pressure to survive, while there still is some room for moral decisions.

I managed to survive the final storm in a new home on the first try, as it was quite clear what measures and actions could lead to survival. But to do so, the workers had to do 24h shifts in mines and farms, while regular public executions kept down the level of unrest, the sick were triaged and then used as fertilizer, and "volunteers" had to sacrifice their lifes to maintain coal production, as the alternative would have been a reduced heating radius and people freezing to death. 

Was it worth it? Thats a good question, and it was presented in the end after surving. There had been many decisions, what difference could it had made, to take different ones? If you see the game, the sick, the unrest, the dead just as a system of numbers and survival as goal, or if you consider a totalitarian dictorship by you as ideal, the question might be easier to answer than if you try to survive while maintaining humanitarian values.

And then it hits: It is a fictional scenario, but clearly an allegory to the real world. When you learn history about Soviet Union during world war 2 and how they defended against the aggression, which sacrifices were made and what did society was like afterwards, some parallels are obvious.
The question is still highly relevant today: We still live with the menace of societies wiped out through cruel war. What means are appropriate for defense?

So I'm only about 10 hrs into my first playthrough and it is an extremely engaging city builder/survival game so far. There's quite a bit of depth to the gameplay but decisions are really where the game shines. You've only got so many working hours in a day so your supply of resources is limited which means the choices you make have to be carefully considered. It simply isn't possible to buy, build and research everything you want so you have to make sacrifices. There's a balance that needs to be achieved between short and long-term goals and if you skew too heavily one way, you'll be punished pretty severely

Deadly temperatures will be the constant element you'll be battling as you try to survive the brutal global winter conditions and figure out what happened to the others who fled the cities

Fulfilling and delightful :-)  After 5 days and having kept me awake for a 35 hrs period without sleeping, I completed the main survival campaign. And without overusing the "cruel" "survival" options, trying always to do the "ethical" thing...

The "New Home" plot felt to me fresh and the different-than-usual. City-building-survival setting is something I really enjoyed, since for many months now I am playing good games, but that all feel like I have played something similar before... That was not the case with Frostpunk :-)

On finishing the campaign, I am feeling complete with a warm feeling of accomplishment: I am feeling like having overcome interesting, hard, cruel, but fair game challenges... And on top of the expansions, there is a "endless" mode that I hope will let me keep upgrading my city to the high pick :-)  

All in all, the game definitely was worthing my time and money.

Rarely in my many years of gaming have I encountered one that so completely monopolized my attention.  I daresay I fired more neurons beating the main scenario than Einstein fired figuring out relativity.  Which is not to say the game is all that complicated, it's just that engaging.

The game-play is solid and satisfying survival/base building with the amp turned up to eleven.  The pressure to stay ahead of events is relentless, eventually building to a stunning crescendo that leaves you bracing for the inevitable death blow - which you must also somehow survive.  Every decision counts, and counts alot.

The story is very good and well-written, both supporting the game-play and adding a social and political dimension that directly impacts your chances of survival.  

The art is steam punk-cool, beautiful and imminently immersive.  The music, sublime.  A hauntingly beautiful and masterful composition, it manages to unobtrusively weave itself through your consciousness and pull you deep into the frozen world the game creates.

Frostpunk is a great game and a complete experience that has me looking forward to a second playthrough, the DLC scenarios and, of course, Frostpunk II.  

Get it.  You'll be glad you did.

One of the standout features of Frostpunk is its innovative mechanics. The game challenges you to balance multiple factors at once, such as temperature, resource management, and the happiness of your citizens. This forces you to make tough decisions and think strategically, as even the smallest mistake can have dire consequences.

But despite its challenging gameplay, Frostpunk is an incredibly rewarding experience. As you progress through the game, you'll be able to research new technologies, construct new buildings, and upgrade your society. And as your city grows, so too will your sense of accomplishment.

Another impressive aspect of Frostpunk is its city-building mechanics. The game allows you to construct a wide variety of structures, from steam-powered generators to hunting huts, all of which are essential to the survival of your society. Each building has its own unique function, and you'll need to carefully consider which structures to prioritize in order to succeed.

But Frostpunk isn't just about building a city ‚Äì it's also about managing the people who live there. The game features a deep and immersive citizen management system, which allows you to assign jobs, pass laws, and even execute criminals. This adds an additional layer of complexity to the gameplay, and ensures that you're always engaged and invested in the fate of your society.

In conclusion, Frostpunk is a masterpiece of a city-building game that is sure to captivate anyone who enjoys strategy games. With its innovative mechanics, engaging gameplay, and immersive world-building, Frostpunk is a must-play for anyone who loves a good challenge.

First of all, I'm not an english speaker so I apologize for any following error.
There is no word to describe this game if not "beautiful": it's graphically beautiful, the soundtrack is chillingly (pun intended) beautiful, the gameplay is pretty unique and the lore is very original.

I won't explain the premises because you can read them above, so let's focus on the game itself.
It kinda starts out as a normal city builder, with an original circular simmetry, because you must build around the big central generator, which provides heat (in exchange for coal) for all the colony. Heat is indeed a resource of its own, and you'll have to manage it well. It could have been nice to have a couple more "advanced" resources (for example: where do these people take the clothes to cover themselves? There's an ice age outside) but the game can be very challenging managing the ones you have, so it's ok anyway. Two "resources" unique to this game are your people's hope and discontent: in order to manage them (but not only for that), you'll have to sign laws, which can also have you face preatty big moral decisions, spanning from legalizing child labour to instituting care houses for the amputees.
Finally, you'll also be able to scout the sorrounding frostland for resources and lore.

To sum up, this game can be a very challenging and rewarding experience (it also has an "easy" option don't worry), perfect for any strategy/city builder fan. Can also be good for someone who's not a fan of the genre, if he is without prejudices.
The price for the main title is definitely right, while some dlcs may be a little overpriced (but I don't own them so don't trust me on this (planning on buying them anyway)), nothing that steam sales can't fix.

The only downside is that devs decided to stop adding new content, which is really a shame because Frostpunk had so much more to tell, from scenarios to game modes and mechanics. Sorry if I've written too much =)

The mechanic behind "babysitting" that big heater, can be really frustrating.
If you forget to turn off overdrive, you lose the game and kind of have to start again (or get thrown back to your last autosave which cost you a few minutes of gametime...)

I think it was a really bad decision from the devs to handle things like they did.. it feels like they just wanted to extend playtime for this game by making you lose it, in such a stupid way (i.e. you pause the game, build some stuff, release a policy, check on your scouts, then you speed up time in game, but forgot that you still running overdrive, boom, game over)

i like the difficult and challenging economic decisions one has to make in this game and ofc the connected outcomes, but the overdrive mechanic can tilt you quite fast. early to mid to end game feels quite similar in every playthrough and its just really frustrating to start from your last autosave, just because you forgot to switch off a controller after zapping through a lot of sheets and menues....

still a thumbs up for the discounted version

For those of you who enjoy both rogue lights and colony sims? This game is definitely for you. If you enjoy random, nonsensical events that neither make any logical sense nor give you any degree of control over them, ending your colony at any given moment? This game is definitely for you. As an example. One playthrough, on Serenity mode, saw an incoming storm bottom out the hope meter and get me evicted, thus ending my game. Despite the fact that there was no threat from the storm as I had adequately prepared with various heaters. On another playthrough? I had just enacted emergency shifts and enabled them at my workshops. One of my engineers 'died from overwork'. Funny thing is? The guy hadn't even finished a NORMAL shift before doing so. I'm uninstalling the game after I finish this review, and I'm glad I purchased this on sale. I am an unlucky individual as a rule, so I can't play games where RNG rules with an iron fist because I will lose, through no fault of my own, often times before I even really get rolling. Devs who do this kind of thing? Should really tag their games as such when releasing them.

To call this game a "city-builder," while technically correct, is a bit misleading. This is more of a highly interactive story (several stories, actually, since each scenario & DLC are their story within a larger context) with gorgeous artwork and mesmerizing soundtrack. The story itself is set in an apocalyptic and steampunk past (Victorian era, because, well, "steampunk") and it has a beautiful tragic air with a hopeful flourish. The world lore is also enshrouded in mystery, and while never fully revealed, a lot of the fun is discovering the backstory to this world. I think replayablity is moderate to high for those who enjoy immersing themselves into this world, less so for those more interested in the gameplay mechanics and "beating the game."
Bleak, sure, but might be the coziest warm blanket you've ever felt. Sumptuous. It's ASMR for your whole face.

Holy shit -- I never imagined an RTS could have me tensed up like this. But the final hours of the storm had me totally stressed and glued to the screen until the sun finally rose again. And as the the time laps started to roll and the words "New London, 630 inhabitants, -30¬∞C" appeared, I could finally relax again.

So far, I've only completed the "A New Home" campaign, but that has been one of the best city-building RTS experiences I've ever had. To me, this game is truly one of a kind. 
I'm now looking forward to completing the remaining campaigns and I can only recommend it.

I picked up Frostpunk on one of the coldest nights of the year. Even so, I am convinced my experience would have been just the same had I started playing on a summer afternoon. The atmosphere of this game is absolutely stunning. Frostpunk sets the stage in a way I would otherwise think impossible for a story so brutal you will find yourself shivering by the end. I recently saw this game mentioned in Jacob Geller's "Fear of Cold" and he describes the idea better than I ever could: cold is not something that can be conquered. All you can possibly hope to do is survive it ‚Äî to stave off its icy grip until, maybe, something warmer comes to fill that frozen void. Frostpunk encompasses this perfectly. Whether you like it or not, the cold will come. You may wish, plead, or bargain, but the cold will come. When it comes, if you are not ready, you will die.

Beyond the breathtaking visuals, novel concept, and unique mechanics, Frostpunk is built to offer endless replay value. Every city will have a uniquely harrowing story, recounted to you at the end of your struggles. This game also presents a challenge that many will find tantalizing. You will have to make difficult, sometimes heartbreaking decisions. You will suffer losses. You will wish you could go back. Unfortunately for you, the cold's advance halts for no one. Frostpunk is a tragedy of the struggle between efficiency, morality, and harsh, cruel reality. As your city branches out like the snowflakes adorning the fallen, you will be forced to ask time and time again whether your actions are worth the anguish.

Hands down, Frostpunk is one of the best games I have ever played. It is a grueling endeavor woven into a beautifully sorrowful tale, and an experience unlike any other.

[h1][u]I mean, it's ok, It's just kind of boring once you've done it once or twice.
[/u][/h1]
The same buildings. The same problems. The same pictures. The same incredibly small linear tree of "laws" that end up making every game identical after you have chosen either 'facism' or 'religion'.
No workshop content, the DLC's are the exact same in premise with a few little quirky changes. 
If you could Steam workshop mod it, if there was more proggresion and variation in gameplay (excluding difficulty and map choice) 

Maybe i just don't get it, but from the outside perspective of someone who doesn't really give a fuck about the lore and creation of the game, just someone who wants a banging colony sim [b]first[/b] and then a rich universe to explore afterwards... This game feels a lil backwards? 
Audio and music for purchase, artwork, backstory, anecdotes, trinkets and doodads from lost explorers, "about the world". All of these aspects seem so incredibly fleshed out while the game itself is rather lacking.

Its like they really want to shove in your face:
[b]"Look! Look! Isn't this cool? Isn't this a cool story we've made? Come on! Buy some artwork! Buy some of the audio you can hear for free on youtube and in game! Why don't you support us so we can keep making Frostpunk better!... Actually add some replay value into the game?... Uhm... I-.... Ermh... Here's a Q&A about the frostpunk lore instead!"
[/b]

[i]You want a great colony building game with near endless progression and massively variating game-play?
[/i]
[b]Go play Rimworld.
[/b]
[i]You want a great story driven game with deep, DEEP lore showing off a world in a post-apoclyptic never-ending winter?
[/i]
[b]Go play the Metro series.
[/b]
[i]You want a mediocre colony builder with a mediocre steampunk story set in a single visible area?
[/i]
[b]Go play Frostpunk

[/b]

Very Immersive. It can take a while to learn how to strategies your decisions. Expect to play through the story a few times just to familiarise yourself with the dangerous consequences of your actions.

Frostpunk is the sort of game you can play at any time of the year and any time of the day. The many ways to build your society to survive along with all the challenges makes it a chillingly refreshing City builder survival game. Despite having played it since its release, I keep coming back for more. The difficulty curve is nice and smooth and you can easily sense it steady rising depending on the gameplay you choose. the Learning curve as well is simple and easy and it wont take long before you build a metropolis within a frozen over world. That at least is my positive side of the review.

Personally, while I love all the game has to offer, even its endless mode, I will say that there is a severe lack of updates and content to keep the player base engaged and wanting for checkup. I would love to see them come with new content, or challenges instead of letting it gather dust while they finish making the sequal. I am not expecting something big, personally. Just enough to keep people in the loop and having fun.

All in all, if you are looking for several hours of fun and a fetching story about the end and possible rebirth of the world and humanity after an iceage cataclysm, I warmly recommend this game.

This is still one of my favorite strategy games.
The Ark and the Last Autumn scenario's are my favorite ones.
I don't know any other strategy game that does ethics this well.
The game will maneuver you into scenario's where you are forced to choose 1 of 2 evils, and the consequence will follow you through that entire game. This gives this game excellent replay-ability, you can play the game again and try a different route, or throw your ethics out of the window and build a penal colony.

The idea is great too, building circular around a gigantic generator where everyone's huddled up for warmth in an ice-age world.

The challenges are also that - challenges. Survivor mode is incredibly tough to beat, and makes you revisit the way you play the game - often by having to pick Laws that don't make your people very happy.

I wholeheartedly recommend picking this game up to anyone, especially if it's on sale, this game is worth every penny.

I'm honestly surprised this game doesn't have overwhelmingly positive status somehow.

Frostpunk is a game about what humans do and how they react to the extremes, I feel. The world has frozen over, almost everything is just snow and ice for as far as the eyes can see. We must survive, and we must band together to do so. But people are, at the end of the day, people. Human. We panic, we lost hope. We fight. And we must ask ourselves, sometimes, is survival at any cost worth it? If human life is sacred at this point, should we really descent into methods that allow us to control almost every aspect of another person's life just to survive?

There's several scenarios, some of them free and some of them paid, for you to playthrough. You won't unlock them until you get far enough in the Main Scenario, A New Home; You'll assume the role of the Captain of a convoy or transport of sorts. You lost many, but you arrived. And no one else is here. Despite the odds, you'll have to make it. You'll have to keep people happy. And if not, either you, the city, or both will perish.
And there's no rolling back laws, either. Once you sign off on something, that's it. So pick the laws wisely.. or save often. Save often in general if you're not good (like me.)

I don't wanna spoil much, so I'll keep the review light. But if you do want my advice... I like to use Charcoal Kilns early on after I get the wall drills in the main scenario. Scout south, too. Be ready to take on new people, but get to steel bridge as fast as you can. You'll want whats there, and you'll want to send it home. Trust me.
And once you have the coal, use Steam Hubs to heat smaller circles outside of the generator's influence. 
If you do play this game, I wish 'ye good luck, I hope you have fun, and I hope my advice helps you. <3

[h1]Pray you make it through the storm[/h1]
This is a great atmospheric city builder set in a brutal environment. Great soundtrack and visuals to immerse you into the world. Hours of gameplay working on optimising base layout, tech tree prioritising and law selection. A good post apocalyptic city builder game worth playing. With biggest issue is that its too short.
Its a good game and the scenarios are all quite varied and interesting. These can be quite additive to play but one of my most greatest issues is that there really need to be more scenarios and longer ones.

As a city builder game its quite unique and different from other city builders as your building around a heat source (part of the post apocalyptic theme) with a weird circular build area which is quite unique to most city builders.
It can be quite additictive to play and also challenging with many routes to failure. 
My main issues besides it being not long enough is water is never considered in a game about survival and many other resources aren't considered. It tends to be quite simple in that respect. This hurts long term play-ability in the endless mode, which i've never finished mostly because it got to boring....

But overall a good game!

[h1]A Sandbox for Sociopaths[/h1]

The conceit for survival colony sims in general is building something out of nothing; is recovering and rebuilding a city, a nation, a civilization; is striving against the darkest impulses. 

The copy for [i]Frostpunk[/i] positions it squarely in line with its peer games: [i]It is your duty to manage both its citizens and infrastructure. What decisions will you make to ensure your society's survival? What will you do when pushed to breaking point? Who will you become in the process?[/i]

In the face of such challenges, many games adopt a ‚Äúdarkest-before-dawn‚Äù mentality: that is, challenges must be overcome to mold a better tomorrow. [i]I Was a Teenage Exocolonist[/i] and [i]Spiritfarer[/i] embrace this conceit with grace, as does a game like [i]Beacon Pines[/i] (though not a sim in any respect). [i]Before We Leave[/i], heck, even [i]Don‚Äôt Starve[/i], [i]Rimworld[/i], and [i]Stellaris[/i] offer players roleplaying choice. [i]Frostpunk[/i], on the other hand, adopts a ‚Äúdarker and darker and darkest‚Äù mentality where even the best of binary bad choices is despicable.

The signs are there early: To unlock entertainment ‚Äì and a literal bar/restaurant ‚Äì you need to unlock pit fighting first. What?!? Why?!? How about no?!? And that‚Äôs only a starting point. 

Thereafter, the classic [i]Frostpunk[/i] scenario enforces a binary choice: Will you embrace religious zealotry and militarily-enforced theocracy, or will you embrace rigid authoritarianism? How about neither, please?!!?! 

Having ‚Äúfun‚Äù with [i]Frostpunk[/i] means leaning into such abominable choices and suspending idealism on the one hand ‚Äì and any roleplaying agency on the other ‚Äì in carbonite. 

My vitriolic reaction to this game may very well indicate to some readers that [i]Frostpunk[/i] has accomplished what it set out to achieve; I would argue that this aim itself is ignominious. 

Avoid this game. I wish I could refund it.

RATING: 9 - Moral Decline is just an Opinion.

Quite Addictive. High Replay Value. Insane Frost Mechanics. Hard Choices... 
It's a city builder with a sort of management system that really takes it all in a different direction... 

Firstly it's disguised in a Steam Punk world, that's undergoing serious Frost Issues. Heat is Expensive and your peoples are dying from Frost Bite. Secondly your Morality will be put to the test... and of course... then you're just managing your own Moral decline... and Thirdly the element of Leveling, Discovering and Feeling serious regrets for Choices and Actions grounds this game so well.

My only Advice is, don't load up a previous save. Grow some ovaries, and keep going.
It's worth it. Don't worry, you'll be able to replay the game and try different things...
GOOD LUCK. You WILL need it.

This game is brutal and I love it!

- Don't expect the default difficulty to give first time players an easy time.
- Don't expect to play this game thinking you know what's best. 
- Don't expect to feel good about your choices.
- Don't expect the game to get easier.
- Don't expect happy endings.

- Expect to hate yourself for making bad decisions each time, even though you think you know what is best.
- Expect the game to hate you no matter how hard you try, but you keep going back for more.
- Expect to make morally difficult choices that fill you with guilt and regret.
- Expect to appreciate the levels of realism this game has to offer..
- Expect tears... Whether you win or lose.

Yeah it's really good.
I do have problems with it:
1) There absolutely is a meta-strategy. Game is honestly easy (on Normal) once you figure out what sequence to discover new technology, what sequence to build etc.
2) The morality system is a joke. The game considers your survival to possibly be a bad thing if you have guards and print pamphlets saying everything will be fine. Meanwhile the game is more than happy with you bribing people with food and brainwashing through religion.
3) The game markets itself as being about 'making hard choices' or how choices have 'long-lasting consequences'. It does not. Pick the "good" choice and you get good-boy points.
I expected a choice of needing to send a kid to its death by having it climb inside the Generator, getting incinerator in the process. But no. Just "should you give a kid two doses of food?"

I know, I know, so fascinating, but it's such a heavy game, right? Lots of morally grey choices you [i]have[/i] to make, right? Isn't it kind of depressing? This game has a certain rep, but you really can play as a [b]good guy[/b] and god bless autosave. 

If you want to just play around, no stress? You can do that! They created a freeplay mode years ago, play on easy and I guarantee you will be drowning in resources to do whatever you like (there are harder modes too). 

Freeplay has the 'benefit' of no story, but the plotlines... It's a complex human drama about a really bad situation, but its not some dirge on how much humanity sucks. Being the good guy is harder, but very often the game will reward you for it. You really don't need to use child labor to succeed (seriously, it's objectively the worse of the two options they give). 

It can be a bit intense when a scenario has gotten a bit out of hand and your balancing the basic survival needs with dealing with a crisis. But with increased experience you get a handle for things (took me about a week or two). Just remember that pause is your friend, and whenever the generator blows, you can just start up like it never happened from the autosave (just remember to turn overdrive off when you load it).

~~~
And on the bright side, all this incessant coal burning their doing aught to warm up the climate sooner or later. They have a lot of buffer space, I'm sure they'll have at least a century of time to figure out how to transfer from steampunk to solarpunk.

Great game, challenging, but not hard. Fun, and heart wrenching. 

This game is a building/resource race against the ever colder frost. The world has been plunged into an Ice Age. And you are the leader of a small group of survivors. As the leader, you manage everything from: food, housing, medical, industrial, resource, research, law, refugees, expansion, scouts, and games and recreation. But who for? The People. The people are of course, the heart and soul of this game. 
Every choice you make will cause and affect the population's Hope and Discontent. And every choice brings you a narrative, your story, shaping the lives of your people as you make the gut-turning choices that sully your hands. 

Advice: 
Your first few playthroughs will be long, so take the time to learn and plan out the best thing to do. Since a big factor in this game is resource management. And trust me, you do not want to be caught with your pants down on resources by the end of the game. Aim for a net positive, but most importantly, stockpiling. For new players with a lack of experience, you'll be making poor choices in regard to resource management. So just pause the timer in-game, read the descriptions and options of buildings/icons and learn. Figure out what you need, what can wait, and what will screw or save you in the long run. The rest is in the tutorial.

The game looks fairly pretty, and it's pretty engaging for the first few hours of gameplay, but after that it turns into a grind. First, there's not really anything that you can do to raise your peoples' hope, even if you've got discontent minimized. Maybe it's rigged, for the big mid-game event where half your pop will leave? A large part of the research tree is so late that it's useless, since you already either got outposts getting more resources, or have spent more in research costs or initial building costs that getting the "cheaper whatever" researches would not help. I was overflowing with spare people, so exploring and manning all the stations was trivial. It's hard at the beginning, but by the time I uninstalled, I was just forgetting to build more things, rather than solving interesting challenges. If you want a game just for the graphics, you shouldn't have a laptop, or have a beefy one, since this game runs somewhat poorly otherwise.

Frostpunk is an outstanding single-player game, the addition of a multiplayer mode would make it even more thrilling. Being able to trade resources and cooperate with friends to build and manage a society in a harsh and unforgiving world would bring a new level of excitement to the game.

Having the ability to interact and compete with other players would bring a fresh dynamic to the game and would offer players a new challenge. It would also give players the opportunity to learn from one another and discover new strategies for survival.

In short, the inclusion of a multiplayer mode would add a new dimension to Frostpunk and would make it an even more enjoyable and engaging experience. Hopefully, the developers will consider this feature in the future, as it would be a great addition to an already fantastic game.

The game feels very polished and balanced. The difficulty was just right for me from the main campaign over the first two scenarios up to the winterhome scenario which is the hardest of them by far.
I also played the last autumn DLC, which I reviewed seperately (recommended imo, even though a bit easy on "normal" if you played winterhome before).

It's easy to get lost in time while playing this game and you can choose many ways to engage with most situations. There is a lot of strategizing, especially with the different laws and technologies you can unlock.

One thing I want to name specifically that made the game way more fun and approachable was the refund on destroying buildings. This makes just growing your city and changing things later a blessing. If you destroy a building you get roughly 80% of the materials back and 100% of the rare materials (steam cores). Many times I just started building the city and later on moved quite a few buildings to optimize when I knew what I really needed and where.

This is by far one of the best games I have ever played.  Although difficult (even on the easiest settings) this game keeps drawing me back for one more play through.  The main story is very compelling and every decision you make feels like it has an impact on the events that happen later on.  In fact, some decisions you make will have some minor effects on the ending.

The extra stories and DLC are also very fun and interesting.  Every story is unique and tells a different tale to further add to the lore and intrigue of the world.  Each story also has their own unique game play mechanic to keeps things fresh.  This is definitely one of the few games I would recommend buying DLC for.

If there is one thing that bothers me, however, is there is one mechanic in the game that feels rather terrible.  As part of the scouting mechanic, there are certain encounters that become a pass/fail that could kill your scouts and set you back within that play through.  The only way around is to "save scum" and try again.  There are a only a couple other examples of this kind of mechanic, but they don't usually make you do a 50/50 forced decision and have some other way to circumvent the problem.  Hopefully in the sequel they will find a way around this because this is the only major problem I have with this game.

TL;DR: This game is a masterpiece and you should definitely buy along with all the DLC.

My only delay in purchasing this brilliant work was my abject poverty and being forced to wait for your promotional sales to coincide with actual money in my PayPal.  My first game was Might and Magic III on Apple Performa 400 in 1993.  It had only fax capability and couldn't get on dial up even updated to the maximum 10MB. Frostpunk is an urban planning survival game. It is similar to RTS games like Starcraft & Age of Empires featuring a resource management side of things but the similarities stop there. Unlike the previous 2 games, the only enemy you fight against is time & nature which can make this game harder to master for some people. If you are a seasoned veteran of RTS games & wanted a new challenge other than beating up the AI all day, this is the game for you!

I completely recommend this game. The story and back lore is very well done. There are many options for replay and many choices in each scenario. The achievements also add an extra challenge for replay. I am still working on these achievements and a bit terrified of the iron man ones. As I said, a challenge. Very atmospheric game where your choices matter a lot. You cannot please everyone and you must carefully consider where and when you spend your resources. Compromise can often be a good choice. Resources are scarce and there is not enough of them in the pit - you must venture out of its safety to get lumber and other things. Do not get content, and do not waste time - use pause to plan and build. You have a limited space and you must consider where you place your buildings and how you lay out your roads. It can be very frustrating at times, especially in the beginning, but worry not because if you are patient, you'll learn the things that matter and in the end you may find yourself content, running a well oiled, efficient machine that can handle anything.

The game will keep you on your toes and you must accept that there will be some setbacks. You can't win everything, you just have to survive. This is a true strategy game about base building, resource management and also a bit about leadership and responsibility. The soundtrack is superb and the world feels just as grim as it looks.

Frostpunk might not be a big AAA title but its quality surpasses many of those. It presents unique ideas and it certainly is one of the greatest strategy games ever made.

Too many variables. I knew the game was hard, designed to be very difficult. But 'difficult' is when strategy and skill are combined with the players knowledge to overcome challenges and feel rewarded. Difficult is NOT a series of quests you must complete where the variables are all out of your hands. After 6 trials I finally began to understand the game and the priority of building/actions/etc. I got my scout party up and kept resources managed as I heated houses, etc. The quests start coming... Heat houses. Did that. Oh wait nope, you didn't. Doesn't explain why, just says 'liveable' all houses are heated and 75% of the population lives in a bunkhouse. That's fine its alright. Then the first real storyline quest starts, The Londoners. People wanna leave and you need to convince people to stay. Except nothing you do has a positive effect. Give people what they want, they just don't get angry. They don't get happier though, just not angry. Then back to back to back quests to build an infirmary. Level 3 tech. 4 carehouses and 5 med bays didn't matter. So I research level 3, giving up other quest and making people angry so I can build this building. Except I can't, because it needs steam cores. You can't make those. You acquire them randomly as you explore, which takes between 24-72 hours. The quest is 24 hours long. So even if you find one, it doesn't matter. Random quests generating and random loot chance isn't 'difficult'. Its the opposite of fun. It sucks hard because I was super engaged and the game was seriously great until I reached this point twice and couldn't progress. I haven't even discoverd another settlement, which means the game really hasn't even started. I mean I have 9 hours. Cmon. If a developer somehow reads this I would love a response.

Mechanics are absolutely solid and everything you'd want from a colony sim game like this.
But the main standout is the *atmosphere*. I've never seen anything make so well an impression of an apocalypse as this. Very well worth a play, provided you have the patience for this genre. Alternately, if it's your first shot at the genre, you can hardly do better than this

O.k. A tough one this, took a few hrs to grow on me. 
 I've the base game, from the steam sale for 6¬£.

 I'll start by saying that the 'normal' mode on this is pretty savage & unforgiving if you're new to the game. This game is way less forgiving than others like it, there's a very particular order to build & r&d that if you get wrong then thats-it ! And the tutorial is hardly worth the name lmao.

 The 'easy' setting is still pretty challenging in the 'mission' based scenarios, if a little forgiving.. a good introduction to the game I.m.o. 
  I've not played 'perpetual' mode as yet, more interested in the little narrative stories of the scenarios. 

 There's no real song & dance for finishing a 'mission', an animation montage of your games  base-building at the end & a little text is all. And there's nothing to state Complete for a mission/scenario, only the Steam Achievements.  I'd feel better if there was a proper Slap On The Back moment at the end of a successful run & the 'mission' listed as complete. 

Oh, and be prepared for a good 30%+ of your game time to be reloads, until you get used to it.

For such a small download it's pretty card intensive, on my RTX 3070 TI it is anyway. Have had some stutters where I'd thought it might crash, but luckily it didn't.

In the end I didn't go back to this title. I still think I got my ¬£ worth from the very low sale price though. It's ultimately variations of the same thing through this game. Once the shine wears off, from how nice it looks, then you'll likely feel the same.

I recommend it if you like strategy. You exist in a small circle and gather resources and research technology in order to have an efficient economy for survival. You eventually branch out and explore by deploying scouts to the surrounding area. At first it doesn't feel like real-time strategy because you can survive at a nice casual pace, but after you die a couple times you realize you need to do upgrades much sooner in the game. There's also a political element in which you make decisions about how to deal with the behavior of the citizens and what sort of governing styles you want to go with, having different strengths and weaknesses as trade-offs.
The game is visually pleasant, although not a ton of detail - similar to your Age of Empires type games. It's basically similar to an AoE type RTS but without fighting and in that regard without a dynamic opposition (you're battling prescribed weather patterns and scarcity, not an intelligent/variable opponent). The cut-scenes/audio are good. I also have yet to beat it at over 50 hrs and there are other scenarios etc available, so you'll get plenty of play time; even if you're an expert it still takes quite a long time to get through - in that regard it's different from an Age of Empires/Mythology match that might last 1 or 2 hours, I'd say it's like 5-10 hours to get through a scenario (TBD). This game makes me look forward to Frostpunk 2!

I just wanted to address one particular negative review, which had something along the lines of "shit happens that you can't possibly foresee that will cause you to fail, and you have to restart over and over again getting one bullshit event further each time". This is a hard paraphrase because I haven't looked at it in a couple weeks.

My 2 cents is, the first time I played through this game I completed it. It felt like I was behind literally the entire time, but in the end I pulled it off. I think this is the games greatest strength.
This game is about perseverance in the face of overwhelming odds, and in my opinion it's balanced extremely well against that. If something isn't working you generally have enough time to pivot, and even though it can feel like everything is falling apart for most of the game, there are ways to pull through.

My one tip to new players: Just because certain things are off cooldown and available to be clicked doesn't mean it's a good choice. The game has a habit of serving you up 2 bad options and forcing you to choose, a lot of people have issues with elements of this. For better or worse, the game railroads you towards it's final destination. 
But you don't ALWAYS have to make choices as soon as they are available. Sometimes it is best to wait and see.

Fun and challenging singleplayer strategy game. You can and will lose missions especially in the beginning. Figuring out what you did wrong and improving until you finally beat the mission makes Frostpunk very rewarding. Frostpunk is played in real-time with a pause available, which makes the gameplay active and dangerous situations hectic. 

I did 2 playthroughs and actually enjoyed the game much more on 2nd playthrough on hard difficulty, where your choices have more impact and you have a better understanding of the game. Frostpunk is definitely designed with replayability in mind. You are encouraged to try different approaches to solving problems and finding your own style.

I liked the stories in each mission and the different choices you can make in each story. This also gave the missions a proper ending and stopped them from dragging on forever. The length of each story was good enough to allow variety between each run. 

On the technical side, the graphic design is great and Frostpunk looks gorgeous. I had no issues with performance on my mid-tier 2016 build PC. Frostpunk did however crash and freeze at least 10 times during my playthroughs. 

The only problem I found with the graphics was that most of the building looks very similar and finding certain buildings especially in big city is frustrating. You can find certain building by opening the building screen and hovering your mouse over the building type you are looking for, but this is cumbersome for such a simple task. 

The UI in general could definitely use improvements in many areas. There should be more hotkeys and views to help manage your city. Cycling through a large number of building is also something that could be better. When playing on hard difficulty you will most likely have to restart your mission often when things go wrong, yet there is no restart mission button in the in-game menu. The difficulty setting also resets to normal every time you go back to the menu, which is annoying. I hope they really focus on improving UX in the sequel. 

I am experienced in RTS and strategy games in general, and it took me 88 hours to finish the game twice (normal and hard) with no guides. You can definitely get your money's worth with Frostpunk. I would definitely recommend Frostpunk, if you have any love for strategy games.

You are the leader of a frigid post-apocalyptic colony in the arctic and you must do what you can keep your people fed, warm, and healthy while still gathering enough resources for buildings and technology to face the ever-dropping temperature, all while the clock is ticking.

The overarching theme of this game is that of practicality and efficiency vs empathy and humanity. Using a branching system of available laws, one can push the colony to maximum production efficiency through implementing heartless laws such as child labor, overtime or 24 hour work days, and sawdust in food rations. However, this can and will turn your populous against you, leading to your demise or banishment. On the other hand, if one is too considerate and humane they may find themselves unprepared for the unbelievably freezing storms and thus end up with numerous casualties. 

The story is simple but brilliant, with surprisingly deep lore that the player must find on their own. Essentially, the sun is blocked out and the global temperature plummets, the only places capable of surviving are coal-powered, steampunk settlements in the arctic that were meant to serve as research bases. There are a variety of different scenarios you may undertake, but you invariably arrive and find that all the settlements have already fallen as a result of incompetence, cruelty, or simply overwhelming odds. The world is rich and atmospheric, though extremely depressing and intense. 

All in all, a solid game. I strongly recommend it to fans of steampunk, base management sims, and top of the line gaming computers.

I can enjoy this endlessly for hours. Most games that are society-building hit a dead end at some point because there is either no story to follow along, no motivation, no challenge, etc., but Frostpunk is different. There is a story in each scenario and time limits for goals that can have multiple endings and/or multiple outcomes. I love that this game is genuinely challenging, even on the easy mode. Damn you, Arks...
The shorts that play before each scenario is beautifully made with amazing voice acting, music, artwork, and its simple animation. The graphics in game are beautiful and very detailed instead of just crude models of structures and environment aspects. 
My only issue with the game isn't the game's fault itself, but I do play it on a laptop (Dell Inspiron, idk the specs im not good with hardware details) and it does not flow smoothly on my laptop at all. I've played the game on a desktop (Alienware Aurora r10) before so I do know it is just an issue with my laptop in particular. On my laptop, I can't play the shorts at the start of a scenario and the audio glitches horribly when I try to watch them. Doesn't get in the way of the gameplay, it just becomes slow and drops framerate.
Quite simple chaos simulator, adding management for temp is the funniest part. Law trees aren't as expansive and diverse as I would like. Very stressful regardless.

Overall another masterpiece by 11 Bit studios .Quiet grim no doubt a solid 9.3/10, so close to perfection honestly.
Im adding to this review in Jan 2023, i still come back and play it sometimes, i have actaully played another 50 hours offline too., The game is set in an alternate 1886 Steampunk like Universe At the Height of British empire And its ownerships of expansive territories oversea's in its Colonies.where the eruptions of Krakatoa and Mount Tambora(Volcano's), the dimming of the Sun, and other unknown factors caused a worldwide Apocalyptic global Ice age. Reminds me so much of Snowpeircer the film/Show This game is quiet  intense.Plays like age of empires building system, with choice based system that effects everything,How society is ruled, And your decisions effect thing greatly, example: the choice of rationing food: 1. put sawdust into the food as 'filler' this will bring discontent,people will hate you for it, but people stomachs will be full for longer, 2. soup  and bread instead of full meals raising discontent, but less than'filler' would, 3. extreme rationing, 1 meal a day, This may lead your people to canniblism (Hidden 'Alternative food source' in the tech tree , fighting ,leaving in masses or may even try to overthrow you, Create a religious Order, Or A militia,Dictated  police state .  The morale choices you have to make are tough , complex  and varied and do have later game effect  on the game, so sometimes being the nice ruler at beginning leads to later hardship down the line. This is a very challenging game too. you defiantly cant please the mob always that's for sure. Really does bring meaning to working towards the greater good,The city must survive.  This honestly most meaningful RPG city builder ive played, There been so many times ive not wanted to do something but pushed on and did, even if it meant loss of lives of my people, For greater to good so that city, and people left survive.Each charater has a name ,And you can hear that character talking if you zoom in on the scene, And start recognise voices ,Excellent  minor details even if some charaters have same voices. The voices all do react to whats  happening, hunger, riots, Death, Decisions so forth. The whole feels alive, and you get sense of mood constantly. It really does feel like the wrong choice can lead you brink of death of the city, then the people. generators can be overcharged, to produce more heat, You have check this, often,lf sothe generator works like steam train, more you put in the more you get out, in terms of speed and heat expansion, its not very efficient being late victorian tech, Putting too much coal, wood to make sure everyone warm keeps  everyone happy, but it also puts everyone lifes at risk of it blowing up.. its always risk/Safe option, and sometimes the people, more so lower classes dont understand that. 9.5/10 Still some perfomance issues, Where it will crash, On the dlc's odd, glitch, But extremly polish,I wont give it 10, even though i know could be 10, Its lack of steam workshop support, waiting on mods, this could massively increase the replayabilty ,All dlc , i'd say there up 200hrs of content here. 50 hrs or so if you were just play the main story chapters once. 
Ive returned to frostpunk recently, And all the chapters open up more lore about the world, What happened to winterhome, What became of the refugee's ,What happend with American expedition to Tesla City (Nicola Telsa's Own Electric ran city) What Happend to the Londoners.
And where you currently are on Earth.  The lore and survival is the narrative driving force here . Depending on your personal beliefs, And choices will determine the outcome of your expedition

The concept is great, but as far as game design and mechanics, there is nothing groundbreaking. This is a survival, builder, resource gathering, strategy game, that presents predictable challenges - this has been done, in different settings.

I wanted to give points for the somewhat unique political system, by which, you're sometimes forced to make unsavory decisions - but then I realized how you're actually forced into this situation by the game design. So, I give no points for this.

My chief complaint, however, is the resources this game consumes. Given the graphics (which are not groundbreakingly awesome), and that every other game mechanic is no more complex than any other strategy game, I'm trying to figure out what, exactly, is pinning my CPU and GPU - ALL THE TIME - eventually, leading to slow gameplay. What is this thing calculating, and why? Why do the fair graphics require so much power? Is this just lazy coding? I don't have an answer, because I don't care enough to investigate deeply. All I can say is, for what this game delivers, it vastly mismanages resources.

So, given that this game is the same old strategy game paradigm, in a unique looking wrapper, that pigeon-holes you into making "unique" decisions, and given its horrible treatment of my computer, I really can't recommend this game.

I mean, I'd have just as much fun playing Age of Empires, circa 1997 - and the graphics of Frostpunk aren't even a far cry from that.

The game lulls you in with pretty graphics and a compelling premise, however falls short of actually delivering a unique gameplay experience. It's a very shallow loop of gathering resources and waiting for the next "freeze"...

Overall, Frostpunk is a fantastic game that is well worth the time and effort to play.

+story, gameplay, decisions, 
-some laws (overcrowding vs extra rations - extra rations can be played, but not on harder difficulties, they are just no so good, child shelters vs children job - you need to build a lot of shelters for your children to have hope bonus), gameplay itself gets boring when you get to state when your economy is fine, your people are living in chilly+ conditions, you have good food industry, your medical post and infirmaries can treat sick sufficienty - in this point it just gets boring for me, because you dont have adrenaline here no more, endless mode - I have played mostly builders mode - cause its the best, but same problem after building generator, it is boring after it, 

DLCs
Last Autumn - fine DLC, whole new variety of play, instead of temperature you have safety, instead of hope you have motivation, I personally have less fun playing it than the new home scenario (the winter just gets more adrenaline than building a generator)
On the Edge - fine DLC, settlements are fine, maybe they could use more options in them, also in the Endless mode settlements cannot establish safe route

Overall good game, few things are not so good, but Im excited for Frostpunk vol2, thats for sure

An amazing game that reworks city builidng. It's [b]seriously [/b] hard until you know the formula. The music is superb. The sound effects are amazing. The thump of events makes you say "oh no... what now?" The crack of ice and frost are top notch. I'm very glad that it has options both for having an ending and not, as well as extreme difficulty options. (which I'm too scared to try.)

This game teaches through repetition, like a souls game - you have to know what needs to be done and practice until you get it right. If you're new to the game, you're almost certainly going to fail a couple times. I don't love that you can't really recover from things, as others have noted. There is a right way to do things, you have to know what to do in advance. This is especially true in The Last Autumn. Certain events will happen and you won't be able to respond in the best way without having certain technologies in place that the game never suggested you have. (Just a lesson for next time, I suppose.) You don't know the balances of what resources you'll need when, until you've played a couple times. I also don't love that hope and discontent are resources of their own. Keeping hope topped off and discontent at 0 is actually kind've a mismanagement of resources. 

I do wish that pop-up decisions had a bit more in the way of options. On that note, the final act in the main scenario is a bit irksome as you can never prevent issues. [spoiler] It's just a slow tick till death or salvation because you can't build warmer homes. [/spoiler] I also wish there was more structured story, but perhaps the point is that "not much matters or is left but survival."

Overall, a great game. Definitely a good way to get some gaming ptsd mixed with stockholm syndrome.
