Frostpunk is the third world country simulator in the beginning of an Ice Age.

Jokes aside, this RTS game will push you to your extremes, both in terms of strategy and moral choices. It's set in a steampunk, pre-ice age era in the late 1800's, where extreme colds are setting in and your only source of heating is a giant heat generator. Your job is to keep everyone warm and happy.

Sounds easy, if not for the preamble I just wrote. You see, when you run out of workers in this game, you don't generate them with food like in Age of Empires. You either bring them from an expedition, or you introduce a policy that forces child labour. Too many people are upset because you can't heat their homes? Watchtowers and propaganda. People getting frostbite? Allow amputations and see where it goes from there. The moral dilemma that Frostpunk puts you in is unlike any other RTS game I've played so far, making you question if your decisions are really for the better of the population, or if you are just being a dick.

This extremety comes from the very high difficulty of the game itself. The main "campaign" so to speak (btw, if you only have the base game you are definitely missing out) is more of a tutorial on just how badly you are going to get screwed over. The scenarios pose some new challenges that, once you get the hang of it, will make you SUFFER due to the odd situations it places you in. The biggest problem with these ones is the fact that oftentimes you may be going well with little discomfort and high hopes, when suddenly a SCRIPTED event will turn the tides, and while that is awesome in the challenge aspect, it is also a bit frustrating that the difficulty comes from simply not knowing what will happen. That means that, once you do know how to handle resources and situations, everything becomes easier. I hope Frostpunk addresses that to some degree.

Still, the game is amazing, and I suggest anyone who wants a challenge and a much more gruesome, gritty and dire RTS to give this one a go.

That is, however, the only downside I can point out, the atmosphere is enthralling and I reckon that is the main selling point. However, it's definitely easier to play with the thought of an impending doom and a finite amount of time you have to prepare for it at the back of your mind. Knowing about just how much worse the cold is gonna get and how to prepare for it makes the second playthrough much easier. 
NB: The tech tree, some buildings, and some laws are certainly not worth the investment and it's completely okay to ignore them.

Frost punk is an exceptional game that masterfully combines strategy and survival elements. The graphics are stunning and the game's atmosphere is truly immersive. The game-play is challenging and requires players to think critically and make tough choices. [h1]Overview[/h1]
Maybe one of the hardest base management game I've played lol. But the ruthless of choices. But it's the most realistic ones, nothing that perfect and not having any side effects. Glad I started it easy. I can imagine if I upped difficulty to hard lol. So until I understand how the game works, I'll play easy 1st.
[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+ The game graphics is beautiful, its depressing, steampunk, winter fest. But its really good.
+ The gameplay is a bit weird at start but I starting to get into it. Easy to understand hard to master.
+ The law/decisions everything had its plus and minus so safe often if you regret it lol.
+ You can be full Tyrant or Cults lol. Have their own Upside/Downside. I often choose order tho since its easier to play the game if hope isn't a problems.
+ The resources at the start is hard to get by but later, it get easier.
+ You can have giant automatron if you lack of people to work in factories lol, and they are winter proof. So produce much especially the 1st scenario that will mostly kept your people in home and not working.
+ The soundtrack is really beautiful. None of them felt sore in my ear, immersive even i can feel the temperature drops IRL lol.
[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- The tutorial doesnt tell much especially at workshop upgrades so you need to read the tutorial the most. So the game wont tell you much as you play but there's a guide manual in game so you must read it.
- Save often so you wont regret choices, the game doesnt have autosave which is a bad/good thing for some people. So if youre screwed far you must replay from last save or even from start.
- The snapping of buildings sometimes annoying you must destroy them and it awlays eat some resources and not snap efficiently.
- The steamcore/things that you can only find in exploration is sometimes too rare lol. But idk that's make the game longer I think. It's all RNG there to actually getting what you actually need.
- The scout can be died if storm is coming/random events to save survivors or trying risky things. And they are a bit expensive to replenish and you lose any items they had before.
[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
The game deserve it GOTY title, unlike those self proclaimed Far Cry 6 dan Cyberpunk 2077 that should win scam of the year 2022. The game is really fun, easy to understand, full of consequences, and need time to plan everything and deep thinking. Recommended

Like the UI system for example (any chance making it smaller, so the city that you built is actually visible and not abstracted by giant menu all the time?) . Also I wish this game had "STATS" at a Glance mechanic... Similar to how they had it in Banished or Farther Frontiers, where you are able to keep track of all of your villagers at once. So like a full statistics about all villagers in one place where you could assign and unassign them instead of 3 different places.... Because the game forces you to play in a very tiny area it is very difficult to see the buildings and the road connections.. it took me a few hours to figure out that a lot of my buildings wernt' simply connected to the road and that was the reason why they were not working properly. 

I love the FrostPunk concept, but it is just too TINY to play... Feels like you are forced to cramp your whole city in to this very small tiny area... Every time you zoom out even a little bit the giant frozen wall abstracts like 30%- 40 % of your play view.... I do not understand how this is a feature.  The biggest struggle for me was selecting building (and I know you can see them in you menus, but it not the same) It just feels chaotic.

 I think if the Frozen wall was 2-3 times wide, so you can really sink in to the ground and look at your city it might have helped. I know a lot of people complain about it being difficult, but I actually admire FrostPunk for that. I like the challenge and the Political /community mechanic is actually quiet interesting. Too bad the game has a major flaw design

Frostpunk is a truly unique and innovative game that blends elements of city-building, survival, and resource management into a deeply immersive and challenging experience. The setting, a frozen post-apocalyptic world, is both bleak and beautiful, and the choices you have to make as the leader of your society are often difficult and morally gray.

One of the things I love most about Frostpunk is the sense of urgency and tension that is present throughout the game. Every decision you make has consequences, and you're constantly struggling to balance the needs of your people with the harsh realities of the world you live in.

But it's not just the gameplay that sets Frostpunk apart. The graphics and audio design are also top-notch. The environments are atmospheric and the soundtrack is hauntingly beautiful, adding to the overall sense of tension and desperation.

Overall, Frostpunk is a must-play for any fan of city-building or survival games. It's a thought-provoking and deeply immersive experience that will keep you engaged for hours on end. The combination of challenging gameplay and a fantastic soundtrack make it a true standout in the genre.

The game is maddening and heartbreaking. I think it captures most realities of a post apocalyptic societies. Every choice you make as a leader is consequential down the road, especially in more advanced difficulty levels. Some consequences are predictable, some just hits you in the face like cat's piss in the morning. It's maddening that even if you save, it's not a guarantee that the same problems will not occur down the road.

I especially liked how Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs can be applied by the player to the game. First playthrough half my villagers died because of not lack of housing. Second playthrough got better until food ran out and most starved to death. Third playthrough saw my healthcare being overwhelmed. Fourth failed due to my inability to control discontent and hope. I finally finished it in the fifth playthrough, after carefully following Maslow's theory. I hate school. 

The game also has a good replay value maybe until 100 hrs. As consequences for decisions are largely unpredictable unless you've spent maybe 50+ hrs playing it, the combinations for disasters and problems are thousands.
Nothing bad to say here, the game is fun and multi-directional, replay value is huge and engaging, reasonably priced and updated frequently.  This game is a solid purchase.

I haven't been this obsessed with a game in a long time. I lost interest in strategy games somewhere after Warcraft 3, and was happily entrenched in the world of single player games like Red Dead Redemption 2, The Witcher, Fallout, etc. Then, a friend insisted I explore Frostpunk. 

This game evades so many of the criticisms I have of strategy games. Of of the few strategy games to come out that really captured my attention--The Guild 2, Republic: The Revolution--this one easily reigns. The story is incredibly engaging, which is amazing considering its simplicity. The mood and setting are remarkable, and captured in ways so few pieces of entertainment have been able to deliver on.

When I'm playing, the hours fly, and I'm completely sucked in. It has a way of making you feel like you're in the trenches with the people of your township, and that the decisions you make have real consequences. It focuses less on the grind, and more on the ethics and philosophy, without becoming too stiff, cliche, or self-important. The fact that without military conflict they manage to keep the player engaged is commendable, and the way they do so makes the snow feel like a living being.

All the DLC are worth having and I'll be playing this game again after beating it. I can't wait to play the sequel.

Challenging and very engaging. Basically, a city builder game with a special twist. You have to college coal, wood, steel, and food. You have to house your peeps and take care of them in hosptials. Most of all, you have to worry about the cold and heating everything. It has several different aspects, but you can change the difficulty to meet your play style (ie. make the weather challenges easier, while keeping the social / people aspects normal or harder). Lastly, there are x2 and x4 speed fast forward to speed through some of the slower resource collecting. There is even a pause!

Several different play-throughs / scenario available so if you play it more than once, you can switch it up with a new challenge.

This game is 98% great, but the last 2% is so atrocious it ruins everything.

The NPC AI will find an infinite number of ways to ruin your campaign. They will be "Going to eat" for 4 hours when you switch their job assignment mid-day.  They will spend 12 hours trying to build something during work hours instead of doing the job you assigned them, unless you cancel the building then restart it after the employee goes back to work.  There's even 1 mission where a guy will spawn "Gravely Ill" on the edge of your map, and the game will ask you to save him, and then he just dies while walking to the hospital, and there's nothing you can do about it except reload a save file and build a hospital at that edge of the map.

The dumbest thing I ever saw, was when the Prison tried to Round-Up some criminals, and it randomly chose to send the people in my "Gravely Ill" Care House to prison, and all the "Gravely Ill" people predictably died while walking to prison.

You can tell by my play-time that I spent a ton of time playing this game, because the core strategy mechanics are pretty fun, but it was NOT worth it.

It's the same flawed Banished logic that has overrun the genre with idiocy. The same people who have been cutting wood for an hour and know how much wood they have, now want a dozen facilities built all made of wood that they know they do not have or they are going to revolt. Why did they not revolt when gathering the wood in the 1st place seeing there was not going to be enough wood to fulfill their desires? It's like spending the time and energy to cut 1 tree knowing you want to build a log cabin, then getting mad that you do not have enough wood because you worked so hard. Gaslighting at its finest. I realize it's "just a game" but Banished introduced the laziest brained A.I. logic to ever hit this genre and has ruined the games. A guy taking a poop in the woods takes 5 wood, it costs 3 wood to sleep, 1 wood per thought...wood they KNOW they do not have....then they revolt and blame you. Genre has been ruined by gaslighting. It's a niche to succeed, do things in this exact order at this exact time and wahlah, you win. No skill AT ALL in that other than memorization and just plain paying attention. We are not all so ADD or ADHD we cant follow that formula. It takes 0 skill and creativity, a robot can do it. The game seems mindless to me and follows all the same logic as most now. Give you time to get the resources, then when you do, bombard you with requests to build 10 things out of a stack of twigs and "the challenge" is to build it in the exact order each time......ZzzZZzzZZzz booooooring

It‚Äôs the eve of 2023, and I‚Äôve returned to Frostpunk.

It‚Äôs still very good.

First off, this game is beautiful, to the ears especially. AAA games have this level of polish, but they take weeks of your precious off time, and are never base-building sims. Frostpunk gives you a AAA-like base-building sim in a short playtime (it‚Äôll take you 10-12 hours max to complete the first campaign, which is a full story in of itself and a great stopping point for time-strapped gamers out there; and another 20 to complete the others), and it‚Äôs a treat to behold. And the soundtrack‚Äìoh, the soundtrack‚Äìis possibly enough to justify the playtime by itself. It‚Äôs all quiet foreboding strings when things are warm, but epic and trumpety and Marvelesque, even, when things are going very badly, such as in the great storm featured in the first campaign. The visuals and effects make you feel like you‚Äôre not so much playing at a computer as you are looking through a window, perhaps from the balloon you deploy early in the game, down at the settlement.

Visuals are nothing without gameplay, of course, and Frostpunk mostly doesn‚Äôt disappoint there. It‚Äôs fun to build a city, power it, heat it, and grow it. If you‚Äôre trying the game at a higher difficulty, or going for achievements (I‚Äôm currently trying a Hard No-Death run), the game starts to feel like a puzzle. Everything is deterministic in the game, which I‚Äôm absolutely fine with. You are able to come up with a strategy, a build order, a plan for each mission in the campaign, and if you have the right plan and execute it perfectly, you‚Äôll keep everyone alive through the cold. It‚Äôs fun to do, and it works.

Also, back to the visuals for a moment: The circular design of base-building is unique to Frostpunk, in my experience. The ‚Äúgrid‚Äù is circular, surrounding the generator, resulting in a city that almost seems to be worshiping it. It‚Äôs beautiful. Building a city is fun just because of how it looks.

Which brings me to perhaps the weakest part of the game: I wish there was more to the lawmaking system in the game, especially once you choose between fascism (‚ÄúOrder‚Äù) or theocracy (‚ÄúFaith‚Äù). I don‚Äôt hate that the game has you make this choice: Indeed, a society like this may turn to inegalitarian means for security. But though gameplay surrounding lawmaking starts strong (I like choosing between child shelters and child labor), it turns out to be a little too boring after the Big Choice is made (There are few meaningful choices).

I‚Äôm excited for Frostpunk 2. I want to find out what happens to New London, and I‚Äôd like to see them take another crack at the Laws system in the game.

It‚Äôs still a masterpiece, and regardless of price, you should play it.

--

A good game usually has one of the following three elements. A clean and thorough exexution of a crystal clear idea. An intriguing and finely tuned balance of factors to keep the player wanting more. And a challenging pace to go with an intuitive and emersive UI. A good "story" helps. And an excellent game has all of these obviously. I can truly say, Frostpunk is fun. It feels gritty, choices matter, death is always a decision or two away. The hallmark of a true survival game. Certainly no hand holding. 

Definitely excited for Frostpunk 2.

I only have a few issues about certain game elements.

Why does the coal thumper produce coal that needs to be collected? Why does the coal thumper have a stockpile limit? When the coal mine collects automatically. No matter the amount of gathering posts, there isn't enough hours in the work day to collect it all. Now that I think about it, it's only the coal thumper that produces materials that need to be collected. Seems a little unnecessary to have a building solely for collection of one material. I mean aside from when you've gathered all the starting bundles.

The research tree feels extremely bare bones. I feel like the current available upgrades are only a taste of what extensive list of options that should be discoverable. 

Once you get about 2-4 Automatons, they kinda render your workers obsolete. On endless, it gets pretty boring having 1000 people and only 200-400 actually work. Not to mention how restricted workplaces are, should be way more job spaces. Especially when a storm is on the way and you need to direly prepare.

The Generator gets on my nerves ngl. The short starting range, how even having the overdrive on can spark the "It's about to explode!" decision. How coal hungry the damn thing is all the time. Sometimes it feels like "Coal gathering and feeding a generator simulator".

Why can't you set the work hours? Conditions people aren't allowed to work in? Like a night shift option would make so much sense. Things that would allow you to avoid having sick and gravely ill citizens. To be blunt, I feel the aesthetic was prioritized a little more heavily than the actual game play.

What choises you can make are tightly influenced by your will to win so you have to chose the popular decisions. You cannot create your own community with its own rules. Have you ever wondered what it would be like to try building a snowman in the Sahara desert? Well, Frostpunk is like that except so much, MUCH harder. It's a great, challenging game that pushes you (and your city folk) to the limit. You have to constantly struggle to maintain warmth as the temperature drops, and drops, and drops until you encounter The Storm where all hell breaks loose. You will be forced to make difficult decisions that place you in a moral quandary: do you temporarily raise the heat, thus burning more of your precious coal, in order to raise hope? Or, do you allow some citizens to die off because you need to conserve resources? This game is WILD and I had a lot of fun strategizing together with my husband (who I gave this to for Christmas - only for me to get it for myself moments later haha). I would definitely recommend playing through New Home a few times on different levels of difficulty because you WILL fail at this game when you start, but that's half the frustrating fun of it all. I would definitely NOT recommend this game for rage-quitters (I've been there myself with a few games) because failure is part of the learning process and is what makes this fun to play again and again. Now that I've FINALLY gotten past New Home, I look forward playing through the other scenarios.

This is one of the best strategy management games I've ever played. The setting is unique and interesting, the radial grid adds a new layout planning challenge that I've never experienced (but also just looks so cool). The morality system is really fun and you will have to make a number of really heart-breaking decisions to survive.
I get overthrown a lot but hey, why not try something different the next time around? Easily addicting and replayable. Just don't forget to keep your people warm and you will be fine.

Frostpunk is a steampunk post-apocalyptic 'survival city builder' - one where you become hopelessly invested in the wellbeing of a virtually faceless population, and every sentence ends with 'and then things got worse'.

Things are already pretty bad when you begin the main story; the unexplained climate and societal collapse causes refugees to flee, Fallout Vault style, to isolated generators which pump up heat from the earth to shelter small communities from the snow. As you might suspect, it's pretty stressful being one of a handful of people just trying to stay alive in deeply sub-zero temperatures... but then It Gets Worse. As days go by, the temperature will drop more and more precipitously - avoiding spoilers, you (the player-manager of New London) will need to gather resources, research improvements, and sign laws in order to keep your population not only alive, but also contented and hopeful. Naturally, therefore, the challenge comes from balancing all of these as Things Get Worse for the settlers.

There's a lot to say about the game mechanics - which I would usually put here, but will instead leave further down so that potential new players can experience the game as naively as possible. What must be made clear, however, is how incredibly invested you become in your communities, and how (surprisingly) emotionally taxing it can be when they crumble. I have never cried at a movie and generally don't get hit by strong bursts of emotion, but it was hard not to get a little choked up during the final cutscene, after you've experienced first-hand the struggles settlers have gone through and the decisions you feel you had to make which have lead to, perhaps, more pain and suffering that they need've experienced. The same goes for each of the DLC scenarios, which I experienced several years after completing the main storyline - the [spoiler]failure of a healthcare system overwhelmed by refugees, with each death toll a stab in the heart[/spoiler] in The Refugees; [spoiler]explosion of the generator before you've managed to evacuate everyone[/spoiler] in The Fall of Winterhome; the [spoiler]coming of the first frost, or the industrial accidents[/spoiler] in The Last Autumn; the [spoiler]desperate gathering of supplies for a New London on the brink of collapse[/spoiler] in On The Edge - each one brought those same emotional highs and lows. [strike]I will go into more detail about the DLCs when I review the Season Pass specifically, but[/strike] can't do that lol. To summarise: each scenario functions like a total conversion mod of the main game - some, like The Last Autumn, are virtually unrecognisable at the beginning - but each is, undeniably, worth your time after the main story.

[i]The next paragraph contains low- to mid-level spoilers about the mechanics of Frostpunk which may influence how you play the game - I strongly recommend going in blind![/i]

I played Frostpunk back when it first came out, and (at the time, on a different website) wrote something about the morality system at play, on which the real, player-imposed 'challenge' is based on. In short: when it came out - and, I believe, to this day - it contained one of the more thoughtful approaches to video game morality i'd seen up to that point, an enormous leap forward from Bioshock-tier 'press x to be a terrible person' mechanics. The game forces you to choose between two ideological systems (based on either 'order' or 'faith') which, on top of the positive effects on hope and discontent, provide production and health/healing bonuses respectively; this starts off pretty innocuously with watchtowers and chapels, but as you enact laws deeper into that tech tree it rapidly escalates into propaganda centres and crucifixions. Crucially, however, the extent to which the player-manager delves into the thinly-veiled communist or theocratic nightmare is, ultimately, up to them; when I watched streamers play it at the time, this caused a certain amount of anger as many of them believed they were 'forced' into extreme measures, and adopted an interesting denialism that it could have gone any different - which can be disproven almost immediately on a second playthrough, since understanding of the game mechanics and the general progression of the game makes it quite easy to keep things cheerful, with no need to resort to public executions, torture, etc. That's not to say it's a loss-condition as such to descend into hell, except for insofar as you feel quite bad about torturing a bunch of people; the game will [spoiler]admonish you during the final cutscene if you have 'gone too far'[/spoiler], but will [spoiler]praise you if you don't. 'The line', in case you were wondering, is protector of the truth/righteous denunciation and pledge of loyalty/forceful persuasion - mostly reasonable, I think, although one which has the potential to cause arguments and fuel denialism[/spoiler]. It is this self-reflection - on top of the normal 'discontent was too high/hope was too low' - which constitutes the real challenge, and it's one pulled off so well that you, like me, might well be mulling it over for a while after you've uninstalled the game.

[i]Spoilers end.[/i]

For a compelling story told almost entirely through textboxes, a harrowing struggle against mounting odds, and a thoughtful, reflective attitude to in-game morality, Frostpunk was my singleplayer game of 2018, if not the decade, and remains one of my 'must-plays'. Buy it, play it, consider how fragile life is and the lies we tell ourselves when we shatter it.

This is basically the Dark Souls of civilization survival games.
I personally find the HUD very easy to navigate. Compared to some other civilization games, this game has very little visual clutter.
It is decently replayable, especially with the custom gamemodes, but the progress in each individual run is relatively linear and straightforward. There is an element of RNG when it comes to the placement of resources and scout locations, but it's usually not enough to drastically change how you play the game. There are a few rare random events which can have huge effects on the run, but they're so negative that it's hard for me to want to continue the run. 
As for replayability, I would strongly recommend buying the standard game first, and if you decide you like it, definitely buy the season pass. The other gamemodes are very interesting and change up the game in cool ways.
The only moderate issue I have recently had with this game recently is that the menu for the beacon in the Arks gamemode is terrible. It took me forever to find the little arrow to press to scroll over to the automaton relief option. Would be best to just show all 2-3 options in the menu, there's plenty of room.

If you expect to beat this game in your first play-through then you might as well go down South, get frosted over, and succumb to the storm. Only those that can plan, adapt, and make the tough decisions thru the cold without losing hope are the only ones who can survive. That is the nature of Frostpunk.

I hate this friggin' game.  Hate it.  With absolute abandon.  I hate the brutal mission, I hate the brutal environment, I hate the brutal attitudes of the Karens that we decided to lead NORTH!!!! when the world is freezing over.  (Seriously WTF were we thinking?)  I hate pretty much every facet of the MFing game... and yet I'm still drawn in trying to save the world, every stinking time, even knowing it's doomed.  The DLC has made the gameplay tolerable; most of all, however, I've learned that playing COOP makes the game even a shade enjoyable.  "Wait, what?" You are asking, there's no COOP mode in this game!?!?  And there isn't, officially.  I bought the game for a friend, and we 'play and pass' on the couch when we're in the mood.  That IS fun, because really, misery does enjoy company, and I've found that as a City Builder, I am way less likely to tell my tinys "Die, you ungrateful b-tards!" and go on a suicidal meltdown of the main reactor if I have someone to trade off with, take a break, eat some snacks, and chill for a bit.  So my recommendation to the game builders is this:  create a multiplayer option, and people will keep playing your game.  My recommendation to players is similar:  if you want to play this game over an hour before rage-quitting, buy some DLCs and get some similar-minded friends to join you on the couch.

This might be the hardest game I have ever played. I'm still not making it all the way through on EASY. 
It's also unbelievably depressing. But that being said, it's also beautiful, well made, satisfyingly challenging, and worth your time. I don't frequently find myself invested in the storyline of a game, but this one kinda got me. Really loved the little reference to the explorer Nansen thrown in offhandedly -- I just read Madhouse at the End of the Earth last winter and it's still very fresh in my mind. The only real complaint I have is that the scenarios don't have a lot of varying behaviors within each, so once you know where the storyline is going. On the one hand, it's great because you can start again and develop a new strategy, on the other, it gets a little boring if you're starting again and again and again. The farthest I've been able to get is The Last Autumn because you're largely dealing with labor management rather than fighting to get enough resources in sub-zero conditions. I hope you play, and I hope this developer keeps making games.

I played three times and lost every time and then quit. I knew it was supposed to be a "great game" but I decided I had too many other games I hadn't played to waste time on one like this that had opaque mechanisms (you don't know exactly what's further down the tech tree until you research stuff above it) making advanced planning difficult if not impossible without resorting to wikis & reddit etc to get spoilers on future events & tech. Yes I understood it was kind of meant to be that way, sort of a rogue-like resource management/pausable-RTS, but it just wasn't for me so I quit.

I didn't think about it for a full day. I went on to play a random pickup-&-play game I like until I decided on which meatier game to dig into and put it out of my mind.

But then it came back to me. Thoughts of what I'd done wrong. Ideas for how I might do better. Nothing resembling a grand strategy but something to get me past the first big hurdle I'd found annoying enough to decide I didn't want to deal with it anymore.

So, I loaded it back up & began from scratch. My vague strategy succeeded, I passed the hurdle, and finally understood enough of the mechanics to see the shape of things and want to see where things lead.

In the end, I did not at all have the patience to play it "pure" and wait until l researched things to see if taking a certain branch was worth it down the road, and save scummed at least once when the game presented an option with fairly significant consequences before really explaining them, and oh by the way the outcome is determined by a RNG.

I looked at wikis and reddit posts and tried to glean a bit of knowledge about optimization without completely ruining things by turning it into a min/max Excel spreadsheet with a fancy interface.

And I enjoyed myself along the way. Enough that I'm writing this review right after buying the two main pieces of DLC, one of which is a prequel of sorts and the other-- not a sequel, but more of an epilogue. 

Oh, and I was a right #($hole to the people. Not by design, but because the the NPC's in this game couldn't get their heads out of their undersides. It was the the quite literal apocalypse and they complained about issue of convenience or practicality as though Buckingham was still up & running & living high on the hog while they starved the Irish to death. You know what kills "hope"? (a core metric in the game) Watching your kids die because some idiot caused a riot over having to eat soup or complained that their kid was asked to drag garbage from the rubbish heap to turn it into something useful.

If you've read the game's description here on Steam then it's no Spoiler to tell you the game gives you a minor guilt trip in the form of a "But At What Cost?" at the end if you don't go down the path of sunshine & rainbows. But what more should you do for NPC's at the end of the world? I have them work to do, a  Pub to relax in, and lots & lots of entertainment. I'm not the grinning programmer that thinks they're clever with their "at what cost" question, yet only bothered to put in **fighting pits** as the **only** form of entertainment and then ushers players down the path of either Saintly Demagogue or Bastard Despot. I'm just playing their game-- and enjoying it!-- which says as much about them as it does about me.

Alright alright, it wasn't just fighting pits. You could optionally allow booze & whores. I decided to allow the booze but punish drunkards who abused it. Prostitution seemed a pretty stupid option to waste labor on when I already had to choose between having enough food to avoid eating soup or enough coal so people wouldn't freeze to death. (I chose to eat soup and, awful as I was at the game, still managed to make enough halfway decent design choices so that after a few week everyone was on solid food AND not frozen). Besides, as far as brothels went I figured that anyone who survived to the point where I could make that choice was minimally practical enough make friends with willing partners outside of work hours.

The point is, at the end of the world when you every living person by name and can walk across the entire livable surface of the planet in 5 minutes... at that point? Hope is overrated. Hope is irrational. Hope, taken as a value to be maximized
instead of an an immeasurably small and knowingly unreasonable  delusion is, in fact, deadly. Or at least it is when it's hope that you might do more than just survive, and use that hope as an excuse to decimate the chance of survival. 

All of which is to say, all of the above, despite any appearance of rantish anger or other such ridiculous things to waste time on for a video game, I had a bit of mild frustration playing the game before deciding it wasn't for me, but then gave it one last go and ended up having a pretty good time. I just think it would have been more a more interesting  game world if the developers had moved a bit beyond the simplistic questions of social policy & governance covered in the first weeks of PoliSci 101 and allowed for a broader spectrum of gray area. But while I'm not a game developer I still understand that the complexity & balance of game mechanics for this genre allow for only razor thin margins of error. Balancing even black & white choice making in a way that doesn't kill enjoyment is hard, so my objections here are made very much as observations and wishlists, and not at all chastisements. It's a great game, and I like forward to both the DLC I'm about to play and the full sequel they're working on.

I absolutely loved playing this. I will play any other 11 bit studios games. If you enjoy suffering for progress and excellency, this is your game. It has interesting mechanics that develop as you progress. It is creative and far from flat. When you play expansions or other chapters, it switches it up a bit, keeping you engaged and focused on your management skills under new goals. The story is well-written and interesting. Highly recommend.

Everyone is right. This game is awesome. The sense of urgency is achieved brilliantly, like in no other resource management game I've played. The narrative drives the game, despite it's not a conventional narrative or story-driven game. The way the weather is the enemy is beautiful. 

At some point in my playthrough of the first scenario, a sudden and almost complete loss of hope felt arbitrary, cause the city was thriving. It frustrated me a bit, but the game kept going smoothly.  Haven't run into any other frustrations so far, and can't wait to play the remaining scenarios and dlcs. Well, every day from 7am to 8am the game stutters. I guess it's 'ending the turn', but it may also be my computer.

False Dichotomy is not "moral complexity". That's all that needs to be said on the moral choices of this game. Even if you play the game like a saint, nobody dies, the game STILL acts like you made oppressive choices.

The challenge of the game is entirely driven by scripted events that catch you off-guard.  That's my biggest issue with the game. If you go in blind, you will fail, by design.  You are then expected to replay the game, and this time prepare for the event that you know is coming up from your last playthrough. If you are still playing blind, you'll fail again because of the next event, and play through a 3rd time...


So in the end you approach the game doing things from the first hour on that are setting the foundation for your city surviving the end scenario - that technically you aren't even aware of yet as a leader.


In short, to win in FrostPunk you need to do things that you only know to do because it's either your 2nd+ playthrough or because you are following a guide. I just can't accept that as good game design. 

If I fail at a game, I want it to be because I made a bad choice. Not because I made a good choice but was given no information on what I was actually preparing for so the choices turned out to be wrong only with the blessing of hindsight.

I am genuinely confused about how so many reviewers talk about "choice" in the game when reality is that a choice between "Do one of these two unappealing things, or die" isn't really a choice at all and it doesn't make any real difference in the grand scheme of things of which path you take. You can have no amputations and no deaths and the game will still give you a tough time in the ending...

TLDR: An amazingly well crafted PvE resource-management game with a shorter playtime if you don't like repeating the small number of scenarios. Absolutely fantastic storytelling, soundtrack and theming. Will happily question your morals.

I used to play a lot of RTS games, but I never really played them against my friends. PvP was just frustrating and a way to make us break out in arguments after a 6 hour game (or 20 minute if your friend rushed you). I spent hours and hours playing against the computers though. Then it was about managing resources, and dealing with issues as they showed up.

Frostpunk is a lot like that. The violin in the soundtrack will tug at your heartstrings, and houses will not just show how warm they are on the heatmap, but have different amounts of snow on them depending on how warm they are. The mechanics are solid and make sense, both from a gameplay perspective and from a world theme perspective. 

Frostpunk also asks you fun questions:

Do you bury your dead? 
Do you throw them out into the cold so they become corp-sicles so you can slap their organs in someone else when theirs start to fail? 

Is it wrong to use force to keep people in line for their own good? 

Is it better to help everyone at the cost of your own stability, or do you covet your resources making sure you and your city survive?

It's not a horror game, it's an existential horror game. Each decision has it's own benefits and drawbacks and after a couple missteps suddenly you'll be deciding whether the moral high ground is worth being lynched by the mob because they're panicked and scared.

The weakest part of this game is probably the number of scenarios. There's sadly only 5 or so, and while they're all reasonably different, they're all kinda short, "Endless" mode can be solved and eventually you just have nothing left to do. There are difficulty sliders, but they don't necessarily make the game more fun to replay. Unless you like replaying the same scenario over and over, you'll probably put this game down after 20 or 30 hours...which isn't always a bad thing.

I'd really recommend Frostpunk if you enjoy resource management at all, because it's probably the best example I've seen. A smaller playtime means that it doesn't overstay it's welcome, even if you wish it would. It'll probably give you some new things to think about in the process.
